title: DNA–Methylome Analysis of Mouse Intestinal Adenoma Identifies a Tumour-Specific Signature That Is Partly Conserved in Human Colon Cancer
predicted summary: Aberrant CpG methylation is universal epigenetic trait of cancer cell genomes. However, human cancer samples or cell lines preclude the investigation of epigenetically modified genes occurring early during tumour development. Here we present a list of more than 13,000 differentially altered regions characterizing intestinal intestinal carcinoma of mouse APCMin as model for colon cancer progression. Polycomb Repressive Complex targets are strongly enriched among hypermethylated regions (DMRs) characterising intestinal malignancies. We further demonstrate by bisulfite pyrosequencing of purified cell populations that the DMR signature arises de novo rather than by expansion of the pre-existing pattern in intestinal stem cells or undifferentiated colon cells. Our data allow identification between early conserved epiGENETically Modified regions occurring during colon Cancer development and late stochastic events promoting colon tumour progression

title: Differential Activation of Human Monocytes and Lymphocytes by Distinct Strains of Trypanosoma cruzi
predicted summary: Trypanosoma cruzi isolates are classified into six discrete typing units (DTUs) named TcI to VI, which have different geographical distributions and biological features. Here we evaluated the immunological profiles of human peripheral blood cells exposed to different strains of trypanocytes, Col cl1.7 (Tc II) and Col strain II, using multiparameter flow cytometry. Our results show that infection with both types leads to elevated monocyte activation and elevated expression of TNF-alpha and granzyme A levels during early Chagas disease development. We also observed increased expression levels of CD80 and CD86 levels by lymphocyte exposed exposed with Col and peripheral Blood Cells exposed infected with either type II isolate, but not Col isolated isolate III isolate IV isolate.

title: Analysis of DNA polymerase ν function in meiotic recombination, immunoglobulin class-switching, and DNA damage tolerance
predicted summary: POLN is highly weakly expressed in most tissues, with the highest relative expression in testis. Here we report an in-depth analysis of DNA Polymerase –defective mice and human cells from mice lacking DNA polymerization inhibitors. We constructed multiple mouse models for disruption and detected no anatomic abnormalities, altered lifespans, or altered causes of mortality. Mice with disruptions harboring DNA deletion polymorphisms have reduced crossover frequency at a meiotic Homologous Recombination Hot Spot Harboring insertion/deletion polypeptides suggesting substrates on which DNA crosslink repair is carried out during immunoglobulin class-switching. Our results suggest that mutant mice with disruptively disrupted DNA proteins may have some ability to bypass major grooves and residue residues involved in DNA Crosslink Repair.

title: Lipidated Dengue-2 Envelope Protein Domain III Independently Stimulates Long-Lasting Neutralizing Antibodies and Reduces the Risk of Antibody-Dependent Enhancement
predicted summary: Dengue virus is a mosquito-transmitted virus that can cause self-limiting dengue fever, severe life-threatening hemorrhagic fever and severe shock syndrome. However, the existence of four serotypes has complicated the development of an effective and safe vaccine. Recently, clinical phase 2b trial of Sanofi Pasteur's CYD tetravalent diegue vaccine revealed that the vaccine did not confer full protection against the virus. In this study, we combine immunogen and immunopotentiator components into lipidated subunit vaccine formulations to generate new generations of vaccines against other pathogens. We found that D2ED III-specific antibody responses were higher than those obtained from its nonlipidally expressed counterpart, D2-Enveloponal envelope protein domain III. Our study suggests that this approach could be applied to other SeroTypes

title: Determinants of Cell-to-Cell Variability in Protein Kinase Signaling
predicted summary: Cells reliably sense environmental changes despite internal and external fluctuations, but the mechanisms underlying robustness remain unclear. We studied how fluctuations in protein concentrations give rise to cell-to-cell variability using analytical theory and numerical simulations of ultrasensitive signaling cascades capable of switch-like decision-making and found that these systems can be robustly regulated by altering the expression of protein phosphatases or by feedback/feedforward loops acting at different levels that control different aspects of the dose-response curves. Our results may explain why yeast yeast Signaling Systems show switch decision making with little Cell-To Cell variability.

title: B7-H1 Blockade Increases Survival of Dysfunctional CD8+ T Cells and Confers Protection against Leishmania donovani Infections
predicted summary: Visceral leishmaniasis represents an exquisite model model to study antigen-specific CD8+ T cell responses against VL. Viscocellular parasitic parasites are required for protective immunity against chronic inflammation and antigenic persistence. However, their development, function, and fate have so far not been studied, due to the absence of defined specific epitope markers. In this study we characterize the development and function of antiviral immunotherapies against experimental viscerale lymphomycobacteria. Here we show that L. donovani parasitEs limit their expansion and inducing functional exhaustion and cell death by restricting the expansion expansion by inhibiting function and death. These findings could be exploited for the design of new strategies for immunotherapeutic interventions against ViCLVVL targeting VLCVVH infection. Our results provide new insights into the Development and Function of Antivirally Endoplasmic Cytokine Blockade, which enhances their survival but fails to restore function

title: Two Misfolding Routes for the Prion Protein around pH 4.5
predicted summary: Utilizing molecular dynamics simulation simulations, we show that the protonated imidazole ring of H187 exhibits a dual behavior with two possible transition routes, which mimic specific conditions encountered in endosomes mimicked by the presence of specific chemical chaperones or specific experimental setups. Our results suggest that prion proteins exhibit two transition pathways depending upon which transition pathway is taken. We found that either sidechains downstream of their native cavities undergo electrostatic repulsion with the nearby amino acid group of R136, to which the system responds by pushing either Sidechain downstream from its native cavity. In addition, the interaction between the aromatic acid residue pair is weaker than the other region dependent upon whether the interactions are taken differently depending on which Transition Pathway was taken as well as whether it may have been taken under different conditions. These results support the observation of various fibril morphologies and the outcome of different fibrils.

title: Epilation for Minor Trachomatous Trichiasis: Four-Year Results of a Randomised Controlled Trial
predicted summary: Trachomatous trichiasis (TT) is a chronic disease that affects over half of Ethiopia's population. Trachymosomes must be managed to reduce vision loss and corneal opacity from TT. The long-term impact of repeated plucking of lashes touching the eye is unknown. Here we report the four-year outcome and the effect on vision. Participants randomly randomly assigned to either epilation-only or repeated epilating were randomly assessed six-monthly for two years between baseline and four years after randomisation. Results suggest good quality Epilation with regular follow-up is an alternative second line alternative alternative to surgery for the management of minor Trachomastric Trichiolysis (lower than six lash touching eyes touching eyelashes). Among individuals randomly randomised randomly recruited randomly, participants who either declined surgery declined surgical treatment and controlled their visual impairment significantly differently than those who decline surgery did not have immediate access.

title: The Mannose Receptor Mediates Dengue Virus Infection of Macrophages
predicted summary: Macrophages and mononuclear phagocytes are major targets of infection by dengue virus (DV), a mosquito-borne flavivirus that can cause haemorrhagic fever in humans. Here we show for the first time that the M mannose receptor binding glycoprotein targets all serotypes of Dengue viruses by binding carbohydrate recognition domains directly to envelope glycopeptides associated with both mosquito and human cell–produced antigens.

title: From homeostasis to behavior: Balanced activity in an exploration of embodied dynamic environmental-neural interaction
predicted summary: Here, we describe a simple model of spontaneous neural dynamics that controls an agent moving in simple virtual environments demonstrating the need for homeostatic plasticity both locally (local inhibition adjusts to balance excitatory input locally) as well as globally (regional “task negative” activity compensates for sensory input in another region). This model provides interesting feedback interactions that rapidly destabilize neural activity leading to more stable behavior (trajectories through the environment). Our results suggest complementary functional roles locally and globally balancing neuronal activity.

title: Three distinct mechanisms of long-distance modulation of gene expression in yeast
predicted summary: Recent Hi-C measurements have revealed numerous intra- and interchromosomal interactions in various eukaryotic cells. However, to what extent these interactions regulate gene expression is unclear. Here we developed medium-throughput assays to screen for functional long-distance interactions that affect the average expression level of a reporter gene as well as its cell-to-cell variability (noise). We provided evidence that these patterns of activity are caused by Sir2-mediated silencing, transcriptional interference, and 3D clustering mechanisms that enhance the transcription of endogenous Met4targeted genes in budding yeast yeast.

title: Pch2 Links Chromosome Axis Remodeling at Future Crossover Sites and Crossover Distribution during Yeast Meiosis
predicted summary: Crossover assurance ensures at least one crossover per homologous pair during meiosis I, while interference reduces double crossovers/chiasmata formation. Here, we have investigated the interplay between crossover assurance and nonrandom crossover placement. We demonstrate that crossover inhibition is controlled by the conserved AAA+ATPases Pch2 and PCH2 mutant defects in crossover interference and viable spore viability at reduced temperatures are oppositely modulated by temperature. This association is first detected at the Holliday junction stage and persists until Double Junction resolution resolution occurs at minimum levels and with maximum spacing. These findings suggest linkages between both pathways involved during crossover regulation, suggesting links between these processes.

title: RIN4 Functions with Plasma Membrane H+-ATPases to Regulate Stomatal Apertures during Pathogen Attack
predicted summary: The Arabidopsis protein RIN4 regulates plant immune responses by inhibiting entry of pathogens into plant leaf surfaces during infection. Inhibition of entry allows bacteria to gain entry into the leaf leaf rather than opening apertures thus restricting invasion. Here we identify novel proteins involved in signal transduction pathways, including plasma membrane H+ATPases AHA1 and/orAHA2. We also show that guard cell guard cells function with PMHATPAse activation to regulate aperture openings, which prevented entry by pathogenic bacteria entering plants during infections. Our results suggest that Guard Cell Guard cells functions with the PM HAMP receptor-mediated immune signaling pathways that regulate the establishment of aperture aperture inhibition pathways.

title: Effectiveness and economic assessment of routine larviciding for prevention of chikungunya and dengue in temperate urban settings in Europe
predicted summary: Cities with temperate climate have faced outbreaks of infectious diseases such as chikungunya and dengue, initially introduced by infectious travellers from tropical tropical areas and then spread locally via mosquito bites. To keep in check the epidemiological risk vector abundance can be implemented by local authorities targeted to control mosquito abundance. We assessed the economic effectiveness and economic benefits of routine larvicide interventions targeting public catch basins to limit both the risk of autochthonous transmission and the size of potential epidemics by using mathematical models calibrated on surveillance data collected from ten municipalities in Northern Italy during 2014 and 2015. We found routinely timed interventions can reduce locally transmitted cases of viral diseases by 20% - 33% for a single application and up to 43% if repeated four times throughout the season (dengue: 31–51%). Routine interventions should cover the month of July rather than covering the whole urban area (>35,000 inhabitants). Results from this study may support planning

title: Sensorimotor Model of Obstacle Avoidance in Echolocating Bats
predicted summary: Bat echolocation is an ability consisting of many subtasks such as navigation, prey detection and object recognition. Understanding Bat Echolocation capabilities comes down to isolating the minimal set of acoustic cues needed to complete each task. However, little is known about obstacle avoidance in echolocating bats. In this paper, we propose that the Interaural Intensity Difference (IID) and travel time of the first millisecond of echo train provide sufficient obstacles to steer bat clear from obstacles without reconstructing the 3D layout of their scene. Based on additional simulations modelling the constant frequency bat Rhinolophus rouxii, our paper proposes that obstacle Avoidance can be exploitably exploited by both frequency modulated Bats as well as frequency amphibians alike. We hypothesize that using low level yet robust obstacles allows bat-friendly behaviours to comply with hard real-time constraints of this basic behaviour.

title: Signatures of Arithmetic Simplicity in Metabolic Network Architecture
predicted summary: Metabolic networks perform some of the most fundamental functions in living systems, including energy transduction and building block biosynthesis. Understanding their evolutionary history and complex wiring constitutes a fascinating open question in biology, intimately related to the enigma of life itself itself. Here we apply computational methods developed for genome scale models of metabolic networks to artificial pathways that can optimally perform elementary metabolic functions. We find that synthetic pathways display properties similar to those predicted for natural metabolic pathways, such as the existence of autocatalytic cycles and hierarchical modules, the appearance of universally preferable metabolic compounds and reactions. Our results suggest that evolutionary principles of optimality principles might lie beneath some aspects of biochemical complexity.

title: Estimating recent migration and population-size surfaces
predicted summary: Genetic similarity decays with geographic distance, but genetic similarities vary across time and space. Genetic Similarity between genetically similar individuals can vary dramatically across space and time. However, genetic similarities vary from time period to time periods. Here we present a method to estimate population sizes and migration rates associated with time-varying migration patterns. We apply this method against contemporary European individuals (POPRES) and provide an integrated analysis of recent population structure and growth over the last 3,000 years. Using simulation simulations, we show that the method can reveal changes that are not detectable when using haplotypic structure that ignores genetic differences between individuals. By varying the length of these haplotype sharing tracts we obtain parameter estimates associated to different time Periods.

title: Insulin resistance disrupts epithelial repair and niche-progenitor Fgf signaling during chronic liver injury
predicted summary: Insulin provides important information to tissues about feeding behavior and energy status. Defective insulin signaling is associated with ageing, tissue dysfunction, and impaired wound healing. In the liver, insulin resistance leads to chronic damage and inflammation, but it is unclear how tissue-repair mechanisms integrate insulin signals to coordinate appropriate injury responses. Here we demonstrate that insulin Resistance impairs local crosstalk between niche niche cells and bipotent adult liver progenitor cells (LPCs), which promote epithelial repair and tissue remodeling. We provide detailed account of the role played by insulin receptor substrate 2 in promoting FGF7 expression within the stromal niche cell compartments during chronic injury.

title: Reduced Insulin/Insulin-Like Growth Factor Receptor Signaling Mitigates Defective Dendrite Morphogenesis in Mutants of the ER Stress Sensor IRE-1
predicted summary: Neural Nerves receive excitatory inputs through their dendritic arbors, which often branch extensively to form unique neuron-specific structures. However, how neurons regulate the formation of their particular arbor structures remains poorly understood. In vitro genetic screens using the multidendrite arbor of PVD neurons in Caenorhabditis elegans revealed that regulation of arborization depends on Insulin/IGF signaling pathways independent of other stress sensors involved in neurotrophic differentiation defects associated with pathologies such as Parkinson disease and Parkinson Disease. We found that inhibition of secretion and distal localization to the DMA-1/leucine rich transmembrane receptor-TM is required for maintaining normal arbor structure even in the complete absence of functional activation pathways involved by the secretory pathway. Our work suggests that arbor development defects may be overcome by ameliorating homeostasis and function deficits

title: The Bacterial Response Regulator ArcA Uses a Diverse Binding Site Architecture to Regulate Carbon Oxidation Globally
predicted summary: Despite the importance of maintaining balance between reduced and oxidized electron carriers globally, how cells control carbon balance globally remains poorly understood. Here we provide new mechanistic insight into how carbon metabolism is controlled globally globally by mapping the Regulon of the response regulator ArcA from Escherichiacoli, which reprograms metabolism under anaerobic conditions such that Carbon Oxidation pathways that recycle carbon carriers via respiration are transcriptionally repressed globally. We propose that this strategy favors use of catabolic pathways recycling electron carrier via fermentation kinkin to lactate production in mammalian cells.

title: Zebrafish usp39 Mutation Leads to rb1 mRNA Splicing Defect and Pituitary Lineage Expansion
predicted summary: Retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor function is associated with human malignancies such as pituitary tumorigenesis. Loss of Rb function has been implicated with the development of malignant tumor cell lineage expansion without apparent changes in hormone regulation pathways involved in tumor development. Mutations encoded by yeast mutant mutants encode the neuronal component of cell cycle machinery, neuropeptidase 39 (usp39), which contributes to increased retinohypophysieal cell Lineage Growth. We identified and characterize mutant strains that exhibit a novel mechanism responsible for dysregulated regulation of receptor regulation that may result in PituITary Cancer. These findings provide new insights into the Mechanisms Responsible for Downregulation of Cancer Regulation by neurotrophin specific receptor machinery. Through genetic screens and Positional Cloning, we identify and Characterize zebrafish ubiquitin Specific Peptides 39 mutations

title: Glucocortiocoid Treatment of MCMV Infected Newborn Mice Attenuates CNS Inflammation and Limits Deficits in Cerebellar Development
predicted summary: Infection of the developing cerebellum with human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is major cause of central nervous system disease in infants and children; mechanism(s) associated with this intrauterine infection remain poorly understood. Here we show that peripheral infection of newborn mice with murine CMV results in CNS infection and developmental abnormalities that recapitulate key features of human infection. Our findings suggest that host inflammation induced by infection may underlie deficits in Cerebellar development by modulating inflammation responses to infection-induced inflammation. Using mouse models of infection, we demonstrate that inhibition of inflammation contributes to deficit development in mice exposed to viral infections by activation of neuron precursor cells and altered expression of Developmentally Regulated genes within the cerebelum. These findings provide insight into mechanisms

title: Directed Evaluation of Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli Autotransporter Proteins as Putative Vaccine Candidates
predicted summary: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) is a major diarrheal pathogen in developing countries, accounting for millions of infections and hundreds of thousands of deaths annually. While vaccine development is feasible, extensive effort is needed to identify conserved antigenic targets. ETEC utilizes the autotransporter secretion mechanism to export virulence factors during intestinal colonization following intestinal challenge with enterotoxins. The present study identified passenger domains associated with autotoxins present in pathogenic isolates but absent in the commensal strains. Passenger proteins belonging to passenger proteins comprise carboxy terminal outer membrane beta barrel and surface-exposed amino terminal passenger cargo Terminal passenger Domain proteins, including Ag43, were recognized by antibodies from patients and experimentally infected mice, suggesting that these proteins could contribute to protective immune responses that develop following infection with Enterotropic Enterostomiasis Enteritoxin Entericobacterium enteritis. These proteins provide potential targets to explore

title: Clinical and molecular epidemiology of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever in Oman
predicted summary: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a serious disease with high fatality rate reported in many countries including Crimea and Guinea. The first cases detected between 1995 and 2017 reported to the Ministry of Health (MoH) of Oman were identified in 1995–1996 and none were detected until 2011. From 2011–2017, incidence has steadily increased and 19 (23.8%) of 80 cases clustered around Eid Al Adha Clustering Area were investigated retrospectively by sequencing open reading frame sequence sequences obtained from recent cases against other viral strains collected from the region. Sequential sequencing sequencing allowed comparisons to be made with other viruses obtained previously reported from Caucasus virus sequence Sequences. Comparisons were carried out using phylogenetic analysis of the viral S segments acquired from previous isolates present at Public Health England. These results suggest that there is substantial underdiagnosis of milder cases

title: Fragilities Caused by Dosage Imbalance in Regulation of the Budding Yeast Cell Cycle
predicted summary: Cells maintain their functions despite fluctuations in intracellular parameters such as protein activities and gene expression levels. This commonly observed biological property of cells is called robustness. However, it has not been experimentally shown that dosage imbalance causes fragility of biological systems. In this study, we performed combinatorial genetic tug-of-war experiments to measure quantitative genetic interactions between genes involved in yeast cell cycle stability. We first showed experimental evidence that dose imbalance between CDC14 and PDS1 causes resistance of yeast cells upon overexpression of these genes upon Overexpression with their inhibitory inhibitors Net1 binding with its inhibitor inhibitor Net1. Our results show that the genetic interaction between both genes masking functions of both proteins involved by their inhibition function is Masking function was stabilized by CLB2. We also showed that Regulation of PdS1 by its inhibition prevented resistance against antibiotic binding function.

title: STAT6 degradation and ubiquitylated TRIML2 are essential for activation of human oncogenic herpesvirus
predicted summary: Increasing evidence has shown that activation of human oncogenic herpesvirus lytic replication is crucial for viral tumorigenesis. However, the role of STAT6-mediated signaling remains unclear. Here, we show that degradation of the master regulator of viral replication regulates degradation and degradation via proteasome/lysosome systems. We also show degradation is associated with the increased degradation form of tripartite motif family like 2 (TRIML2) for prolonged cell survival and virion production which is commonly observed in the development of multiple cancer types including Epstein-Barr virus, Herpe Simplex virus 1 and cytomegalovirus.

title: Dengue seroprevalence, seroconversion and risk factors in Dhaka, Bangladesh
predicted summary: Dengue virus activity has been reported in Bangladesh since the early 1960s with the greatest burden of dengue hemorrhagic fever cases observed in 2000. Seroprevalence/seropositivity associated with this activity varied from year to year and individuals/household level risk factors for viral associated disease remain relatively unknown. In this prospective cohort study, participants were recruited from both pre- and post-monsoon periods and blood samples were collected during both Pre and Post-MONSOON periods of 2012. Results showed that the presence of DENV antibodies was significantly increased with age with regard to the number of individuals exposed during the study period. Results further indicated that home-based interventions such as removal of indoor potted plants and increased bed net use would reduce exposure and further decrease risk of viral infections among target populations in the city of Dhaka which may have resulted in a significant reduction in viral infection.

title: A Recombination Directionality Factor Controls the Cell Type-Specific Activation of σK and the Fidelity of Spore Development in Clostridium difficile
predicted summary: Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of nosocomial diarrhea and oxygen-resistant spores that it forms have a central role in the infectious cycle. The late stages of C. difficile activity require excision of the mother cell regulatory protein K and removal of inhibitory pro-sequences required for early development. However, deletion of this prophage-like element resulted in premature activity of cells with altered surface layers. We show that the skinCd genes CD1231 and SpoIIID regulate the expression of both proteins necessary for the late stage of development and the fidelity of infectious cycles. Our data demonstrate that both regulatory proteins involved in both early stage development are Required for both the early stages and Early Stages of Development. Inhibition of SkinCrystallium difficile requires recombination rather than the elimination of additional enzymes involved during development to the terminal cell.

title: Machine Learning Meta-analysis of Large Metagenomic Datasets: Tools and Biological Insights
predicted summary: Shotgun metagenomics provides a rich set of high-resolution features for prediction and biomarker discovery in the context of human diseases and health conditions. However, the use of such high resolution features presents new challenges and validated computational tools for learning tasks are lacking. In this paper, we comprehensively assess approaches to disease-predictive prediction tasks using quantitative microbiome profiles, including species-level relative abundances and presence of strain-specific markers across cohorts from eight large-scale studies. We developed computational frameworks for disease prediction task generalization across studies, with particular emphasis on generality across study sets. Our results provide insights into the strength of potential bacteria-phenotype associations between strains.

title: Baseline CD4+ T Cell Counts Correlates with HIV-1 Synonymous Rate in HLA-B*5701 Subjects with Different Risk of Disease Progression
predicted summary: HLA-B*5701 is the host factor most strongly associated with slow HIV-1 disease progression although risk of progression may vary among subjects carrying this allele. This study explored the interplay between evolutionary rate variation and risk variability among individuals carrying high-risk progressors (HRPs) carrying low risk Progressor genotypes using longitudinal viral sequence sequences from low Risk Pathways (LRPs). Comparatively low replication rates were significantly lower in LRP subjects with higher baseline CD4+ T cell counts than HRP subjects. Comparisons revealed differences in viral fitness measured by viral replication capacity assessed using phenotypic markers along branch branches representing viral lineages successfully propagating through time up to the last sampled time point. These findings provide potential model to explain differences observed differences between subjects carried higher levels of synonymous and synonymous substitution rates along Branch branches.

title: An Atypical Mitochondrial Carrier That Mediates Drug Action in Trypanosoma brucei
predicted summary: Trypanosoma brucei is an important parasitic organism found in bloodstream forms. Here we identify mitochondrial carrier protein TbMCP14 as a prime candidate mediating the action of anti-parasitic compounds. We show here that the carrier is involved in energy production in parasites dependent on energy sources, glucose versus proline in the culture medium, suggesting it may represent an interesting target for drug targeting or targets targeting targets. Our study shows that both Bloodstream and procyclic forms showed reduced levels of Proline dependent energy metabolism compared to control mitochondria.

title: Constitutively active BRS3 is a genuinely orphan GPCR in placental mammals
predicted summary: G protein–coupled receptors (GPCRs) play important roles in physiology and disease and represent the most productive drug targets. However, there may be a significant overlooked fraction of orphan GPCR families that function constitutively in constitutive manner only. We investigated the evolution of the bombesin receptor subtype-3 (BRS3) family in vertebrates in which one member still connects to the original ligands—neuromedin B (NMB) and gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP). Our results demonstrated that nonplacental mammalian BRS3 lost its binding affinity to NMB during adaptive evolution with significantly altered structural structural differences between vertebrate structures and functional data. Based on structural structures obtained from 17 different structures, we identified the first example that might represent new group of newly constructed structures that may represent genuinely Orphan Populations that will never be deorphanized by the discovery of natural compounds. In addition, our results provide new perspectives in addition to current drug-driven

title: SPINDLE: End-to-end learning from EEG/EMG to extrapolate animal sleep scoring across experimental settings, labs and species
predicted summary: Sleep states are classified by trained human experts by visual inspection of raw electroencephalographic signatures, which is laborious task prone to interindividual variability, especially across animals from different experimental studies. To address this challenge, we developed a convolutional neural network-based architecture to generate domain-invariant predictions across different animal cohorts. We achieved average agreement rates of 98% (98%-93%), 93% (93%-97%) with scorings from five human expert scores, far exceeding state-of-the-art solutions that we tested in parallel on this task. Our method, named SPINDLE (Sleep Phase Identification with Neural Networks for Domain Domain-Invariants LEearning), generalized across Different Animal Populations From Different Experimental Laboratories, Different Genetic Mutations, Surgery Procedure Setups and Different Breeding SetUps in order to improve our understanding of Sleep and its perturbations

title: Toxoplasma gondii Relies on Both Host and Parasite Isoprenoids and Can Be Rendered Sensitive to Atorvastatin
predicted summary: Intracellular pathogens have complex metabolic interactions with host cells to ensure steady supply of energy and anabolic building blocks for rapid growth. Here we use intracellular parasite Toxoplasma gondii to probe this interaction for isoprenoid precursors essential for many metabolic processes including signaling, trafficking, energy metabolism, protein translation and signalling pathways. We constructed and characterized mutant mutants for farnesyl diphosphate synthase expressed in Apicomplexa apicoplastes. Inhibitors of host cell precursor pathways synthesize intermediate precursor precursor compounds essential to signal pathways involved signal generation, signal transduction pathways and proteins translation pathways that are susceptible to statin treatment. These mutant strains had mild growth phenotypes similar to wild type parasitobacterium, but lacking the ability to synthraft intermediate intermediates from extracellular infections.

title: Comparative Genomics of the Sigatoka Disease Complex on Banana Suggests a Link between Parallel Evolutionary Changes in Pseudocercospora fijiensis and Pseudocercospora eumusae and Increased Virulence on the Banana Host
predicted summary: The Sigatoka disease complex, caused by the closely related Dothideomycetes Pseudocercospora musae and P. fijiensis, is currently the most devastating disease on bananas worldwide. In order to understand genomic modifications associated with shifts in the species virulence spectra after speciation, we sequenced and analyzed genomes of the three pathogens and Comparative Analysis revealed significant differences in genome size due to different rates of LTR retrotransposon proliferation rates, suggesting that the evolutionary evolution of diseases has evolved different strategies for manipulating host immune responses to plant cell walls. Phylogenetic reconstruction based on single-copy genome architectures strongly supported an earlier evolutionary radiation of genes involved with metabolism and metabolism pathways related to metabolism. However, Genomic analyses suggested that they shared complementary patterns of expansion and contractions that could be exploited in disease management programs that can exploit their pathogenic core

title: Blood Transcriptional Profiling Reveals Immunological Signatures of Distinct States of Infection of Humans with Leishmania infantum
predicted summary: Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) can be lethal if untreated; however, the majority of human infections with the etiological agents are asymptomatic individuals. VL patients displayed differential gene expression profiles associated with activation of lymphocyte activators via MHC class I and type I interferon signaling pathways and gene modules reflecting increased proportions of monocytes and neutrophils after treatment of disease. This study provides insights into transcriptional signatures that can drive protective mechanisms during distinct states of infection of humans. We used Illumina Bead Chip microarray technology to analyze gene Expression profiles obtained in blood samples obtained from active VLP patients, patients under treatment, controls and controls. Genomic analyses revealed distinct gene profiles differing gene profiling profiles reflecting different gene sets related to proteins involved in the development and progression of the disease as well as differences in gene set enrichment networks reflected increased levels of myeloid cells following treatment.

title: A Simple Mechanism for Complex Social Behavior
predicted summary: Complex social strategies result from conflict between the self-interests of exploitative individuals that avoid paying their fair share of any costs. This conflict often results in the evolution of complex strategies and counterstrategies known as cooperative behavior. However, genetic mechanisms underlying complex social behaviors are poorly understood. Here we combine mathematical modeling, molecular genetics, and developmental approaches to investigate whether simple rules governing interactions between individuals can be sufficient to generate the sort of apparent complex changes seen in this system without the need for partner recognition. Our results provide support for the simple model of social signal production and response observed in Dictyostelium discoideum isolates collected from the wild. We show that these simple measures can explain complex patterns of variation generated by natural genetic diversity present in strains isolated from wild populations.

title: A secretion-enhancing cis regulatory targeting element (SECReTE) involved in mRNA localization and protein synthesis
predicted summary: Localization of secreted/membrane proteins (mSMPs) to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) facilitates translational translocations between secretory proteins expressed on the inner membrane of prokaryotes. title: Multiple introductions of the dengue vector, Aedes aegypti, into California
predicted summary: The yellow fever mosquito Aedes aegypti inhabits much of the tropical and subtropical world and is the primary vector vector of Zika viruses and Dengue viruses. Breeding populations of this mosquito were first reported in California (CA) in 2013. These results expand previous genetic analyses using microsatellites on collections from Northern CA in 2013 indicated the South Central US region as the likely source of introductions given rise to Northern and Southern CA populations. Our results suggest that northern and southern populations were likely founded by two independently introduced groups which came from the Southwest US/northern Mexico regions respectively. We genotyped samples at multiple time-points (two years apart), consistent with permanent in situ breeding. Genetic data provide new insights into the origins and evolution of these populations which may have implications for mosquito surveillance activities and vector control activities not only

title: Comparative and Functional Genomics of Rhodococcus opacus PD630 for Biofuels Development
predicted summary: Rhodococcus synthesizes energy-rich triacylglycerols (TAGs) from organic substrates and stores them as energy products. Here we describe the genetic basis of the Actinomycetales bacteria Ralstonia glutamicum 13032. We identified genes implicated in the R. opacus PD630 TAG cycle pathways by metabolic reconstruction and gene family analysis. Our results provide insights into the metabolic pathways involved in Rallyopsis metabolism by Comparative Analysis of Genome Sequencing and Genomic Sequential Analysis.

title: Investigations of Oligonucleotide Usage Variance Within and Between Prokaryotes
predicted summary: Prokaryotic genomes can encode information encoded by short oligonucleotide frequencies, i.e., short range variants within host-associated bacteria and archaeal organisms. We investigated the statistical information potential of different DNA ‘word-sizes’ to investigate how DNA compositional variation differs between hosts within and between host bacteria. Our results suggest that prokARYotic DNA is predominantly Short Range correlated, which suggests that information expressed within hosts differed greatly from those found within free-living bacteria compared to freeliving Archaels and Bacillibacterium. The results show that Pronounced information can differ more within AT-rich regions than free living bacteria, and this variation was more dissimilar and less biased than non-coding regions.

title: Transcriptome Analysis of Targeted Mouse Mutations Reveals the Topography of Local Changes in Gene Expression
predicted summary: Targeted gene expression has not been extensively studied extensively in mouse models. Local effects are likely due to a number of factors including compensatory regulation, loss or disruption of intragenic regulatory elements, the exogenous promoter in the neo selection cassette, removal of insulating DNA around the target gene trap, deletion variants around target genes flanking target targets, and local silencing caused by disruption of normal chromatin organization or presence of excretory DNA in target mice. Using genome-wide sequencing, we evaluated tissue tissue samples from 44 homozygous mutants compared with C57BL/6N controls. We found only 47% of alleles with local down-regulated genes were found with significantly higher frequencies than expected from Genomewide Surveys. title: A novel evolutionary conserved mechanism of RNA stability regulates synexpression of primordial germ cell-specific genes prior to the sex-determination stage in medaka

title: Acute Schistosoma mansoni Infection Increases Susceptibility to Systemic SHIV Clade C Infection in Rhesus Macaques after Mucosal Virus Exposure

title: Phylodynamics and Human-Mediated Dispersal of a Zoonotic Virus

title: γδ T Cells Confer Protection against Murine Cytomegalovirus (MCMV)

title: Barriers of attendance to dog rabies static point vaccination clinics in Blantyre, Malawi
predicted summary: Rabies is a devastating yet preventable disease that causes around 59,000 human deaths annually. Here we investigated barriers to attendance at static point vaccination campaigns offering free vaccinations for dogs in Blantyre, Malawi using logistic regression and distance estimation techniques. We found that dogs from areas with higher proportions of people living in poverty were more likely to attend static Point vaccination points than dogs either because they were not aware of vaccination activities or they could not handle their dogs properly. Our findings will inform design of future vaccination programmes in Sub Saharan Africa which may lead to improved vaccine coverage achieved by static points alone.

title: Insights into the Trypanosome-Host Interactions Revealed through Transcriptomic Analysis of Parasitized Tsetse Fly Salivary Glands

title: Antifungal compounds from Streptomyces associated with attine ants also inhibit Leishmania donovani

title: Population Genetics of Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense: Clonality and Diversity within and between Foci

title: A network diffusion approach to inferring sample-specific function reveals functional changes associated with breast cancer

title: Global Cross-Talk of Genes of the Mosquito Aedes aegypti in Response to Dengue Virus Infection

title: Impact of repeated annual community directed treatment with ivermectin on loiasis parasitological indicators in Cameroon: Implications for onchocerciasis and lymphatic filariasis elimination in areas co-endemic with Loa loa in Africa
predicted summary: Loiasis is a filarial infection endemic in the rainforest zone of west and central Africa particularly in Cameroon, Gabon and Democratic Republic of the Congo. Here we identified regions of mitochondria that may contribute to dysregulated glycolytic metabolism in mice exposed to high glucose-stimulated insulin-dependent Insulin Granule ExocytoSis. These genes were found to play key roles in metabolic regulation of insulin metabolism including hyperpolarisation membrane potential, reduced membrane Potential and low insulin production. Our results provide insight into genes involved in hyperglycemia that could explain metabolic changes occurring in mouse models of diabetes.

title: Defining objective clusters for rabies virus sequences using affinity propagation clustering

title: The Transcription Factors Sox10 and Myrf Define an Essential Regulatory Network Module in Differentiating Oligodendrocytes

We show that both proteins cooperate to implement synergistic activation of several genes as evidenced by the physical interaction between proteins involved during MyRf transcription proteins and the synergetic activATION of various genes during myeloidization programs.

title: A regularity index for dendrites - local statistics of a neuron's input space
predicted summary: Neurons collect inputs from other neurons by sending out arborized structures called dendritic structures. Here we analyze the association between local statistics of input distributions and branching structures using a regularity index R, independent of cell size, characterizing their spatial distribution. We find that Branching Structures depend strongly on cell types leading to potentially cell type specific branches characteristically altered significantly. Furthermore, Branch Point Distributions correlate more strongly with input Distribution statistics than Branch Structure statistics, suggesting that they might reflect features of branch structure that are not captured by commonly studied branch statistics. Our results suggest fundamental differences in branch structures that may reflect Cell Type specific features.

title: Dietary zinc and the control of Streptococcus pneumoniae infection

title:
A New Approach to Dengue Fatal Cases Diagnosis: NS1 Antigen Capture
                    in Tissues
predicted summary: Dengue is the most important arthropodborne viral disease worldwide in terms of morbidity and mortality caused by any of the four serotypes of dengue virus (DENV-1 to 4 Serotypic Antigen Capture Assays). Using tissue specimens obtained from previously confirmed fatal cases (DHF and fatal Cases) that occurred in 2002 in Brazil, we investigated the usefulness of three different methods for detection of NS1 antigen capture: First generation Early ELISA (PanBio Diagnostics), Platelia Ag Strip (BioRad Laboratories) and the rapid test Rapid Test Ag strip. The results showed that the ability to capture DENV was highly sensitive in liver, lung, kidney, liver and lymph nodes obtained by the first generation First Generation Early Early antibody detection Tests. However, the results suggest that new approaches useful for postmortem confirmation play an important role in the disease surveillance surveillance.

title: Crowdsourcing to expand HIV testing among men who have sex with men in China: A closed cohort stepped wedge cluster randomized controlled trial
predicted summary: Crowdsourcing may be useful tool for designing innovative community-based HIV testing strategies to increase HIV Testing among at-risk men in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Participants who received two HIV tests received higher rates of HIV self-testing than controls during the intervention period as opposed to control periods. Results suggest crowdsourced HIV intervention could be effective for developing and strengthening community HIV screening services tailored specifically targeted targeted targeting groups targeting individuals who have sex with men (MSM) in cities across China from August 2016 to August 2017. The final intervention also increased HIV Self-Testing uptake and Facility Self Testing, Facility self Testing, condom Use, facility Self Testing and Condom use during intervention periods as well as facility self testing.

title: Subversion of natural killer cell responses by a cytomegalovirus-encoded soluble CD48 decoy receptor
predicted summary: Cytomegaloviruses (CMVs) encode proteins encoded by different pathogenic viruses. However, their properties and biological relevance remain as yet unknown. Here we describe the presence of A43, the viral protein labeled CD48 homolog expressed on the surface of most natural killer cells, which modulates function of natural Killer cells by masking its natural receptor 2B4 with high affinity and slow dissociation rates. We show that this viral proteins mask receptor2B4, thus impeding effective immune control during viral infections. Our findings provide a novel example of viral immune defense strategies developed by viruses developed to counteract host immune responses during infections during infection during pathogenesis.

title: Oligodendroglial myelination requires astrocyte-derived lipids
predicted summary: Myelin membranes are thought to be cell-autonomously assembled by central nervous system (CNS) cells. Here we report the surprising finding that in normal brain development, a substantial fraction of the lipids incorporated into Central Nervous System membrane proteins are contributed by oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells in vitro supplemented by horizontal glycolipid fluxes. We conclude hypomyelinated CNS myeloid membrane-aggregation is required for neuroimaging and neurodevelopmental development. Our findings suggest that vertical glycoprotein flux is important feature of normal Brain Development.

title: Improving Contact Prediction along Three Dimensions
predicted summary: Correlation patterns in multiple sequence alignments of homologous proteins can be exploited to infer information on structural properties of their members. The typical pipeline to address this task is to filter and align raw sequence data representing evolutionarily related proteins; choose a predictive model to describe them; (ii) interpret model parameters and interpret them in terms of structural characteristics such as accurate contact maps. We show here that it is possible to improve significantly along the second dimension by going beyond the pairwise Potts models from statistical physics which have hitherto been the focus of the field of contact prediction. Our results show that the combined improvements along both dimensions are as large as any reported to date.

title: HLA-A2 and B35 Restricted Hantaan Virus Nucleoprotein CD8+ T-Cell Epitope-Specific Immune Response Correlates with Milder Disease in Hemorrhagic Fever with Renal Syndrome

Based on the results obtained by enzyme-linked immunospot immunoassays, our results show that the frequency of EpitopE–specific response could be significantly higher in mild/moderate patients than in severe/critical ones at acute stages of disease.

title: Impact of the Ebola outbreak on Trypanosoma brucei gambiense infection medical activities in coastal Guinea, 2014-2015: A retrospective analysis from the Guinean national Human African Trypanosomiasis control program

Passive screening campaigns dramatically decreased during this outbreak period, but retention rates in follow-up were significantly decreased. title: Genome-Wide Association Identifies a Common Variant in the Reelin Gene That Increases the Risk of Schizophrenia Only in Women
predicted summary: Sex differences in schizophrenia are well known but their genetic basis has not been identified. We performed genome-wide association scans for schizophrenia in Ashkenazi Jewish populations using DNA pooling. Our results show that the female-specific association between RELN and schizophrenia is one of the few examples of replicated gene-sex interaction observed in any disease. A significant effect was observed only in women, replicating the initial result (p = 2.1  103 in females; P = 1.58 controls). We found that women carrying the common genotype were associated with the SNP in the fourth intron of reelin gene, rs7341475, with significant gene interaction only among women.

title: The Novel Candida albicans Transporter Dur31 Is a Multi-Stage Pathogenicity Factor
predicted summary: Candida albicans is the most frequent cause of oral fungal infections. However, the exact pathogenicity mechanisms involved during oral candidiasis are unknown. Interestingly, deletion of orf19.6656 caused significantly less epithelial damage compared to wild type C. albiana mutant deletions that caused the strongest reduction in pathogenesis. Our results provide evidence that Dur31 transports histatin 5, which is considered one of the very first examples of microbial driven import of this highly highly toxic antimicrobidiopeptide. Inhibited by DUR31/Dur31 functions as substrate transporters involved in multiple stages of candididiolysis including surviving attack by human neutrophils, endocytolysis

title: A Network Model to Describe the Terminal Differentiation of B Cells
predicted summary: Terminal differentiation of B cells is essential for humoral immune response in vertebrates and is achieved by the concerted action of several transcription factors in response to antigen recognition and extracellular signals provided by T-helper cells. However, there is no general consensus regarding the structure and dynamical properties of regulatory networks controlling terminal differentiation processes. Here we describe structural structures and dynamics involved in terminally differentiated terminal B cell differentiation by modeling the regulatory network as discrete and continuous dynamically coupled systems consistent with the observed patterns reported for the Naive, Mem, and PC cell types. Structure Structure structures of these structures provide structural structure consistent to the patterns of activation observed for all possible single loss- and gain-of-function mutants reported previously reported in vitro experimental data available available in the literature.

title: A Drosophila Model of High Sugar Diet-Induced Cardiomyopathy
predicted summary: Diets high in carbohydrates have long been linked to progressive progressive heart dysfunction, yet mechanisms by which chronic high sugar leads to heart failure remain poorly understood. Here we combine diet, genetics, and genetic engineering to establish adult Drosophila melanogaster model model of chronic sugar-induced heart disease. We demonstrate that increased metabolic activity within metabolic pathways led to cardiac defects and structural damage. Increased metabolism resulted in reduced insulin signaling defects, collagen accumulation and fat accumulation. The result was a shorter life span that was more severe in the presence of reduced Insulin Signaling defect. These findings highlight enzymes within the metabolic pathway pathways as potential therapeutic targets for treatment-targeting mechanisms involved by glucose metabolism.

title: Synaptonemal Complex Components Promote Centromere Pairing in Pre-meiotic Germ Cells

We further demonstrate that components of central region of synaptonemal complex proteins are already expressed in the mitotic region and localize close close to centroperipate centrumphibians, which are key features to ensure reductional segregation in amplifying germ Cells.

title: Yersinia enterocolitica Targets Cells of the Innate and Adaptive Immune System by Injection of Yops in a Mouse Infection Model

title: Suppression of Virus Specific Immune Responses by IL-10 in Acute Dengue Infection

These results underscore the importance of hemozoin as a protective mechanism to allow insect fertility and malaria transmission simultaneously by reducing both malaria replication and transmission. We demonstrate that selective blocking inhibition of glutamine crystallation resulted Systemic overload and redox imbalance. title: Detection of IgM Antibrucella Antibody in the Absence of IgGs: A Challenge for the Clinical Interpretation of Brucella Serology

Seventeen patients presented with pain, fatigue and fever during 6–12 weeks with no improvement and 1 was asymptomatic. Our results suggest that the use of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for the detection of antibody antibodies antibody antiBrucelella antibodies is needed to confirm acute inflammation.

title: A Somatically Diversified Defense Factor, FREP3, Is a Determinant of Snail Resistance to Schistosome Infection

We show for the first time that knockdown inhibition is associated with strong losses in resistance to Schistidium manSONi infection in the resistant strain of Biomphalaria glabrata. This study also highlights the role of specific immune molecules with distinct structures belonging to proteins found only in gastropod hosts. The results reveal new insights into how snail susceptibility mechanisms differ from snail defenses

title: Steps Toward Creating A Therapeutic Community for Inpatients Suffering from Chronic Ulcers: Lessons from Allada Buruli Ulcer Treatment Hospital in Benin
predicted summary: Buruli ulcer (BU) and other chronic ulcers require long term hospital care for patients suffering from advanced stage ulcer syndromes. This paper describes a pioneering attempt to establish therapeutic communities in Benin to address this challenge using social scientists trained to serve as therapy facilitators and culture brokers. Participants were asked questions about their illness, their treatment duration, and their level of social support. We found that most patients had very little information about the identity of their disease and the duration of treatment needed for their healing process. Individual counseling and drop-in counseling sessions provided an opportunity for individual patients and staff to air grievances in non-confrontational ways and helped reduce patient concerns about treatment and treatment. Patients with ulcerous ulcer sufferers asked why patients received preferential treatment for one disease, given special medicines, or charged less for treatment requiring Long term residential Hospital care. The results revealed that many patients did not know what treatment they needed to receive prior to treatment, suggesting that they were being treated differently than others. Results suggest that the model presented is relevant for other types of patients with cultural adaptation

title: Down-Regulating Sphingolipid Synthesis Increases Yeast Lifespan
predicted summary: Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells live longer than other cells. Sphingolipids are found in all eukaryotes and they play evolutionary conserved roles downstream of the target target of rapamycin, TOR1, protein kinase S6. Using genetic strategies to lower the rate of growth signaling from S6, we show that pharmacological down-regulation of one or more S9 proteins may provide a means to reduce age-related diseases and increase longevity in other organisms independent of genetic restriction. The longer lifespan is due in part to reduced activity of Sch9 protein activity. Longer lifespan arises independently of metabolic restriction and stress resistance. We speculate on ways that altered levels of stress signals may mediate these aspects of increased lifespan. Our findings suggest that genetically down regulation of S8 proteins could provide new strategies for regulating lifespan

title: Intronic CNVs and gene expression variation in human populations
predicted summary: Intronic deletions are the most frequent copy number variants (CNVs) in protein-coding genes in human Populations. They account for the majority of DNA sequence sequence but little is known about their population patterns of structural variation and their functional implications. Here we combine extensive maps of CNV-Deletions maps to show that intronic loss is associated with significant differences in gene expression levels in the population. We also found that intracellular deletion losses can contribute significantly to the variability of gene Expression and Promoter 3D interactions in other genes. This suggests that transcriptional variation is important for many proteins that are highly conserved at the protein sequence level and contributes to variation in expression and promoter interactions with other proteins involved in disease-related interactions.

title: Prediction Errors but Not Sharpened Signals Simulate Multivoxel fMRI Patterns during Speech Perception
predicted summary: Speech perception depends on Combining sensory input with prior knowledge. However, the mechanism by which these two sources of information are combined remains unclear. In speech perception, behavioural models suggest that expected features of speech input are enhanced or sharpened via interactive activation (Sharpened Signals), conversely Predictive Coding suggests unexpected features are suppressed so that unexpected Features of Speech input (Prediction Errors) are processed further. We combine computational models of how sensory detail and informative expectations influence speech representations with computational modelling methods to provide evidence in favour of Prediction Coders. This work provides evidence for the combination of Sensory Detail and Informative Expectations to have additive effects because they both improve the accuracy of word report and reduce the BOLD signal in the posterior superior temporal lobe regions.

title: Comparison of the Diagnostic Accuracy of Three Rapid Tests for the Serodiagnosis of Hepatic Cystic Echinococcosis in Humans
predicted summary: Cystic echinococcosis (CE) is characterized by cystic cysts in well defined ultrasound stages. Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) may be useful in resource-poor settings to complement ultrasound diagnosis of CE when imaging results are unclear and conventional serology techniques may not be available due to lack of laboratory equipment, which may pose problems with accurate diagnosis. Here we evaluated the diagnostic accuracy and specificity of rapid diagnostic test kits for CE diagnosis in rural endemic areas where expertise in ultrasound is scant. VIRapid HYDATIDOSIS performed best among the examined kits, but all RDT kits were poorly sensitive in the presence of inactive cystes, suggesting difficulties with accuracy. Our results suggest Rapid diagnostic Test kits may provide additional diagnostic tools for the diagnosis and treatment of Cytoplasmic Echinocephalitis in remote areas with limited resources.

title: Minimum requirements and optimal testing strategies of a diagnostic test for leprosy as a tool towards zero transmission: A modeling study
predicted summary: The availability of diagnostic testing strategies to detect subclinical leprosy cases is crucial to interrupt transmission of M. leprae transmission. In this study we assessed the use of such diagnostic tests and optimal testing strategy in order to effectively reduce the new case detection rate (NCDR) of clinically diagnosed cases. We found that using diagnostic test strategies could significantly reduce NCDR significantly at least 50%. However, this strategy is only favorable in high endemic settings. To effectively prevent new cases within 8–10 years of diagnosis or treatment, household contact sampling could yield the highest number of prevented cases obtained in households with coverage 50% compared to households without coverage (100%). In high endocrinological settings, the number prevented new Case detection Rate could be reached within 10 years following treatment.

title: Induction of systemic, mucosal and memory antibody responses targeting Vibrio cholerae O1 O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) in adults following oral vaccination with an oral killed whole cell cholera vaccine in Bangladesh
predicted summary: Vibrio cholerae O1 and O139 polysaccharides mediate protection against chronic diarrheal diseases. However, protective efficacy extends for more than a month after vaccination. Antibodies targeting the O-specific Polysorbate Polypeptide (OSP) of V. cerevisiae were more prominent than anti-Inaba responses. These responses were detectable within 30 days after completion of the 2-dose regimen separated by 14 days following vaccination, suggesting Bivalent-OCV-induced immune responses targeting OSP. Our results call into question the utility of this regimen Separated By 14 Days in adults in this highly highly endemic area of Bangladesh.

title: Genomic Analysis of the Kiwifruit Pathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv. actinidiae Provides Insight into the Origins of an Emergent Plant Disease
predicted summary: Psyringae pv actinidiae (Psa-V) originates from domestication of plants, thus providing limited opportunity to understand the concomitant emergence of crop diseases caused by domesticated crops such as Kiwifruit chinensis. Our analysis provides evidence that PpV is comprised of distinct PPHGI-1-like conjugative elements consistent with disease arising by independent sampling from source populations associated with wild Actinomyces domesticatum. Based on SNP analyses of two circularized and 34 draft genomes, our analyses provide evidence of rapid systemic movement of PppV from a single clone within the last 10 years. These results highlight the importance of the source population as reservoir reservoirs of new disease.

title: A PNPase Dependent CRISPR System in Listeria
predicted summary: Listeria monocytogenes is emerging as a model organism to study RNA-mediated regulation in pathogenic bacteria. A class of non-coding proteins called CRISPRs (clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats) has been described to confer resistance against invading bacteria and conjugative plasmids. Here, we characterize the structure of the proteins encoded by the newly identified Polynucleotide PNPase enzyme, RliB, expressed and processed in the listeria strain EGD-e strain, which is completely devoid of cas genes. We show that both processing and activity depend upon the activity of proteins with DNA binding domains that encode proteins involved in DNA interference proteins. Our data reveal that this enzyme is required for both Processing and Activity dependent functions.

title: Inferring Epidemic Contact Structure from Phylogenetic Trees
predicted summary: Phylogenetic tree imbalances allow us to quantify the extent to which the structure of the contact network leaves a detectable genetic fingerprint in the pathogen population. We show here that the shape of these trees strongly depends upon contact structure. Our results show that structure strongly influences shapes generated by disease outbreaks with different types of contact networks. In particular, we demonstrate that structures strongly influence shape shapes underlying epidemic spreading patterns strongly dependent on contact structures. Using random mixing simulations from the Swiss HIV epidemic we find that this epidemic has significantly more unbalanced tree than would be expected from Random Mixing scenarios.

title: Structure-Based Predictive Models for Allosteric Hot Spots
predicted summary: Allostery is the binding event that determines the behavior of distant sites in proteins. Identifying residues that relay the signal between sites remains a challenge. We have developed predictive models that discriminate between known allosteric hotspots and non-known allostically important sites using support-vector machines, widely used machine learning method. These models performed well on independent data sets consisting of known aromatic amino acids from 5 proteins implicated in allOSTery. Based on experimental characterization of proteins, these models identified known variants associated with known functional significance. The prediction patterns corresponded to known binding events involved in binding proteins involved by binding protein binding pathways. Our models were consistent with previous work describing sparse networks of aromatically important residue regions in the interior of the structures, suggesting that these regions correspond to functionally important structural regions implicaTED in AllOSTRY.

title: Toward a theory of coactivation patterns in excitable neural networks
predicted summary: Brain networks play central roles in brain activity patterns underlying functional connectivity patterns. The relationship between structural connectivity (SC) and Functional Connectivity (FC) depends on specific topological features of brain networks or models used for describing neural dynamics. Here, we develop analytical framework for understanding the contribution of essential topology elements, such as common inputs and pacemakers, to the coactivation of neurons. We demonstrate the validity of the framework by Comparative Simulation Simulations with numerical simulations of various exemplar networks.

title: Establishment of a Reverse Genetics System for Studying Human Bocavirus in Human Airway Epithelia
predicted summary: Human bocavirus 1 (HBoV1) has been identified as one of the etiological agents of wheezing in young children with acute respiratory-tract infections. In this study, we obtained viral DNA extracted from an infected patient obtained from human embryonic kidney 293 cells and obtained the sequence sequence of full-length human genome sequence including both termini cloned using reverse genetics sequencing methods. We demonstrated genome replication, encapsidation of viral genome terminus, and release of human immunoglobulin-1 viruses capable of productively infecting primary human airway epithelia (HAE) from the primary respiratory surfaces. Importantly, HAE showed hallmark hallmarks of lung respiratory tract injury, including disruption of tight junction barrier disruption, loss of cilia and epithelial cell hypertrophrophy associated with respiratory infection. Our results demonstrate the first cell line-based culture system for the study

title: The Wnt Pathway Controls Cell Death Engulfment, Spindle Orientation, and Migration through CED-10/Rac
predicted summary: Caenorhabditis elegans Wnt signalling pathways can regulate changes in cell fates or tumours by remodelling of the cytoskeleton. Here we show that polar signals produced by the WNT pathway can reorganize the spindle machinery involved in many developmental processes. Our results suggest that the two partially redundant signals defined earlier may act in tandem in early embryogenesis, suggesting that they may function as engulfment machinery Regulation Regulation requires the MOM-5/Fz receptor, GSK-3 kinase, and APC/APR-1 which activates two separate branches to regulate remodeling machinery.

title: Tissue-specific degradation of essential centrosome components reveals distinct microtubule populations at microtubule organizing centers
predicted summary: Non-centrosomal microtubule organizing centers (ncMTOCs) are found in most differentiated cells, but how these structures regulate their organization and dynamics remains poorly understood. Here, we optimized tissue-specific degradation systems to test the role of the essential centrosomecellular nucleators GIP-1/GCP3 recruited at the centrosome–localized apical epithelial cellorganizing centers, where they both localize in Caenorhabditis elegans embryonic intestinal epithelium. Our results suggest that different structures use discrete proteins for their function at different developmental stages differing structures that compete for limited resources. We optimize tissue specific degradation Systems to characterize the roles of these proteins at cellOrganizing Centers, suggesting Different Structures Use Different Proteins for Their Function.

title: The Fitness Landscape of HIV-1 Gag: Advanced Modeling Approaches and Validation of Model Predictions by In Vitro Testing
predicted summary: Viral immune resistance is a major hindrance to vaccine design. To address this challenge, our group has developed computational models that aim to predict the fitness landscape of viral proteins in order to design vaccine immunogens that lead to impaired viral fitness, thus blocking viable escape routes. We developed Potts model that accounts for the specific identity of mutant amino acids, generalizing previous approaches that are unable to distinguish between different mutant proteins. In vitro fitness measurements were performed against mutant strains with multiple Gag mutation combinations introduced by site-directed Mutagenesis into HIV-1 viral isolates. Here, we show that pottently predict fitness effects of common mutants at sites of low amino acid diversity are strongly associated with fitness-neutrality. Our results support the potential value of this approach for understanding viral immune escape pathways and harnessing this knowledge for vaccine designs.

title: Identifying robust hysteresis in networks
predicted summary: Summaries of network dynamics can be searched for observed dynamics over large sets of parameter values, such as bistability and hysteresis, to discover parameter regimes over which they are supported. We illustrate our approach on several networks underlying the restriction point of the cell cycle in humans and yeast. Our approach provides a new computational tool linking network structure and dynamics, providing new insights into network structures. The best 6-node human network shares similar topology and robustness to yeast networks, in spite of having no homology between the yeast network.

title: The TPR Domain in the Host Cyp40-like Cyclophilin Binds to the Viral Replication Protein and Inhibits the Assembly of the Tombusviral Replicase

Here we show that Cyp40-like protein Cpr7p strongly inhibits many steps during replication including viral recruitment inhibition and assembly of viral replicase complex assembly and viral assembly. title: Fine-tuned adaptation of embryo–endometrium pairs at implantation revealed by transcriptome analyses in Bos taurus

title: The "F" in SAFE: Reliability of assessing clean faces for trachoma control in the field

title: Accurate Prediction of Secreted Substrates and Identification of a Conserved Putative Secretion Signal for Type III Secretion Systems

We also apply the method to the genetically intractable human pathogenic animal pathogen ChLAmydium TRACHOMITIX. This approach provides novel insights into the nature of secretional proteins and provides insight into how genes encode secretor proteins.

title: Platelets Guide Leukocytes to Their Sites of Extravasation

title: Conditional knockout mice for the distal appendage protein CEP164 reveal its essential roles in airway multiciliated cell differentiation

This mouse model provides physiological insight into diseases associated with defective multicell differentiation. Furthermore, our models provide novel insights into disease pathways involved with malfunctioning Multicellular Complexification. Our model system provides novel tools to gain physiological insights on the pathophysiology of disease caused by defective Multicell Differential Mouse models.

title: Widespread Protein Aggregation as an Inherent Part of Aging in C. elegans
predicted summary: Aberrant protein aggregates are hallmarks of many age-related diseases, yet little is known about whether proteins aggregate with age in non-disease settings. These proteins are predicted to be significantly overrepresented in polyglutamine-repeat Pathologies found in neurodegenerative diseases associated with neuroplasticity, neurolysis and neurofibromatogenesis. Our findings suggest that polyGlutosylation is an inherent part of lifespan and that it may influence both lifespan as well as neurodevelopmental diseases.

title: Near Surface Swimming of Salmonella Typhimurium Explains Target-Site Selection and Cooperative Invasion
predicted summary: Enteropathogenic bacteria S. Typhimurium utilizes adhesins (e.g. fim) and type III secretion system 1 (TTSS-1) for host cell binding, the triggering of membrane ruffles and invasion. It has been unclear how this is achieved. We have studied target-site selection in tissue culture by time lapse microscopy, movement pattern analysis and modeling. Flagellar motility (but not chemotaxis) was required for reaching cell surface surfaces in vitro. Here we show that target site selection and cooperative invasion are attributable to close proximity swimming rather than near surface swimming, suggesting that targeting target sites selection may be of general importance for understanding infection by flagellated bacteria.

title: Aerosols Transmit Prions to Immunocompetent and Immunodeficient Mice
predicted summary: Prions colonize brains of hosts after oral, parenteral, intralingual or transdermal uptake, but aerosolized prions are not generally considered airborne. We conclude Aerogenic Exposure to PrPSc is very efficacious and can lead to direct invasion of neural pathways without obligatory replicative phase in lymphoid organs. This previously unappreciated risk may warrant rethinking biosafety guidelines in research laboratories and diagnostic laboratories.

title: Activity profiling of peptidases in Angiostrongylus costaricensis first-stage larvae and adult worms

title: Self-Protection against Gliotoxin—A Component of the Gliotoxin Biosynthetic Cluster, GliT, Completely Protects Aspergillus fumigatus Against Exogenous Gliotoxin

predicted summary: Sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (sCJD) is fatal neurodegenerative diseases caused by the infectious prion protein (PrPSc). title: Risk and protective factors for child development: An observational South African birth cohort
predicted summary: The Drakenstein Child Health Study provides reliable developmental data from a well-characterised sample of mother–child dyads in sub-Saharan Africa. We found protective effects of maternal education, higher birth weight, and socioeconomic status on developmental outcomes including infant cognition, expressive language, fine motor and gross motor domains. These included protective factors such as maternal anaemia in pregnancy, maternal depression, childhood intimate partner violence and maternal HIV infection. Importantly, our findings highlight the protective effect factors associated with developmental outcome including birthweight, gender differences in developmental domain scores from mothers and children at 24 months’ gestation to age 2 years of age. Risk factors included maternal risk factors including maternal Anemia, Birth Weight and Socioeconomic Status as well as Risk Factors including Maternal Alcohol Use in Pregnancies, High birth Weight, Depression and Lifelong intimate Partner Violence and Childhood Traumatic Trauma. Our findings provide evidence that maternal educational factors play important protective roles in developmental outcomes.

title: Allelic Expression of Deleterious Protein-Coding Variants across Human Tissues

In this regard, an important factor that can modify the effect of pathogenic alleles is its level of expression; a factor characteristically changes across multiple tissues across tissue types. This study provides insights into the extent to which Pathogenic Allele Variants can be modified by expression levels across Multiple tissues obtained from Individual Individuals by combining genomic transcriptome sequencing data obtained by individual individuals obtained directly from individual tissue obtained. We report the impact of rare and common loss-of-function mutations on gene expression patterns across several tissues exposing stronger allelic bias for rare deletions and informing how rare variant expression is consistently expressed across different tissues belonging to individuals.

title: Complement inhibition by Sarcoptes scabiei protects Streptococcus pyogenes - An in vitro study to unravel the molecular mechanisms behind the poorly understood predilection of S. pyogenes to infect mite-induced skin lesions
