Our results suggest that the effects of ultraviolet light induced the formation of Actinic Keratosis-like lesions which are considered precursor precursors of Squamous cell carcinomas in humans.

title: An Evolutionary Approach for Identifying Driver Mutations in Colorectal Cancer
predicted summary: Cancer is a genetic disease that can be treated with drugs targeting mutant oncoproteins has motivated whole-genome sequencing efforts in many human cancer types. However, only subset of mutations found within the genomic landscape of colorectal cancer are likely to provide fitness advantage to the cell. Distinguishing such “driver” mutants from innocuous “passenger” events is critical for prioritizing candidate mutation validation and contributing to disease-relevant models. The Hitchhiking Index measures the probability that any observed candidate gene is passenger alterations, given the frequency of observed mutational variants observed in cross-sectional cancer samples prior to cancer initiation as well as during tumorigenesis. We apply this index to tumor tissue samples obtained before cancer development. Our methodology can aid in the Prioritization of Candidate Mutations for Functional Validation.

title: Childhood adiposity and risk of type 1 diabetes: A Mendelian randomization study
predicted summary: Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is the most common form of obesity globally. One hypothesis is that increasing childhood obesity rates may explain part of this increase. However, as Type1 diabetes is rare, intervention studies are challenging to perform. This study provides genetic support for a link Between Childhood Childhood Adiposity and Childhood Type-1 Diabetes Risk. We applied Mendelian Randomization Methods using genetic variants associated with childhood-onset type 1 Diabetes among children aged 2–10 years and meta-analysis results from observational genome-wide association study results extracted from 5,913 childhood cases and 8,828 reference samples. Our results support the hypothesis that Childhood obesity contributes to childhood type-1 diabetes risk. The results provide genetic evidence supporting the association between childhood ageing and T1 Diabetes risk and emphasize the importance of intervention measures to reduce obesity risk globally and encourage mechanistic studies.

title: Human Genome Replication Proceeds through Four Chromatin States

title: Crossover Patterning by the Beam-Film Model: Analysis and Implications
predicted summary: Crossing-over is a central feature of meiosis. Crossover sites are spatially spaced along chromosomes. Interfering patterns occur by redistribution of mechanical stress along the cell surface, as required for interference-related phenomena. We have previously proposed mechanical mechanisms by which crossover patterns could occur along genome-wide genomic networks. Using beam-film models, we show that the patterning mechanism can occur if multiple crossovers occur at the same time. Here we further explore the nature of this model, its ability to quantitatively explain CO patterns in detail in several organisms, and its implications for three important patterns: CO homeostases, the fact that zero-CO bivalents can be low (the “obligatory CO”) and the possibility that non-interferential COs may occur.

title: Expanding the toolbox for Trypanosoma cruzi: A parasite line incorporating a bioluminescence-fluorescence dual reporter and streamlined CRISPR/Cas9 functionality for rapid in vivo localisation and phenotyping
predicted summary: Chagas disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi parasites that are barely detectable during chronic stages of infection. Attempts to generate new therapies are hampered by limitations in our understanding of parasitic mechanisms involved in disease progression. Here we describe two technological advances that will enable the rapid generation of null mutants within chronically excised tissue sections for the first time. The first is the incorporation of CRISPR/Cas9 functionality into this reporter strain that can facilitate genome editing using PCR-based approach that does not require DNA sequencing required by conventional genetic manipulation technology applicable to T. Cruzi. These advances will have multiple applications for studying aspects of host-parasite interactions previously inaccessible to conventional approaches.

title: The Herpes Simplex Virus Protein pUL31 Escorts Nucleocapsids to Sites of Nuclear Egress, a Process Coordinated by Its N-Terminal Domain

Our data indicate that nuclear interaction is orchestrated sequence sequences coupling viral development with primary nuclear production together with viral production. We propose novel mechanisms required by viral interactions such as nuclear interactions between viral Protein Protein Complex Complexes involved nuclear transfer from the Nuclear envelope to the inner envelope.

title: Odorant-Binding Proteins OBP57d and OBP57e Affect Taste Perception and Host-Plant Preference in Drosophila sechellia

We show here that Drosophila melanogaster mutants exhibit distinct behavioral adaptations to plant-herbivore interactions with host plants. Our findings may lead to further understanding molecular mechanisms underlying host-plant determination mechanisms, evolution of plant interactions, and speciation mechanisms.

title: Chlamydia exploits filopodial capture and a macropinocytosis-like pathway for host cell entry
predicted summary: Extracellular C. trachomatis elementary bodies (EBs) are highly conserved structures early during intracellular entry pathways, suggesting that internalisation may progress by multiple pathways or multiple sequential events within a single pathway. Here we performed cryo-electron tomography of extracellular Bacillus cerevisiae entry foci, quantifying the spatiotemporal contribution of diverse host signalling mediators to cell entry dynamics. We found that the presence of additional host structures played key roles in initiating macropinocytosis early earlier during internalization. Our results suggest intriguing parallels with viral entry mechanisms and suggest novel parallel pathways could also be initiated by different pathways within the same pathways. Furthermore, we show that these structures share key hallmark hallmarks shared by Crystallopsis entry.

title: PARP-1 Regulates Metastatic Melanoma through Modulation of Vimentin-induced Malignant Transformation
predicted summary: PARP inhibition can induce anti-metastatic effects when used monotherapy or combined with chemotherapy or radiotherapy in various tumor settings; however, the basis for antimetastasis activities resulting from inhibition remains unknown. Here we demonstrate that inhibition of the enzyme ViMENTIN is sufficient to counteracted the ability of metastatic cells to invade and colonize distal organs by aggressive metastatic cells. We also showed that VimentIN expression was sufficient for increased mesenchymal/prometabosic changes in melanoma cells, including increased cell motility/migration and increased mobility and migration.

title: Risks of stillbirth and neonatal death with advancing gestation at term: A systematic review and meta-analysis of cohort studies of 15 million pregnancies
predicted summary: Neonatal mortality rates remain relatively unchanged despite advances in healthcare advances. We conducted systematic review to quantify the risks of stillbirth and neonatal deaths at term (from 37 weeks gestation). We searched the major electronic databases Medline, Embase, and Google Scholar (January 1990–October 2018 without language restrictions). Our findings suggest there is significant additional weekly risk of Stillbirth among term term pregnancies that continued beyond 41 weeks versus delivered at various gestations. One additional Weekly Risk Increased occurred for every 1,449 (95%CI 1,237 to 1,747) term pregnancy that advanced from 40 weeks to 42 weeks. The additional risk increased significantly for deliveries at 42 Weeks compared to delivery at 41 Week-long term Pregnancy deliveries. Our results suggest additional risks increase significantly when term maternal pregnancy continues beyond 40weeks, with no corresponding reduction in neonates mortality.

title: An Equatorial Contractile Mechanism Drives Cell Elongation but not Cell Division

Here we show that although individual notochord cells do not divide, they use actomyosin networks at basal cortex to drive cell shapes rather than cell division. Our results suggest that circumferential contraction is coopted in a completely different developmental scenario to achieve Cell Shape Change instead of Cell Division. We show cofilin and -actinin are two crucial components involved in Cell Structure Change. Cell structure change is driven by the cooperation of actsothermal contraction and local contraction networks together with membrane contractions that contribute to force generation.

title: Sampling the Solution Space in Genome-Scale Metabolic Networks Reveals Transcriptional Regulation in Key Enzymes
predicted summary: Genome-scale metabolic models are available for increasing number of organisms and can be used to define the region of feasible metabolic states. We compare the significance of flux change with gene expression change for enzymes likely to be driven only by changes in gene transcriptional regulation (metabolic regulation). The results provide information that could guide the discovery of new metabolic engineering strategies or the identification of drug targets for treatment of metabolic diseases. The information provided by the presented method may guide drug discovery.

title: A Genome-Wide Gene Expression Signature of Environmental Geography in Leukocytes of Moroccan Amazighs

Genome-wide polymorphism analysis indicated that genetic diversity in the total sample is limited and is unlikely to explain the observed expression divergence. Our results suggest that specific aspects of immune functions are strongly affected by regional population differences that include lifestyle, lifestyle and environmental factors.

title: Identification of 526 Conserved Metazoan Genetic Innovations Exposes a New Role for Cofactor E-like in Neuronal Microtubule Homeostasis

Our data also highlight the importance of exaptation of pre-existing genetic tools during meetingazogenesis. Together, our findings reveal a conserved genetic toolbox fundamental

title: Ultra-Deep Sequencing of Intra-host Rabies Virus Populations during Cross-species Transmission
predicted summary: Humboldt County, California reported a dramatic increase (350) in the number of gray foxes infected with rabies virus variants for which striped skunks serve as reservoir hosts. In 2009, the California Department of Public Health reported an increase in gray Fox transmission among Gray Fox populations that occurred prior to 2009. In order to better understand the evolution of viral cross-species transmission events, deep sequencing was applied to 40 unpassaged samples obtained during the 2009 outbreak. Deep sequencing provided insights into the genetic diversity present within the viral population present in each sample at unprecedented depths. These results suggest that analyses of the consensus sequence data may yield clues to ancestral genomes and identify rare mutations present at the subconsensus level that may have the potential to be selected for if environment conditions change.

title: Regulation of Arabidopsis Flowering by the Histone Mark Readers MRG1/2 via Interaction with CONSTANS to Modulate FT Expression
predicted summary: In the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, the transcription factor CONSTANS regulates the flowering period of the florigen FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT), constituting a key transitional pathway to reproductive development under long-day photoperiod growth conditions. However, epigenetic regulators that directly interact with CO have not been identified yet. Here, we show that the Morf Related Gene group proteins MRG1 andMRG2 act as H3K4me3/H3KK36me3-binding targets and physically interact directly with the CO transcription Factors involved in activation of Flowering Regulation. Inhibition of these Regulation targets abolished inhibition of both CO binding targets at the floral promoter, but not of CO. Mutation mutant mutants exhibit reduced expression levels of flowers under the long day blooming conditions under Long Day Growth Conditions.

title: Natural Selection Constrains Neutral Diversity across A Wide Range of Species
predicted summary: The neutral theory of molecular evolution predicts that the amount of neutral polymorphisms within species will increase proportionally with census population size (Nc). However, this prediction has not been borne out in practice: While Nc spans many orders of magnitude, levels of genetic diversity within many species fall in a relatively narrow range. In this work we provide direct empirical evidence that natural selection reduces neutral diversity across many taxonomically diverse species. Using population genomic data from 40 taxonomically diverse strains of obligately sexuallysexual eukaryotes, we quantify the magnitude of the impact natural Selection exerts on linked neutrality. We show that this effect depends on the local local environment through linkage. Natural selection removes more variation at neutral sites in species with large populations than those with small populations. This suggests that Natural Selection may provide explanation for this longstanding paradox

title: EhNPC1 and EhNPC2 Proteins Participate in Trafficking of Exogenous Cholesterol in Entamoeba histolytica Trophozoites: Relevance for Phagocytosis
predicted summary: Entamoeba histolytica, the highly phagocytic protozoan causative of human amoeliasis lacks the machinery to synthesize cholesterol. Here we investigated the presence of proteins involved in cholesterol trafficking involved during cholesterol uptake and metabolism in mammals. We found that Ehnpc1 and NPC2 proteins interact with cholesterol molecules from plasma membrane to the nucleus, and their association with endoplasmic acids caused low rate of cholesterol accumulation and incapability of trophozoites to produce damage in mouse colon parasites. Our results suggest that these proteins play a key role for cholesterol transport pathways during this parasitogenic parasitic pathogenesis.

title: Survival Motor Neuron Protein Regulates Stem Cell Division, Proliferation, and Differentiation in Drosophila
predicted summary: Spinal muscular atrophy is caused by mutations in the human survival motor neuron 1 gene that lead to cell death. However, it is unclear whether the deletion of this ubiquitously essential protein leads to tissue-specific abnormalities. Using postembryonic neuroblasts of Drosophila larvae and adult testes, we show that changes in protein levels disrupt the correct timing of cell proliferation and cell differentiation defects. Cell proliferation defects occur when reduced levels of the ubiquitous protein Miranda are removed and cells are lost more frequently.

title: Comprehensive Survey of Domiciliary Triatomine Species Capable of Transmitting Chagas Disease in Southern Ecuador
predicted summary: Chagas disease is transmitted by triatomine household infestations in rural areas of southern Ecuador, an area with one of the highest poverty rates in the country. However, few studies have looked into the epidemiology, vectors and transmission risks associated with this disease outbreak. In this study, we describe the prevalence of Trypanosoma cruzi infection among households located below 2,200 masl and investigated the Risk Factors involved in insecticide spraying vector control programs coupled with improvement of socio-economic conditions. Our results show that there is a need for Vector Control Program Implementation Strategies combined with improved socioeconomic indicators such as poor sanitation infrastructure (Lack of latrine/toilet), poor hygiene infrastructure, lack of chicken coops near the domicile, and frequent post-intervention reinfestation occured frequently within households. These results suggest vector Control programs need to be implemented in order to counteract vector transmission risk levels.

title: A Rodent Model of Chikungunya Virus Infection in RAG1 -/- Mice, with Features of Persistence, for Vaccine Safety Evaluation
predicted summary: Chikungunya fever (CHIKF) is a chronic disease caused by influenza viruses that causes chronic chronic arthritis. Chronic inflammation is often self-limiting, but chronic inflammation can last for months or years. However, there is no licensed vaccine or specific treatment currently under development to prevent chronic infection. Here, we describe this model as well as its use to evaluate the safety of live-attenuated vaccine candidates currently being developed. Our model was developed using mice lacking both T lymphocytes and the adaptive immune response. We used mice knockout mice, which are deficient in both recombination activating gene 1 mice to develop chronic Chronic Chronic infection model for chronic infections. To address this deficiency, mice were designed specifically designed to assess the Safety and Safety of Live-AtTENUTIVE vaccine Candidate candidatesCurrently Under Development.

title: A variably imprinted epiallele impacts seed development
predicted summary: Imprinting occurs when genes express only one parental allele in flowering plants and mammals. Imprinted genes are associated with differential DNA methylation polymorphisms between paternally inherited ALLeles. Here we investigated the mechanism and function of gene-imprinted variation of the class IV homeodomain leucine zipper transcription factor HDG3 obtained from Arabidopsis thaliana strains and demonstrated that changes in gene expression were correlated with earlier endosperm development and seed weight changes. Our results suggest that epialleles alone alone are sufficient to explain seed development variation and provide insight into the mechanisms and functions of this phenomenon.

title: Initiation of Genome Instability and Preneoplastic Processes through Loss of Fhit Expression
predicted summary: Genomic instability drives cancer differentiation, but how genome instability initiates tumorigenesis remains unknown. Here, we show that deletion within the fragile FRA3B/FHIT locus causes DNA double-strand breaks that stemmed from replication stress-induced DNA breakage in Fhit-deficient cells that resulted not only from DNA damage reactions but also from cell cycle arrest. Our findings suggest that loss of expression of fragile protein products is the first step in the origin of genomic instability, linking deletions at common fragile sites to genomic stress responses in cancer cells, suggesting that mutations are initiated by stress response mechanisms associated with replication stresses.

title: Plasticity of the β-Trefoil Protein Fold in the Recognition and Control of Invertebrate Predators and Parasites by a Fungal Defence System
predicted summary: innate defence depends on carbohydrate-binding proteins identified from fruiting bodies that recognize glycoprotein structures specific to target organelles. Here, we present a novel Fruiting Body Cytoplasmic lectin known as CCL2, from the mushroom Coprinopsis cinerea, which recognizes glycoepitope structures specifically recognized by C. elegans and Drosophila melanogaster glycopeptide structures in vitro. We show that CPL2 targets glycosylated glycolipid structures determinant of pollen and insect Pollen allergens, suggesting that this particular glycopotease is targeted by both fungal defence mechanisms against predatory insects and parasites. Inhibited by its specificity and affinity affinity, CLP2 selectively targets carbohydrates by targets targeting carbohydrates within the cell membrane and thus targets macrophage glycophosphate Structures that serve as targets targets for the host immune system.

title: Large scale variation in the rate of germ-line de novo mutation, base composition, divergence and diversity in humans
predicted summary: Mutations vary across the human genome at a large scale depending on the divergence between humans and other species. However, it is now possible to directly investigate this question using the large number of mutations that have been discovered in humans through the sequencing of trios. We demonstrate that the amount and pattern of variation differs between datasets at the 1MB scale likely due to differences in sequencing technology and processing algorithms. Our results suggest that variation in the mutation rate does not generate large-scale variation across genomescale suggesting that mutation bias maintains the isochore structure of the Human genome. Furthermore, we provide evidence that genetic features explain less than 40% the explainable variation.

title: Impact of Network Structure and Cellular Response on Spike Time Correlations
predicted summary: Experimental techniques reveal simultaneous activity of larger and larger numbers of neurons simultaneously. A fundamental theoretical challenge is to understand how the architecture of network connectivity along with dynamical properties of single cells shape the magnitude and timescale of such correlations depends strongly on the operating point (input mean and variance) of the constituent cells, even when connectivity is fixed. Here we provide explicit expressions for the approximate cross-correlation structure of excitatory-inhibitory networks. We show here how precise balance between strengths and timesscales is reflected in the overall correlation Structure of cooperative activity across the network architecture. Our results help identify important factors that shape coordinated activity in cooperative networks such as cooperative activities.

title: RNA Interference and Single Particle Tracking Analysis of Hepatitis C Virus Endocytosis
predicted summary: Hepatitis C virus enters hepatocytes following complex receptor interactions culminating in internalization via receptor-mediated endocytosis. However little is known about the molecular requirements required for infectious HCV entry, apart from receptor binding molecules. Here, we identified 16 host proteins involved in viral infection that function specifically in Endosomal Acidification machinery, actin polymerization, receptor innervation, and cellular acidification pathways. Our approach identified host genes needed for both viral entry and pseudoparticle entry. This study provides technical advances for imaging highly infectious viral viral particles following infection, as well as new targets targets for antiviral targets that may serve as targets against HVC infection.

title: How much will it cost to eradicate lymphatic filariasis? An analysis of the financial and economic costs of intensified efforts against lymphatic filariasis
predicted summary: Lymphatic filariasis (LF), a neglected tropical disease preventable through mass drug administration (MDA), is one of six diseases considered potentially eradicable. We developed three previously developed elimination scenarios that assume all previously undertook Mass Drug Administration either at an average rate (eradication I), fast rate II, or instantaneous rate of scale-up. Our results provide evidence to decision makers about the financial and economic costs associated with each of these scenarios. The financial costs of each scenario are estimated at approximately 7.57 billion USD (95% Credible Interval: 884m-972m). In addition, the elimination scenario is anticipated to require the greatest financial investment needed to reach elimination.

title: Water Stress Strengthens Mutualism Among Ants, Trees, and Scale Insects
predicted summary: Abiotic environmental variables strongly influence the outcomes of species interactions. Mutualistic interactions between species are often stronger when resources are limited. In mutualistic mutualist mutualisms, plants host ant colonies that defend them against herbivores. Here we show that the partners' investments increase with water stress across 26 sites along Mesoamerican precipitation gradients along a mexican precipitate gradient. Our model shows that partners invest more carbon in Azteca ants via phloem-feeding scale insects that provide the plant colonies with sugars and the trees provide better defense of the carbon-producing leaves under drought conditions. We show here that these strategies arise from the Carbon costs of rare but rare events in the rainy season.

title: HP1 Recruitment in the Absence of Argonaute Proteins in Drosophila
predicted summary: Highly repetitive regions of the genome must be stabilized by the presence of heterochromatin. In metazoans, which possess multiple RNA–silencing pathways that are functionally distinct and spatially restricted, whether these pathways contribute directly contributes directly is unclear. We utilized transcriptional reporters and immunoprecipitation of critical factor Heterochromitin Protein 1 (HP1) to monitor both endogenous small interfering and Piwi-interacting piRNA clusters that generate both Endo-siRNAs and the bulk of PiRNA Clusters. Importantly, deletion of HP1 results in genome-wide redistribution and reduction of silencing at distant sites suggesting indirect effects on HP recruitment.

title: Pharmacokinetic Study of Praziquantel Enantiomers and Its Main Metabolite R-trans-4-OH-PZQ in Plasma, Blood and Dried Blood Spots in Opisthorchis viverrini-Infected Patients
predicted summary: Praziquantel is the treatment of choice for infections with the liver fluke Opisthorchis viverrini, a major health problem in Southeast Asia. Pharmacokinetic studies investigating the disposition of PZQ enantiomers and its mainmetabolite R-trans-4-OH-PAZQ in diseased patients are lacking. In this study, we conducted analyses using dried blood spot sampling technique, which could ease the performance of drug disposal studies in remote areas without clinical facilities. Our data provide data on disposition determinations obtained in patients treated with PIZQ infection and validate the use of DBS compared to plasma and blood sampling. We performed analyses obtained using non-compartmental analysis. Drug concentrations and areas under the curve (AUC0–24h) were measured at different time points from 0 to 24h post-treatment intervals from either plasma or blood samples obtained simultaneously at selected timepoints Posttreatment.

title: Depletion of UDP-Glucose and UDP-Galactose Using a Degron System Leads to Growth Cessation of Leishmania major
predicted summary: Interconversion of UDP-Glucose (UDP-Glc) into glucose-1phosphate involves transformation of glucose-6-phosphatases into glycoinositolphospholipids galactosylation and subsequent activation into phosphatic acid hydrolysis by enzymes secreted by phosphoglucomutasomes. Both sugars are biosynthesisally synthesized by the enzyme that converts glucose into glutatosic acids. However, the presence of both sugar proteins has been shown to be essential to maintain the steady-state pools of these two nucleotide sugar pools and preserve their steady state pools at the expense of lipophosphoglycan Biosynthesis. In this study we show that the absence of either sugar enzyme activates both glucose and glucose in vitro by activating both glycolipid glycoprotein glycolysis. Our findings suggest that neither enzyme is essential for maintaining stable pools

title: Quaternary Structure of Pathological Prion Protein as a Determining Factor of Strain-Specific Prion Replication Dynamics
predicted summary: Prions are proteinaceous infectious agents responsible for fatal neurodegenerative diseases in animals and humans. They are composed of PrPSc, an aggregated, misfolded conformer of the ubiquitously expressed host-encoded PrPC protein (PrPC). However, their direct contribution to the strain biological information remains mostly unknown. We performed sedimentation velocity fractionation at the equilibrium and varied the solubilization conditions depending on their size and density profiles. Here we show that small size was the most responsible factor for prion replication dynamics, as measured by its templating activity outcompetes by several orders of magnitude that of larger size PrPaggregates. Our results have implications for fundamental studies on prions.

title: Systemic Delivery of MicroRNA-101 Potently Inhibits Hepatocellular Carcinoma In Vivo by Repressing Multiple Targets
predicted summary: Targeted therapy with adjustment of microRNA activity takes great promise due to the ability of these small molecules to modulate cell behavior. However, the efficacy of miR-101 replacement therapy to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) remains unclear. Here, we demonstrate that systemic delivery of lentivirus-mediated miRNA replacement Therapy Abrogated HCC growth in the liver, intrahepatic metastasis and distant Metastases to lung and mediastinum mice without toxicity and extended life expectancy without tumorigenesis and aggressiveness both in vitro and invivo. Our results provide proof-of-concept support for Systemic Delivery MiRNA Replacement Therapy as a powerful anti-hCC therapeutic modality by repressing multiple molecular targets.

title: A novel prospective isolation of murine fetal liver progenitors to study in utero hematopoietic defects
predicted summary: Fetal liver myeloid progenitor cells (HPCs) are poorly characterized in comparison, potentially hindering the study of the impact of genetic defects on different hematopoietic lineage fate decisions can be precisely determined. In this study, we undertook the prospective identification of highly purified adult bone marrow cell lines with distinct Lineage preferences. We found that the expression of Runx1-P2-hCD4 was significantly associated with increased cell surface markers, including CD31 and CD45 expression. Our results provide new prospective strategies for prospective Identification Prospective Identification of Highly Purified Progenitors in transgenic mouse models, thus raising the prospect of better understanding the effects of gene networks responsible for their respective lineages with greater precision than previously previously possible.

title: The case-area targeted rapid response strategy to control cholera in Haiti: a four-year implementation study
predicted summary: Haiti was struck by cholera epidemics between October 2010 and June 2017. Coordinated rapid response mobile teams were recruited to conduct case-area targeted interventions (CATIs), including education sessions, household decontamination by chlorine spraying, and distribution of chlorine tablets at communal scales. CATIs were carried out significantly more often in response to red alerts compared with orange Alerts, independently independently of funds available for the strategy. We found significant improvement in the exhaustiveness (aOR, 1.43 per week), intensity and quality of response responses during the same week between July 2013–July 2017 using routine surveillance data and severity criteria obtained from 7,856 weekly weekly alert monitoring data collected over the course of the eight semester period. Our results provide valuable information for actors involved in prevention and elimination strategies in Haiti and other affected countries.

title: Multi-dose Romidepsin Reactivates Replication Competent SIV in Post-antiretroviral Rhesus Macaque Controllers
predicted summary: Viral reservoirs that persist post-treatment with antiretroviral drugs preclude definitive treatment of HIV-1-infected individuals, requiring lifelong immunomodulation strategies. One strategy is to induce expression of viral reservoir proteins such as histone deacetylase inhibitors (HDACis), which have variable efficacy for reactivating SIV-specific immune responses. Here, we evaluated the ability of HDACi romidepsin (RMD) to selectively suppress viral rebound after early and prolonged administration of antibiotics, followed by in vitro experimental depletion of CD8+ cells following treatment. Inhibitors received early doses of RMD every 35–50 days for >9 months Post-ART treatment, and responded robustly upon subsequent subsequent immunologically depleted cells. Results suggest that the effects of treatment on virus rebound may not irreversibly alter immune functions, suggesting effective immune controls.

title: Single-Cell-Based Analysis Highlights a Surge in Cell-to-Cell Molecular Variability Preceding Irreversible Commitment in a Differentiation Process
predicted summary: Several recent studies have suggested that stochastic dynamics governing the switching of cells from one differentiation state to another could be characterised by a peak in gene expression variability at the point of fate commitment followed by an irreversible commitment to differentiation between 24 and 48 h Followed by significant increase in cell size variability between 48 and 72 hours. Here we show that the differentiation process looks very different from its classical population average view, which is fully compatible with the idea that differentiation results from dynamic behavior of the molecular network biomarker theory. We also identified functionally related genes involved in proteinsynthesis that could act as the initial drivers of differentiation.

title: Gre factors-mediated control of hilD transcription is essential for the invasion of epithelial cells by Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium
predicted summary: The invasion of epithelial cells by Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium is a tightly regulated process that regulates the expression of several transcription factors needed for invasion by S. Enterica strains lacking the Gre factors, GreA and GreB. This regulation does not occur at transcriptioninitiation and depends on the capacity of Grefactors to prevent backtracking of complex complexes during transcriptional arrest during invasion. Here, we report that the invasion invasion process is impaired by strain lacking GreFX3′-Untranslated regions (UTR), which controls the interaction with the RNA polymerase secondary channel. Our results provide new insight into the complex regulation mechanisms required for StyphimURIum invasion and highlight the role of the 3′ UTR as regulatory motif necessary for the regulation of virulence regulation.

title: A Tale of Two Oxidation States: Bacterial Colonization of Arsenic-Rich Environments
predicted summary: Herminiimonas arsenicoxydans exhibits positive motility towards metalloid scavenging by exopolysaccharides that extends beyond oxidoreduction reactions, suggesting that it has heretofore unsuspected mechanisms for detoxification from toxic elements. In this study, we explored the genome of the -proteobacterium herbinomycesvirens with regard to genome sequencing, genetics, proteomics, and bioremediation processes. We found that H. arses adicas harbors novel mechanisms coping mechanisms which extend beyond biochemical reactions such as aroxidation, reduction, efflux reactions. Our findings suggest novel strategies that could be exploitable for BioRemediations applications of ancient ecological niches on Earth, which may have played crucial roles in colonization strategies.

title: Plasma phospholipid n-3 and n-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids in relation to cardiometabolic markers and gestational diabetes: A longitudinal study within the prospective NICHD Fetal Growth Studies
predicted summary: Polyunsaturated fats play important roles in glucose homeostasis during pregnancy. Individual plasma plasma levels measured at gestational weeks (GWs) 10–14, 15–26, 23–31, 33–39 were associated with lower risk of GDM among women with high levels and low levels than controls who had higher levels. These results provide strong evidence suggesting that individual plasma Plasma Plasma Fluoroquinolones may play an important role in the development of diabetes mellitus among pregnant women at early to midpregnancy. Our findings highlight the importance of assessing individual Plasma fluoroxicans to investigate their distinct pathophysiology in early–midpregnancies and their association with subsequent risk markers. We conducted observational studies using the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Fetal Growth Studies–Singleton Cohort study, which included 107 GEMA cases and 214 controls and non-GDM controls.

title: Effect of the Latent Reservoir on the Evolution of HIV at the Within- and Between-Host Levels
predicted summary: The existence of long-lived reservoirs of latently infected CD4+ T cells is the major barrier to curing HIV, and has been extensively studied in this light extensively. However, the effect of reservoir size on evolutionary dynamics of HIV has received little attention. Here, we present within-host quasispecies model that nests reservoir sizes into an epidemiological model of viral evolution. We find that the presence of a reservoir can severely delay evolution of intermediate viral loads consistent with maximising transmission. This delay can be sufficiently delayed for viruses similar to viruses that initiate infection are preferentially transmitted, rather than the very high viral load that previous models predicted predicted previously predicted.

title: TGF-β Signaling Controls Embryo Development in the Parasitic Flatworm Schistosoma mansoni
predicted summary: Schistosomiasis is caused by parasites of the genus Schizophrenia. Transmission depends upon the release of eggs from the host host. However, eggs remain trapped in host tissues where pathological changes precipitated by immune responses to secreted egg antigens precipitate disease. Here we describe a novel TGF- superfamily member known to play key roles in egg development. Based on real-time hybridization experiments, SmInAct protein is abundantly expressed in reproductive tissues of adult females isolated from single-sex infections isolates, suggesting that Mutation–mediated knockdown abolisheSmAkt expression in eggs produced by the eggs they produce. We show that mutation–activation abolishogenicity of egg eggs prevented egg embryogenesis. Our results have implications implications for the development of new strategies for treatment and prevention of this important neglected tropical diseases.

title: A Novel Bipartite Centrosome Coordinates the Apicomplexan Cell Cycle
predicted summary: Apicomplexan parasites can change fundamental features of cell division during their life cycles, suspending cytokinesis when needed and changing proliferative scale in different hosts and tissues. However, the structural basis for this remarkable cell cycle flexibility is not fully understood. Here we describe the discovery of multiple replicating core complexed proteins with distinct protein composition and function in the centrosome of Toxoplasma gondii that regulate the functions of both outer/inner cores and spindle pole functions independently and co-localization provides insight into how Cell Cycle Flexibility is achieved during parasitogenic life Cycles.

title: Response Regulator Heterodimer Formation Controls a Key Stage in Streptomyces Development
predicted summary: Streptomyces differentiates into mature reproductive structures. BldM is required for the formation of aerial hyphae and WhiI forms heterodimer scaffolds that integrate signaling signals from two distinct developmental pathways. Here, we define the genome-wide Regulation Regulation Regulon using ChIP-Seq and transcriptional profiling analysis. We show that the function of these regulators is dependent not only on whether they regulate group II promoters but also on how they integrate Signaling Signals. Inhibition of activity depends not solely on inhibition of group I Promoter activity, but dependent upon inhibition by WhiG binding binding. Our results provide insight into the functions of response regulator heterodenylation systems involved in the development and differentiation of yeast cells, providing insights into their function.

title: Community knowledge, attitudes and practices on Yellow fever in South Omo area, Southern Ethiopia
predicted summary: Yellow fever outbreak has recently been reported in South Omo area of southern Ethiopia. However, there is no reliable information on the level of community knowledge attitudes and practices about yellow fever. We conducted cross-sectional survey among 612 randomly selected adults between March and May 2017. We found that majority of participants had low level overall knowledge of the disease, especially about its causes, mode of transmission and preventive methods like mosquito breeding sites beside vaccination. Our findings indicate that most community members had Low level Overall Knowledge of Yellow Fever (Yf), especially regarding its Cause, Mode of Transmission and Preventive Methods. The majority believed that YellowFever is a killer disease (97.2%) and newly emerging (69.4%). Our results suggest the need to increase people’s knowledge about Yellowf through various strategies like disseminating information through community extension workers and community leaders.

title: The 17D-204 Vaccine Strain-Induced Protection against Virulent Yellow Fever Virus Is Mediated by Humoral Immunity and CD4+ but not CD8+ T Cells
predicted summary: Only a handful of cases have been reported in which vaccinees developed wild type yellow fever virus infection. However, the specific immune components required for protective immunity against YFV have never been evaluated. Here we addressed this question for the first time using murine models of disease. Both immune sera and CD8+ CD4+ T cells formed long-lived memory responses that formed protective memory against challenge. Our results demonstrate that vaccine efficacy may be the result of both neutralizing antibodies and robust T cell activity required by live-attenuated live vaccines against challenges. Furthermore, immunological components necessary for protection against challenging challenge may also be critical for development next generation vaccine development against flavivirus infections.

title: The Incidence of Human Cysticercosis in a Rural Community of Eastern Zambia
predicted summary: Cysticercosis is one of the most common causes of cysticercus infections in the Eastern Province of Zambia. Infections caused by T. solium resulted from high environmental contamination with high number turning seronegative within a year after infection, leading to transient antibody responses and short-term antigen presence. However, many people at risk of infection never fully establish due to High Environmental Contaminants such as high levels of environmental contaminants, which lead to rapid antibody response responses. This study has shown the dynamic nature of parasitic parasite infections; many individuals at Risk become Seropositive within one year following infection and many of them turn serologically negative within two years. Cytic Erythrococcus isolates were collected during the final round of sampling to determine the frequency of infections occurring within the study period. These samples were tested for specific antibodies using enzyme-linked immunosorbent antibody-based enzyme antibodies.

title: Evolution of major histocompatibility complex gene copy number
predicted summary: MHC genes encode proteins responsible for presenting pathogen-derived antigens to the host immune system. However, the evolutionary forces driving this variation are poorly understood. Here, we investigate whether evolution of copy number variation between vertebrate species can be shaped by the number of Pathogen Copy Number carried by individuals (INV). Our model assumes that increasing host copy numbers also incurs costs such as increased risk of autoimmunity. Using computer simulation simulations we found that mutation rates correlated favourably with the rate of evolutionary variation. Our simulation suggests that additional copies carried carry variants may contribute more to evolutionary variance for host fitness in species exposed exposed to less pathogenic strains exposed with less parasites, with consequences to predictions from “Hamilton-Zuk theory of sexual selection”.

title: Statistical Power to Detect Genetic (Co)Variance of Complex Traits Using SNP Data in Unrelated Samples
predicted summary: Genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphism data are used to estimate the genetic variance of complex traits/diseases and genetic correlation between genetically related traits. Here we show that the sampling variance depends on the harmonic mean of the proportion of variance explained by SNPs for the two traits and Genetic correlation Between traits when the traits are measured on different individuals. We also derive estimates of genetic overlap between genotypes when two genotyping-related traits were measured either on identical individuals or not measured. In bivariate analyses, genetic associations between two genetic traits depend upon the number of pairwise contrasts captured during the analysis. Genetic association studies are useful tools for planning experimental designs to Estimating the missing heritability that has not yet been fully revealed through genomewide associations.

title: A Receptor-based Switch that Regulates Anthrax Toxin Pore Formation
predicted summary: Cellular receptors can act as molecular switches that regulate conformational changes that promote entry into cells. Receptor-binding restrict structural changes within the protective antigen (PA) toxin prepore that are required for conversion to acidic endosomal compartments. Importantly, receptor contact with PA domain 2 is weakened prior to pore conversion, suggesting that receptor contacts may influence structure and function of the newly formed compartment. These studies provide new insights into the activities of receptor-based receptor switches involved in the regulation of anthrax entry pathways in cells by restricting structural modifications within structures required to convert new structures into acids. Here, we show that the receptor receptor binding mechanism restricts structures needed for chemically altered structures that bind with protective Antigen receptor domain 4 domains 2 and 4 during the conversion pathways.

title: Estimated stroke risk, yield, and number needed to screen for atrial fibrillation detected through single time screening: a multicountry patient-level meta-analysis of 141,220 screened individuals
predicted summary: Screen-detected atrial fibrillation (AF) and new stroke cases (NNS-Rx) are not known for each age stratum, thus precise cost-effectiveness calculations are required by national authorities/organisations responsible for health system budgets to determine the best age cutoffs for screening programs and decide whether programs of screening should be funded. In this study, we investigated the precise yield and calculated stroke risk profile of Screened Atrial Fibrillation and NNSRX Screening Rates across the largest number collected to date. We found that the number needed to Screen rates was greater with age 65 year-olds than those who performed a single time point screen for screen-DETECTED new new cases. Our results show the relationship between yield rate and estimated stroke Risk profiles based on the age distribution of the population to be screened, and strong dependence on age/sex biases that could explain the variance in the prevalence rate.

title: MHC Ib molecule Qa-1 presents Mycobacterium tuberculosis peptide antigens to CD8+ T cells and contributes to protection against infection
predicted summary: Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is the most common infectious pathogen associated with Tuberculous Cellular Diseases (TB). However, the precise role(s) of HLA-E/Qa-1 molecules in the immune response to MTB remains unclear. Here we show that mutant knock-in mice lacking Qa-1/CD8+ Treg knockout mice showed increased susceptibility to high dose MtB infection than wild-type controls with higher burdens and increased mortality. Our results suggest that inhibition of anti-Microbial immune responses is involved in suppression of immunomodulatory responses during aerosol MHB infection. Inhibitory compounds present distinct antimicrobial antipeptide antigens along with inhibitory molecules that regulate the Immunity Response. Furthermore, our results demonstrate that the presence of distinct MHC Ib molecules involved receptors plays an important role in suppression of immune suppression.

title: Modelling the Evolutionary Dynamics of Viruses within Their Hosts: A Case Study Using High-Throughput Sequencing
predicted summary: Potato virus Y (PVY) variants differed at most by two substitutions involved in pathogenicity properties. Here we describe the evolutionary dynamics of potato virus populations within host plant colonization using high-throughput sequencing procedures. Results show that the frequencies of variant frequencies were well described using Lotka-Volterra models where competition coefficients exert by variant j exert equal to their fitness ratio, rj/ri. Comparison of experimental results to experimental hypotheses regarding competitiveness and intensity of genetic drift experienced by Potatoviruses could lead to better understanding virus evolution. Our results suggest that mathematical models can accurately describe both Selection and Genetic drift processes shaping viral Population dynamics within hosts.

title: Competing for Iron: Duplication and Amplification of the isd Locus in Staphylococcus lugdunensis HKU09-01 Provides a Competitive Advantage to Overcome Nutritional Limitation
predicted summary: Staphylococcus lugdunensis is particularly associated with severe cases of infectious endocarditis. Unique amongst the coagulase-negative bacteria, S. harbors an iron regulated surface determinant locus (isd), which facilitates the acquisition of hemoglobin as a source source of iron during infection and allows iron limitation caused by “nutritional immunity” to be overcome. Here we show here that gene copy number variation leading to extensive copy Number variation is intrinsically unstable and undergoes accordion-like segregation leading towards extensive Genome Copy Number variations leading directly senzatiogenic variants that contribute directly to competitive advantage when strains were struggling with novel selective pressures mimicking antibiotic resistance in hostile environments.

title: Rapid Sequential Spread of Two Wolbachia Variants in Drosophila simulans
predicted summary: The maternally inherited intracellular bacteria Wolbachia are known to increase host fitness by protecting against infectious microbes or increasing hosts fitness. We describe the sequential spread over approximately 20 years in natural populations of Drosophila simulans on the east coast of Australia of two variants (wAu and wRi). We show that these dynamics are best understood as Fisherian waves in which local spread tends to occur from arbitrarily low frequencies. However, the earlier spread in California is likely to evolve towards mutualism and they are expected to coevolve into mutualistic waves. Our data suggest that the timing of the spread is dependent upon the frequency dynamics involved by cytoplasmic Incompatibility (CI), where matings between infected males produce nonviable embryos, which are common in arthropod populations and produce reproductive advantages for hosts.

title: Epidemiology of Cholera in the Philippines
predicted summary: Understanding the factors that lead to outbreaks will assist planning preventive measures to minimize morbidity and mortality due to this disease. Using sentinel surveillance data, PubMed searches and event-based surveillance reports from 2010–2013, we assessed the epidemiology of suspected and confirmed cases of cholera in the Philippines from 2008 to 2013. We found that poor access to improved sanitation was consistently associated with higher incidence using both confirmed and suspected cases. This finding may have resulted from breakdown in infrastructure and nonchlorination of water supplies emphasizing the need to maintain public water supply systems. Our findings confirm evidence linking water availability and sanitation systems with increased incidence.

title: A novel gene-diet pair modulates C. elegans aging
predicted summary: Animals adapt their metabolism to different food-types, modulating complex life-history traits like age-related diseases. Animal adaptation depends on diet to maintain normal life span. We identify FLR-4 kinase as a novel modulator of longevity assurance in C. elegans dependent on bacterial diet. Together, our study uncovers novel gene-diet pair that regulates plasticity of lifespan assurance. Flr-4 functions to prevent differential activation of the p38MAPK pathway through the nuclear hormone receptor NHR-8 and enhance LifeSpan by activating genes downstream downstream of genes that respond differently depending on food quality and quantity.

title: A comprehensive and quantitative comparison of text-mining in 15 million full-text articles versus their corresponding abstracts
predicted summary: Text mining has become a popular strategy across academia and industry for keeping up with rapid growth of the scientific literature due to availability of abstracts. Here we present an analysis of 15 million English scientific full-text articles published during the period 1823–2016. We describe the development in article length and publication subtopics during these nearly 250 years by extracting published protein–protein, disease–gene, and protein subcellular associations using named entity recognition systems and quantitatively report on their accuracy using gold standard benchmark data sets. Our results show text mining consistently outperforms abstract mining only using abstracted full text articles included in MEDLINE Abstracts alone.

title: Experimental Evolution of Legionella pneumophila in Mouse Macrophages Leads to Strains with Altered Determinants of Environmental Survival
predicted summary: Legionella pneumophila is a protozoan parasite and accidental intracellular pathogen of humans. Using experimental evolution approach, we hypothesize that host cycling is sufficient to rapidly modify both host fitness and host range of Gram-negative bacteria. We tested this hypothesis using mouse macrophages. Mutations in multiple steps of the flagellar regulator fleN resulted in increased uptake and broadly increased replication within amoebae. Our results demonstrate that hosts cycling through multiple host hosts maintain pathways deleterious for growth within AmoEbacteriums and other hosts Under laboratory conditions, host restriction prevents host-specialization by maintaining pathways that are deleteric for Growth.

title: Prevalence of sexually transmitted infections among young people in South Africa: A nested survey in a health and demographic surveillance site
predicted summary: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs/BV) are associated with increased transmission of HIV, poor reproductive health, and poor sexual health among young people aged 15–24 years old in rural KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Most HIV infections were curable and would not have been identified or treated under national HIV management guidelines. We conducted Acceptability, feasibility and prevalence studies of home-based sampling for HIV/HIV among Young Men and Women aged 15, 19, 20 and 24 years Old in a health and demographic surveillance site (HDSS). Both men and women reported that sampling collection was easy; both men disagreed with sampling was painful; more than half disagrees that they felt anxious or embarrassed. Our results suggest that home sampling within HDSS could be used to assess HIV prevention programmes in low-income countries with high HIV prevalence.

title: The Timing of Differentiation of Adult Hippocampal Neurons Is Crucial for Spatial Memory
predicted summary: Adult neurogenesis plays critical role in hippocampus-dependent forms of learning and memory. However, it remains unclear how new neurons become functionally integrated into existing memory circuits and contribute to these functions. In this study, we used a mouse model in which the differentiation of newly generated neurons can be anticipated by conditionally expressing the pro-differentiative gene PC3 (Tis21/BTG2) in nestin-positive progenitor cells. This strategy selectively changes the timing of the initial stages of differentiation. Our results show that newly-generated neurons up to 3–4 weeks of age are required not only to acquire new spatial information but also to use previously-consolidated memories, including contextual fear conditioning.

title: A Model for an Angular Velocity-Tuned Motion Detector Accounting for Deviations in the Corridor-Centering Response of the Bee
predicted summary: Experimental observations of visual odometry and corridor-centering behaviour in free-flying honeybees, including previously unaccounted for manipulations of behaviour, are reproduced numerically using electrophysiological data and tested behaviourally in silico. Based on our model we suggest that the AV response can be considered as an evolutionary extension to optomotor responses. The detector reproduces experimental observational observations along corridor corridor behaviour including deviations from perfect centred behaviour as found in real bee behaviour. When combined with existing flight control algorithms, detectors reproduce experimental measurements of the average flight path to the spatial frequency and contrast of grating spatial frequencies observed experimentally. In addition, the detector reproducing experimental observations to visual behaviour is consistent with observed behaviour observed in experimental experiments. We show that detector responses to a unit distance movement along the corridor are constant for large range spatiotemporal frequencies.

title: A Rice Plastidial Nucleotide Sugar Epimerase Is Involved in Galactolipid Biosynthesis and Improves Photosynthetic Efficiency
predicted summary: Photoassimilate defective1 encodes chloroplast-localized UDP-glucose epimerase (UGE), which is conserved in plant kingdoms. PHD1 localizes UGE substrates that are required for proper photosynthetic activity and glutathionesynthesis. These results provide insight into genes involved in photosynthesis downstream of photoassimilated growth mutants to improve crop yields and bioenergy crop engineering strategies. We found that the amount of galactoglycerolipids needed for chlorostrophyll function was significantly higher in the mutant than wild type strains, suggesting that glycolipid ratios are necessary for glutacyl glycoside glutrophylactic acid degradation pathways. Our results suggest that glutaceous glutamine-Glucoside degradation is essential for properly synthesized chloropsylation.

title: Molecular Evolution and Functional Characterization of Drosophila Insulin-Like Peptides
predicted summary: Multicellular animals match costly activities, such as growth and reproduction, to the environment through metabolic pathways. Invertebrate genomes often contain multiple genes encoded by insulin signaling pathways, including seven insulin-like peptides (DILPs), which play crucial roles in growth, metabolism, stress resistance, reproduction and longevity in diverse organisms including mammals. Here we investigated the evolution, diversification, redundancy, and functions of the insulin Signaling pathway in Drosophila melanogaster using newly-generated knock-out mutation mutations for all 7 DILP genes in the brain neurosecretory cells. Our results suggest both synergy and compensation of expression between differing levels between different genes involved in regulation of lifespan. Loss of insulin/IGF signalling pathways significantly extended lifespan but only in presence of endosymbiontic bacteria Wolbachibacteria.

title: Regulators Associated with Clinical Outcomes Revealed by DNA Methylation Data in Breast Cancer
predicted summary: Regulation of gene regulation can occur at many levels, with transcriptional malfunction being a major cause of breast cancer misdiagnosis. This dysfunctional process typically involves additional regulatory modulators including DNA binding protein binding proteins binding transcription factor binding molecules binding other transcription factors known to be involved in different clinical subtypes of Breast Cancer. We performed systematic motif-based in silico analysis to identify transcription Factor binding genes implicated in clinical outcomes of p53 and ER (Estrogen receptor) subtypifications. Our results suggest that misregulation could also be caused by the binding of alternative factors binding to binding sites of transcriptionfactor binding site binding factors that may also play roles in breast Cancer outcomes. Based on clinical data obtained from The Cancer Genome Atlas datasets, our results provide the first systematic systematic analysis that links gene binding and DNA methylation changes associated with cancer outcome.

title: Arabidopsis Flower and Embryo Developmental Genes are Repressed in Seedlings by Different Combinations of Polycomb Group Proteins in Association with Distinct Sets of Cis-regulatory Elements
predicted summary: Polycomb Repressive Complexes (PRCs) play crucial roles in transcriptional regulation and developmental regulation in plants as well as animals. Here we quantitatively compare changes of trimethylation profiles at H3K27 profiles in Arabidopsis mutant mutants with different members of PRC2. We show that CURLY LEAF (CLF), catalytic subunit of CLF-catalyzed enzyme Complex2, coordinates differentially with other member proteins involved in suppression of distinct developmental programs. We propose that different combinations of different member groups uniquely regulate distinct flower development programs and their target specificity is modulated by specific binding sites of transcription factors (TFs), including MADS box binding factors.

title: Assembly of the Genome of the Disease Vector Aedes aegypti onto a Genetic Linkage Map Allows Mapping of Genes Affecting Disease Transmission
predicted summary: The mosquito Aedes aegypti transmits some of the most important human arboviruses, including dengue, yellow fever and chikungunya viruses. A large genome contains repetitive sequences that have resulted in the genome being poorly assembled. Here we have improved genome assembly by scoring SNPs from two strains of mosquito genomes. We found that there are very large regions around the centromeres which extend to as much as 47% of genome scaffolds along the chromosome. This allowed mapping candidate genes that could affect disease transmission. To illustrate the utility of this new genome Assembly map, we used this map to map gene that makes mosquito resistant to the human parasite Brugia malayi resistant against the mosquito brugibacterium.

title: The mecillinam resistome reveals a role for peptidoglycan endopeptidases in stimulating cell wall synthesis in Escherichia coli
predicted summary: Bacterial cells are typically comprised of heteropolymer matrix matrixes called the cell wall constructed from heteropeptidoglycan synthases called penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs). These drugs prevent the crosslinking of nascent matrix material into the existing network. Here, we used transposon-sequencing (Tn-Seq) as a high-throughput method to identify nearly all mecillinam resistance loci in the E. coli genome, providing insights into new mechanisms involved in drug assembly and drug resistance. We found that the overproduction of endopeptide enzymes that cleave Crosslinks in filamentous cells promotes drugsynthesis by stimulating enzyme activity. Our results provide new insight into novel mechanisms responsible for drug production and Drug Resistance. Furthermore, our results reveal that inhibition of stress response-independent resistance is likely to promote drug development.

title: Shunting Inhibition Controls the Gain Modulation Mediated by Asynchronous Neurotransmitter Release in Early Development
predicted summary: GABAergic interneurons regulate information flow at synapses during early development. Synaptic transmitter release regulates the firing rate dependent on the membrane conductance and noise-dependent plasticity. However, early developmental neurons are excitatory and other mechanisms such as asynchronous release may contribute to modulating neuronal input-output curves. In this paper we investigated the impact of membrane noise and short-term Plasticity on synaptical gain during Early Development. We modelled both high-shunt inhibition and Low-Shunt regimes in early Development to study the effects of noise inhibition on neurons firing rates depending on membrane Conductance. Our results suggest that inhibition inhibition can regulate the input response of neurons to input inputs and its impact can be flexibly modulated by membrane plasticities.

title: Regulation of Protein Quality Control by UBE4B and LSD1 through p53-Mediated Transcription
predicted summary: Protein quality control is essential for clearing misfolded proteins from mammalian cells by activating both proteasomal degradation machineries and autophagic degradation machineryries. Loss of human orthologs UBE4B and lysine-specific demethylase 1 (LSD1) promotes clearance of Misfold proteins associated with neurodegenerative disorders. Here, we identify two genes involved in protein quality regulation that synergistically and robustly suppress neurotoxicity associated mitotic proteins in Caenorhabditis elegans. Mutation of transcription factor p53 functions downstream regulators involved by regulation of proteins Quality Control Regulation Regulation pathways that protect against proteotoxicity involved with protein degradation processes. This study identifies transcription factors that function as key regulator of protein Quality Regulation and provides insights into mechanisms that regulate proteins quality Regulation.

title: DynaFace: Discrimination between Obligatory and Non-obligatory Protein-Protein Interactions Based on the Complex’s Dynamics
predicted summary: Interactions between proteins have been evolutionarily designed to enable transduction between the proteins. Here we hypothesize that analysis of the dynamics of protein interactions can reveal details about the nature of interactions and whether it persists throughout the entire lifetime of proteins, or not. We show here that obligatory proteins differ in their decomposition into dynamic domains, i.e. mobile elements held together through few anchor residues on one side of Interface Interface that interact with their counterpart grooves at the other end. In obligatorily binding proteins Complexes the interface often hinged between nonbinding proteins Holding Together Through Few anchor Binding Grooves held Together through couplers holding together between them. title: Genetic Control of Conventional and Pheromone-Stimulated Biofilm Formation in Candida albicans
predicted summary: Candida albicans are the sexually competent form of Candida. Opaque cells undergo efficient growth and mating in the presence of pheromone-stimulated biofilm formation under physiological conditions. In contrast, opaque cells are also required for cell cohesion. Here we show that Cph1, ortholog of Saccharomyces cerevisiae Ste12, regulates formation of both conventional and non-conventional forms of C. albianae Biofilm Formation. We also identify genes that mediate formations of conventional forms by mediating transcriptional regulators involved in cell CoHesion Regulation. Furthermore, we identify transcription factors that play general roles during cell development. This study shows that transcription regulator genes play important roles in Cell Cohension regulation.

title: Resolving Structural Variability in Network Models and the Brain
predicted summary: Large-scale white matter pathways crisscross brain regions create complex patterns of connectivity that underlies human cognitive function. However, little is known about mechanistic drivers of structured networks. We characterize both empirical and synthetic networks using familiar graph metrics, but presented here in a more complete statistical form, to reveal the full range of variability across scales in the network properties measured from diffusion spectrum imaging data of the human brain. Using synthetic models chosen to probe the roles of physical network embedding and temporal network growth rules and constraints, we find that networks hardcoded to display one property do not simultaneously simultaneously display another property (e.g., hierarchy). We show that synthetic network models that constrain networks to be physically embedded in anatomical regions tend to produce distributions that are most similar to the measured measurements for brain imaging datasets. These results suggest that multiple neurobiological mechanisms may be at play during the development of brain network architecture.

title: Conditional Inactivation of Upstream Binding Factor Reveals Its Epigenetic Functions and the Existence of a Somatic Nucleolar Precursor Body
predicted summary: Upstream Binding Factor (UBF) is a unique multi-HMGB-box protein first identified as co-factor in RNA polymerase I transcription. However, its poor DNA sequence selectivity and ability to generate nucleoprotein complexes suggest that UBF defines the active conformation of both gene sequence and enhancer sequences, leaving open open the question of its requirement for RPI transcription beyond morula. Using gene deletion in mouse embryonic cells, we show that deletion prevents formation of the large sub-nuclear structure resembling the Nucleolar precursor Body (NPB) of oocytes and early embryos. Loss abolished the number of actively transcribed ribosomal proteins involved in gene activity but did not affect cell proliferation. Furthermore, deletion prevented formation

title: Mitochondrial dual-coding genes in Trypanosoma brucei
predicted summary: Trypanosoma brucei is transmitted between mammalian hosts by the tsetse fly. These parasites undergo repeated population bottlenecks as they evade host immune systems that would create additional forces of genetic drift that endangers their integrity. Here, we show that many mitochondrial genes can alter the choice of start codon and open reading frames by alternative editing of the 5′ end flanking genes within genes that remain under selection. We hypothesize that dual-coding genes protect genetic information by hiding non-selected genes contained within those genes under Selection that are subject to Genetic drift. This novel metabolically expensive system provides novel molecular strategy to combat genome-wide Genomic drift in Non-Selective conditions.

title: Genome-Wide Association Analyses Identify SPOCK as a Key Novel Gene Underlying Age at Menarche

Our findings strongly supported the hypothesis that Age At Menarchemia Variation Underlies Age-Amenarhie variation. In addition, our results strongly Supported that age at Menarhia variation underlies ageing senzati senzati variation in women across different ethnic backgrounds. However, genetic variants underlying age associated variation remain unknown. Previous studies have identified novel genes that play important roles in age AtMENarhi

title: Cathepsin B in Antigen-Presenting Cells Controls Mediators of the Th1 Immune Response during Leishmania major Infection

Previous reports indicated that cysteine cathepsin inhibitors indicated differential patterns of antigen processing patterns during both susceptible and resistant mouse strains during infection.
