We generated bone-marrow Dendritic cells (BMDC) and macrophages (BMM) from Ctsb/ mice expressing high levels of MHC class II molecules than their wild-type counterparts. These findings suggest that Cytopeptide-dependent proteins play important roles during L. major infections. Our findings provide insights into the role played by cysticillins B (CtSb) regulation of Th1 response responses during the development of resistant mice. Moreover, we show that Cathepasin B regulates the expression of cytokine production. Furthermore, our results suggest

title: Teaching genetics prior to teaching evolution improves evolution understanding but not acceptance
predicted summary: Genetics and evolution are typically taught separately to 14- to 16-y-old secondary school students as separate topics with few links, in no particular order and sometimes with a large time span between. In this study, we modified extant questionnaires to ascertain students understanding evolution along with acceptance of evolution. We found that teaching genetics prior to evolution had positive effects on evolution understanding by increasing knowledge by 7% over those taught in the inverse order. Our results suggest minimally disruptive, zero-cost intervention to improve evolution Understanding.

title: Experimental Evolution of an RNA Virus in Wild Birds: Evidence for Host-Dependent Impacts on Population Structure and Competitive Fitness
predicted summary: RNA viruses form populations that are genetically complex due to error-prone replication and are reduced by stochastic and selective mechanisms that remain incompletely understood. Understanding how natural selection shapes viral populations is critical because it can inform treatment paradigms and enhance control efforts. This study provides insights into how different hosts differ in susceptibility to virus-induced mortality. We conducted fitness competition assays in wild-caught American crows, house sparrow-passaged WNV passaged in American Robins to assess the fitness gains that occurred between passages that differed between species-specific host populations differing in severity of disease-susceptible viruses. Our results suggest that mutational tolerance is strongly influenced by natural Selection, likely via complementatory complementation rather than selective pressures associated with the strength of selection that controls virus populations.

title: Significant associations between driver gene mutations and DNA methylation alterations across many cancer types
predicted summary: Recent evidence shows that mutations in several driver genes can cause aberrant hypomethylation patterns, a hallmark hallmark of thyroid cancer. We hypothesized that the landscapes of tumor genomes and epigenomes are tightly interconnected. Here we used principal component analyses applied at the nucleotide level and with respect to genome-wide trends to distinguish between two thyroid Cancer subtypes. These results establish that driver gene mutation associations are associated with site-specific changes capable of shaping regulatory network functions, which could improve treatment efficacy. Furthermore, using these association associations, we were able distinguish tumors into more homogeneous subsets according to their molecular characteristics.

title: Increased Vascularity in Cervicovaginal Mucosa with Schistosoma haematobium Infection
predicted summary: Schistosoma haematobium ova surrounding the female genital mucosa increased the risk of human immunodeficiency virus infection compared to healthy controls. Inhibitory blood vessel markers CD31 and von Willebrand Factor markedly increased Blood vessel proliferation in the tissue surrounding viable parasites associated with viable blood vessels in vitro. These markers were used for immunohistochemical analysis to quantify and characterise the characteristic characteristics of the Vasculature surrounding Sylvesterella Haemoglobinocytes surrounding fibrils and Blood vessels. The findings suggest that SYMPHOLOGY may increase the Risk of Human ImmunDeficiencyVirus infection. Further studies are needed to explore the biological, clinical and epidemiological features of this parasitism.

title: Interpreting Expression Data with Metabolic Flux Models: Predicting Mycobacterium tuberculosis Mycolic Acid Production
predicted summary: Metabolism is central to cell biology, and metabolic disturbances play a role in numerous disease states including tuberculosis. However, the ability to study metabolic states at global scale using genomic technologies is limited. Here we present E-Flux (a combination of Flux Balance Analysis) algorithmically predict metabolic flux capacity using whole cell measurements of gene expression data. Our method correctly predicts seven of the eight known compounds specifically targeted for mycolic acid biosynthesis pathways and makes accurate predictions regarding the specificity of these compounds for metabolic pathways. We apply this algorithm to mycobacterium Tuberculitis, which causes Tuberculous Tuberous Disease (TB). We tested our algorithm using Genomic Genome SequenceArray datasets obtained from over 400 expression array arrays. Using this dataset, we accurately predicted the impact of 75 different drugs, drug combinations and nutrient conditions on metabolism capacity. Based on our results, our method accurately predict seven compounds specific compounds that are targets for several first-line drugs

title: Structural and Functional Insights into the Pilotin-Secretin Complex of the Type II Secretion System
predicted summary: Gram-negative bacteria secrete proteins called secretins on cell surface using special secretion systems known as T2SS, T3SS and T4PS comprising large outer membrane channels formed by lipoprotein pilot proteins essential for the assembly of the secretory proteins. However, the molecular mechanism of this process is poorly understood and its structural basis is unknown. Here we describe the crystal structure of pilotin structure that comprises an arrangement of four -helices profoundly different from previously solved Pilotin structures from the T3. The structure can be described as the incorporation of one open loop into a second open hexagonal hairpin with bent final helical bundles. We show here structures differ significantly different structures than previously Solved Pilot proteins from previous solved pilot systems from known pilot structures and known four distinct structures. These structures suggest the importance of these structures in vitro

title: Exploring the inhibitory effect of membrane tension on cell polarization
predicted summary: Cell membrane tension has been shown to act as a long-range inhibitor of cell polarization. Here, we present mathematical models that incorporate the interplay between Rac GTPase, filamentous actin (F-actin)ATPases during cell membrane relaxation. We further test predictions of this model by performing single cell measurements of spontaneous cell responses of cancer stem cells (CSCs) and non-stem cancer cells. Our simulations recapitulate experimental results described by Houk et al. revealing Rac inhibition induces new cell survival under random perturbations. Based on both models and experimental simulation results, our model provides the first recapitulation of experimental data summarized by experimental measurements performed by cells with the pseudopod-neck-body morphology of Cancer stem Cells.

title: Mesoscopic Segregation of Excitation and Inhibition in a Brain Network Model
predicted summary: Neurons operate under balance of excitation and inhibition, which maintains neural microcircuits within the proper operational range. However, how this balance is played out at the mesoscopic level of neuronal populations is poorly understood. Here we describe computationally the dynamics of a network of cortical macrocolumn networks operating in partially irregular regimes operating under partially synchronized conditions. We show that some columns operate excitably while others exert inhibitory effects on their neighbors. These results suggest that these interactions occur spontaneously under conditions under which these balance arises, suggesting that there may be potential mechanisms for regulation of the balance between Excitation-inhibition balance.

title: A bacterial toxin-antitoxin module is the origin of inter-bacterial and inter-kingdom effectors of Bartonella
predicted summary: Host-targeting type IV secretion systems (T4SS) evolved from conjugative proteins that mediate interbacterial transfer between host cells. However, the origins of effector proteins secreted by these systems remain poorly understood. In this study, we show that the binding proteins VbhT and other FicTA-antitoxin modules of Bartonella schoenbuchensis are closely related to Bacillus subtilis Bacteria conjugata. We propose that they represent an evolutionary missing link that leads from a regular conjugation system to the intracellular binding domain–the BID domain—similar to those Secretor Proteins that are recruited into host Cells via the host host system. Moreover, our results suggest that their recruitment as interkingdom effects may serve yet unknown biological functions in the context of intercellular transfer, suggesting parallel evolutionary pathways.

title: Molecular Detection and Characterization of Tick-borne Pathogens in Dogs and Ticks from Nigeria
predicted summary: Vector vector vector pathogen Candidatus N. mikurensis was detected in blood samples and ticks collected from 181 dogs from Nigeria and represents the potential high risk of human exposure to infection with these agents. Only limited information is currently available on the prevalence and prevalence of vector Vectorborne Pathogens present in dogs in Nigeria. The purpose of this study was to use molecular techniques to detect and characterize Human Vector Pathogenic Agents abundant in Dog Blood Samples obtained from dogs. Blood samples were collected and tracked for human and animal vector-borne agents by sequencing and DNA sequencing techniques. This study indicates that human pathogenic agents are abundantly abundant and represent the Potential High Risk Human Exposure Potential of humans exposed to vector parasites. These results provide new insights into the pathogenesis and development of new strategies to identify vectors that could be beneficial for humans and animals.

title: Filament Compliance Influences Cooperative Activation of Thin Filaments and the Dynamics of Force Production in Skeletal Muscle
predicted summary: Striated muscle fiber activation is greatly enhanced by cooperative interactions between neighboring thin filament regulatory units (RU-RU cooperativity), which increase myosin cross-bridge formation along thick filament distances. These interactions occur with a temporal order, hence they can be considered mechanical forms of cooperation. However, the relative contribution from each mechanism is difficult to separate experimentally-explicitly. In this paper we explored whether these cooperative forms occur cooperatively during muscle contraction. We found that these interactions differed strongly depending on the state of neighbouring regulator units. Our model predicts that the cooperative force response can vary depending upon the number of neighborly Regulation Units involved in XB-dependent interactions. Comparisons provide novel insights into the interaction dynamics dynamics involved during the development of the Half Sarcomere Half SARCOMERE half-sarcomèree.

title: CERAMIC: Case-Control Association Testing in Samples with Related Individuals, Based on Retrospective Mixed Model Analysis with Adjustment for Covariates
predicted summary: Genotypic association testing of binary traits is computationally efficient for genomewide analysis of genetic association information in samples of related individuals of almost any configuration including small families, unrelated individuals and even large complex pedigrees. We propose CERAMIC, which extends previously proposed logistic regression and linear mixed-effects model approaches to allow samples with partially missing genotype information to incorporate missing data in the analysis while correcting for type 1 error across a wider range of scenarios. In simulations, we show that CREAMIC outperforms existing methods maintaining high power and correct Type 1 errors across wide range scenarios, providing better control of Type 2 diabetes errors than Prospective methods such as GMMAT when the model model is misspecified. Using genome scan data from the Framingham Heart Study (FHSS) Genomic Sequence Survey datasets providing data on diabetes susceptibility loci.

title: Primate Lentiviral Vpx Commandeers DDB1 to Counteract a Macrophage Restriction
predicted summary: Primate Primates encode four “accessory proteins” including Vif, Vpu, Nef, and Vpr/Vpx which counteract the antiviral effects of early and late steps in viral replication cycle by counteractivating viral restriction in macrophages. These proteins countervirally counterhibit virus replication by antagonizing viral restrictions against early steps of replication. Here we present evidence that primate primates evolved VpitX proteins that counteracted HIV-2/SIVSM restriction potently against virus infection. Our results suggest VPx proteins are essential for HIV infection by blocking the inhibition of virus infections by inhibiting the activity of VPTX against HIV-1 and SIV replication inhibition.

title: TDAG51 is a crucial regulator of maternal care and depressive-like behavior after parturition
predicted summary: Postpartum depression is closely associated with physical changes and physiological stress during pregnancy or after parturition in stress-sensitive women. However, the influence of genetic risk factors on the development of depression remains unclear. In this study, we discovered novel function of T cell death-associated gene 51 (TDAG51/PHLDA1) against maternal care defects and depressive behaviors after postpartogenesis. These findings suggest that T Cell Death-Associated Gene 51 plays protective role against both maternal Care defects as well as depression-like behaviors following Parturitiation. We found that mutations in the expression levels of various genes regulate neuroendocrine factor levels, monoamine neurotransmitter levels and neuropeptide levels were also observed in dams with impaired maternal behaviors in pup retrieving, nursing and nest building tests.

title: A key role for sex chromosomes in the regulation of parthenogenesis in the brown alga Ectocarpus
predicted summary: Sexual reproduction is frequent evolutionary transitions from sexual reproduction to parthenogenetic reproduction. Genetic bases of these shifts remain poorly understood. Here we used quantitative trait analysis combined genomic information combined with genomic and transcriptomic information to dissect the genetic basis of reproductive polymorphisms in the brown alga Ectocarpus. We found that Parthenogenesis is controlled by the sex locus, together with two additional autosomal loci. Our data provide the first empirical illustration, to our knowledge, of a trade-off between the diploid stages of the life cycle, where distinct parts have opposing effects on male fitness, and different fitness effects depending on the Life Cycle generation/ploidally-antagonistic selection. Importantly, our results provide insights into the mechanisms by which the action of fluctuating selection may contribute to the maintenance of genetic diversity in natural populations and structures life history evolution.

title: Functional significance of rare neuroligin 1 variants found in autism
predicted summary: Neuroligin1 (NLGN1) is known to cause neuropsychiatric disorders including autism spectrum disorder. However, its significance in neurodevelopmental disorders remains unknown. Here, we present genetic variants found in ASD siblings that lead to altered localization, protein degradation, and altered spine formation. We show that mutant mice lacking mutant mutant proteins display abnormal social behavior characteristic characteristic of autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). These results support that synaptopathies play important roles in the development and function of the neuronal glutamatergic synapses involved involved cell adhesion molecules involved in glutATPATP binding pathways. Moreover, mutations are functionally significant because they are associated with changes in spine Localization and degradation proteins. Our results suggest that deletions that occur at the glutamine glutachemia pathway may contribute to the impairment of spine Formation, which is a core feature of Autism Spectrum disorder characterized by abnormal behavior.

title: Risk Factors for Buruli Ulcer: A Case Control Study in Cameroon
predicted summary: Buruli ulcer is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans which is associated with areas where the water is slow-flowing or stagnant. However, mechanisms of transmission of the disease through human activities are unknown. A case-control study comparing Case-patients with community-matched controls identified risk factors including low education level, swamp wading, wearing lower-body clothing while farming, living near cocoa plantation or woods, using adhesive bandages when hurt, and using leaves as traditional treatment. Risk factors identified included using bed nets during farming activities as protective guarding against BurULI ulcer disease. This study provides new insights into the mechanism mechanisms mechanisms involved in transmission mechanisms including wound treatment and wound treatments.

title: Exposure Patterns Driving Ebola Transmission in West Africa: A Retrospective Observational Study
predicted summary: The ongoing West African Ebola epidemic began in December 2013 in Guinea, probably from a single zoonotic introduction. It resulted in more than 19,000 probable and probable cases by 4 May 2015, mostly in Liberia (5,343) and Sierra Leone (10,746); exposures were reported by 33% of suspected contacts prior to becoming ill. Here we present retrospective analyses of data collected during the outbreak, which identify drivers of transmission patterns and highlight areas where control could be improved. We found evidence linking cases to potential source contacts was better than other health care facilities at providing information on the transmission network. Our analysis revealed high degree heterogeneity in inferred transmission networks, with only 20% of cases accounting for at least 73% new infections; this phenomenon is often called super-spreading, often known as Super-Spread.

title: The Ebola Virus VP30-NP Interaction Is a Regulator of Viral RNA Synthesis

title: Feasible Introgression of an Anti-pathogen Transgene into an Urban Mosquito Population without Using Gene-Drive
predicted summary: Mutating mosquitoes carrying only anti-pathogen constructs into wild vector populations could reduce disease transmission. However, none of the proposed gene-drive mechanisms are likely to be implemented as public health measures in the near future. Here we use Skeeter Buster, previously published stochastic spatially explicit model of Aedes aegypti, to assess whether two other genetic control strategies have been developed for mosquito populations that rely on population reduction would be efficient and effective under field conditions. We find that releases carried only mosquito strains can substantially decrease vector competence, even at release ratios well below those considered necessary for population replacement Strategies that depend upon population suppression alone. Our results suggest that both genetically feasible strategies require linking genes with selfish genetic elements, rather than linking gene driver genes to selfish genes.

title: Polysome Profiling in Liver Identifies Dynamic Regulation of Endoplasmic Reticulum Translatome by Obesity and Fasting

Obesity-associated metabolic complications are generally considered to arise from changes in carbohydrates and fat metabolism, but the status of proteins metabolism remains poorly understood. Here, we performed comparative polysome-bound transcriptional profiling analyses to study the dynamics and functional implications of protein synthesis machinery and mitochondrial components in livers of obese mice under chronic obesity conditions. We found that the liver translatome exhibits a general reduction in protein synthetization machinery, mitochondria components, and proteins involved in glycolipid metabolism. Further studies including new samples and areas are needed.

title: Inferring decoding strategies for multiple correlated neural populations
predicted summary: Neuronal activity has long been used separately to understand the neural basis of perception. However these approaches sometimes lead to drastically conflicting conclusions about the functional role of brain areas without additional experiments to measure interneuronal correlations. Here we demonstrate here that it is possible to infer correlation weights of different brain regions at a coarse scale without precise knowledge of the correlation structure. Our theory makes specific testable predictions consistent with data collected from two different cortical areas trained to perform heading discrimination tasks experimentally without the need for measurements of correlation structures. We apply this theory to neural data obtained from macaque monkey monkeys trained during headhunting tasks trained for Headhead Hunting Tasks Training.

title: Informing Optimal Environmental Influenza Interventions: How the Host, Agent, and Environment Alter Dominant Routes of Transmission
predicted summary: Influenza transmission can occur through respirable airborne particles, inspirable particles (intermediate size particles), direct droplet spraying, and contact modes. How these modes are affected by features of the virus strain (infectivity, survivability, transferability), host population (behavior, susceptibility profiles, or host movement patterns) and environment has only recently come under investigation. A discrete-event stochastic transmission model constructed to analyze the environmental processes through which influenza passes from one person to another via different transmission modes can cause high transmission in isolation of other modes, while in other contexts no transmission may result. We found that one or more modes may be sufficient to cause High Transmission. Inhibition choices that involve blocking environmental pathways should be contextualized depending on specific characteristics of people, viruses strain strain, host populations and host characteristics.

title: Association of Fasciola hepatica Infection with Liver Fibrosis, Cirrhosis, and Cancer: A Systematic Review

Future high-quality studies are needed to determine the role fasciolinacia on the development of liver cancer worldwide. title: Active-site mTOR inhibitors augment HSV1-dICP0 infection in cancer cells via dysregulated eIF4E/4E-BP axis

Our results suggest that combination inhibitor combination of active Site Dual inhibitorhibitors abolishes the viral response in tumour cells exhibiting dysregulated expression of binding protein binding proteins (4EBPs), thus augmenting infection.

title: Systematic review of community-based, school-based, and combined delivery modes for reaching school-aged children in mass drug administration programs for schistosomiasis
predicted summary: School-based mass preventive chemotherapy of school-aged children with praziquantel is the mainstay of current schistosomiasis control programs. This treatment is delivered through combination school and community delivery systems that maximize coverage for both in- and out-of-school children overall and specifically of non-enrolled subpopulations of children. Overall coverage rates were highest overall overall (49%) followed by the lowest coverage specifically for children in groups with low school enrollment overall (99%). Comparatively low coverage included fear of side effects, inadequate education about MDA, lack incentives for drug distributors, and inequitable distribution to marginalized groups, a potential challenge for future mass prevention programs, especially when combined with interventions such as snacks for treated children, educational campaigns, incentive campaigns and active inclusion campaigns. These results provide evidence-Based framework for the development of future Mass Treatment Control Programs. Combination of community and school Based Treatment Delivery Systems provides an Evidence Based Framework for Future Development Strategies

title: Complex Evolutionary Events at a Tandem Cluster of Arabidopsis thaliana Genes Resulting in a Single-Locus Genetic Incompatibility
predicted summary: Genetic interactions between genomes have important implications not only for practical applications such as breeding but also for understanding evolution. In extreme cases, genes from different genomic backgrounds may be incompatible and compromise normal development or physiology. However, only a few cases of genetic over- or underdominance affecting plant growth or fitness are understood at the level of individual genes. Here we describe an interaction between two different accessions of Arabidopsis thaliana OAK (OUTGROWTH-ASSOCIATED PROTEIN KINASE) gene interactions that resulted in aberrant growth patterns that depend on newly acquired promoter sequences with novel expression patterns. Our work provides insights into how tandem arrays, which are particularly vulnerable to frequent rearrangements, can produce novel plant fitness effects.

title: A modeling study of budding yeast colony formation and its relationship to budding pattern and aging
predicted summary: Budding yeast cells undergo different biological processes during budding and mating. However, not much is known about the biological functions differing among yeast colonies at population level. In this paper, we develop agent-based agent model system to study yeast colony development under physiological constraints. Based on simulation simulations, colonies initiated by aged diploid cells show declines in growth probability at an early stage and recover as rejuvenated offsprings become the majority. Our results suggest that the frequency of matING type switch might control the trade-off between Diploidization and Inbreedering, possibly due to the fact that young cells contribute the most to colonization. The results provide insight into the effects of nutrient limitation on the number of cells initiated at early stages.

title: Incorporating Scale Dependence in Disease Burden Estimates: The Case of Human African Trypanosomiasis in Uganda
predicted summary: Disability-adjusted Life Years (DALYs) are estimates of the burden of human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) globally. However, most estimates have been calculated as national totals. This represents the first geographically delimited estimation of HAT disease burden at the sub-country scale, taking into account the critical importance of spatial scale bias bias against highly focal diseases for which geographicly targeted interventions may be feasible and cost-effective. We map spatial variation in disability burden across Uganda for the years 2000–2009 using Geographic Information Systems software and summarised by parish and district levels. Our results provide updated and improved estimates across high-impact districts in Uganda comparable to the national burden rates for major infectious diseases such as malaria and HIV/AIDS.

title: MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry Detection of Pathogens in Vectors: The Borrelia crocidurae/Ornithodoros sonrai Paradigm
predicted summary: Borreliae are neglected vector-borne pathogens that cause mild to deadly mild fever and miscarriage in Africa. Screening vectors for the presence of these pathogenic bacteria requires technically demanding molecular methods. Matrix-assisted laser time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF-MS) has recently emerged as a tool for rapid identification of vector species and vectorization of cultured strains of bacteria. In this work we investigated whether matrix-Assisted Laser Time-Of-Flight Mass Spectrophorescopy could be used to identify vectorized bacteria directly in ticks. We found that mammalian bacteria-specific protein patterns were detected directly from tick tick samples. Our results demonstrate the potential to use laser-based mass-spectroscopy to detect B. crocidurae directly by subtracting the uninfected tick profile from the previously determined protein profiles.

title: Functional Interplay between Type I and II Interferons Is Essential to Limit Influenza A Virus-Induced Tissue Inflammation
predicted summary: Influenza influenza A virus (IAV) is associated with exuberant inflammation characterized by the production of proinflammatory cytokines including interferons (IFNs). However, it remains unclear how the immune system clears influenza viruses without causing lethal immunopathology. Here, we demonstrate that type I IFN signaling coordinates host inflammation during influenza virus infection in mice by orchestrating the recruitment of classical Ly6Chi mononuclear cell populations into IAV-infected lungs. In addition to its known anti-viral activity, Type I Regulation Regulation regulates both monocyte recruitment and neutrophil trafficking pathways required for the regulation of host immune responses to influenza infection. Our study provides insight into the regulatory mechanisms required by both types of regulatory pathways.

title: Characterization and Identification of MicroRNA Core Promoters in Four Model Species
predicted summary: MicroRNAs are short noncoding RNA molecules that play important roles in posttranscriptional gene regulation. We characterize the promoters of microRNA genes in Caenorhabditis elegans, Homo sapiens, Arabidopsisthaliana, and Oryza sativa using common query voting CoVote prediction method, which is more effective than available Promoter prediction methods. Using this new approach, we identify putative Core Promoters of most known macrophages that match or resemble known protein-coding genes that regulate transcriptional transcription. Our results show that many significant sequence sequencemotifs are conserved across different species while others are specific to individual species. Furthermore, our results reveal many characteristic sequence motif sequence Sequential Sequence motifs associated with transcription regulation of genes.

title: DUF1220 Dosage Is Linearly Associated with Increasing Severity of the Three Primary Symptoms of Autism
predicted summary: One of the most frequently documented copy variations associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is the copy number variation that encompasses sequences encoded by previously unexamined gene variants known as DUF1220 protein domains. title: A polyploid admixed origin of beer yeasts derived from European and Asian wine populations
predicted summary: Saccharomyces cerevisiae strains used to make beer, bread, and wine differ genetically and phenotypically from wild populations associated with trees. The origins of these domesticated populations are not always clear; human-associated migration and migration have had a strong impact on their population structure. We found yeast variants that were recombinant between grape grape varieties and rice rice populations, suggesting that modern yeast fermentation technology is the product of an evolutionary melting pot of fermenting technology.

title: Characterizing Antibody Responses to Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum Antigens in India Using Genome-Scale Protein Microarrays
predicted summary: Understanding naturally acquired immune responses to Plasmodium parasites is key to improving malaria surveillance and diagnostic tools tailored to the diverse epidemiology of malaria across the world. Our results suggest targeted surveillance approaches tailored specifically to malaria epidemiologic settings across different epidemiological settings.

title: Genome Sequence of the Pea Aphid Acyrthosiphon pisum
predicted summary: Aphids are important agricultural pests and also biological models for studies of insect-plant interactions, virus vectoring, and the developmental causes of extreme plasticity. These findings provide foundation for post-genomic study of fundamental biological questions and applied agricultural problems.

title: PEP1 of Arabis alpina Is Encoded by Two Overlapping Genes That Contribute to Natural Genetic Variation in Perennial Flowering

title: High Affinity Human Antibody Fragments to Dengue Virus Non-Structural Protein 3

title: KSHV Reactivation from Latency Requires Pim-1 and Pim-3 Kinases to Inactivate the Latency-Associated Nuclear Antigen LANA

title: LAB-1 Targets PP1 and Restricts Aurora B Kinase upon Entrance into Meiosis to Promote Sister Chromatid Cohesion

title: A Genome-Scale DNA Repair RNAi Screen Identifies SPG48 as a Novel Gene Associated with Hereditary Spastic Paraplegia
predicted summary: Repair via homologous recombination DNA double-strand break repair (HR-DSBR) typically restores original DNA sequence without introducing mutations. However, this important DNA repair pathway is frequently mutated in patients suffering from hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP). Here we describe a genome-scale screening screen for genes involved in HR Double Stroke Repair. We show that the gene KIAA0415 encodes proteins that interact with protein complex proteins SPG11/SPG15 that are required for efficient HR double break Repair pathways. Mutations in mutant cell lines suggest novel mechanisms involved with HR repair pathways and associated medical conditions associated with HSP-associated diseases.

title: Diagnosis of Bacterial Bloodstream Infections: A 16S Metagenomics Approach
predicted summary: Bacterial bloodstream infection (bBSI) is one of the leading causes of death in critically ill patients and accurate diagnosis is therefore crucial. This proof-of-concept study was delivered in 75 children with severe febrile illness in Burkina Faso and showed that appropriate control samples are crucial for the detection of background signals due to environmental contamination. Our results demonstrate that 16S metagenomics is a powerful approach for diagnosing and understanding Polymicrobial Bloodstream infections.

title: Tsetse Control and Gambian Sleeping Sickness; Implications for Control Strategy
predicted summary: Gambian sleeping sickness (human African trypanosomiasis, HAT) outbreaks are brought under control by case detection and treatment although it is recognised that this typically only reaches about 75% of the population. Vector control is capable of completely interrupting human malaria transmission but is considered too expensive and difficult to organise in resource-poor settings. We conducted a full scale field trial of vector control technology to determine its utility in control of Sleeping sickness in Northern Uganda. Using data obtained from previous field trials we determined the number of tiny targets required required to reduce Gambia sleeping mosquito populations by more than 90% needed to stop transmission.

title: Analyzing the symmetrical arrangement of structural repeats in proteins with CE-Symm
predicted summary: The analysis of structural repeats is fundamental to understanding protein function and evolution. The detection of internal repeat patterns and repeat elements fundamentally helps the user investigate interesting cases of protein evolution, functional annotation and evolutionary studies. We present recent improvements to CE-Symm 2.0 tool for systematically detecting sequence-to-structure sequence sequence patterns in proteins with robust algorithmic extensions and demonstrate its application to the study of interesting Cases of Protein Evolution and Functional annotation. In addition to accurately reporting the type of repeating unit, CESYMM 2.0 detects the sequence repeat repeat arrangement with transformation operations and Transformation operations, and Comparing the similarity of all repeat units at residue level.

title: Mapping Dynamic Histone Acetylation Patterns to Gene Expression in Nanog-Depleted Murine Embryonic Stem Cells

The molecular mechanisms that govern cell fate are poorly understood, but recent results point to a key role for epigenetic mechanisms. Our results shed light on the complexity of genomic regulation networks that regulate embryonic stem cells. We identify genes central to the regulatory network of MouseEmbryonic stem CellRegulatory Networks, including those identified in recent genome-wide genomic screens and PluriNet, which is computationally derived stem cell signatures. title: Phenotypic Heterogeneity and the Evolution of Bacterial Life Cycles

Here we show that surface colonization rapidly evolves and leads to complex life cycles in which sticky cells alternate between living in the liquid and living side by side on the surface. We show here that the evolution of the sticky cell type goes hand in hand with the Evolution of Complex Life Stages: colonies reproduce via fission and by producing filamentous propagules inside colonies; colonies produce filament filaments to facilitate expansion; colony replication is formed by colonies that exhibit complex features: they reproduce by their own attachment, but also that of non-sticky cells. In the presence of regulation, cell differentiation leads side-by-side interactions between sticky and Non Sticky Cell Types, which are required for surface attachment.

title: Convergent Transcription Induces Dynamic DNA Methylation at disiRNA Loci

title: Functional Impairment of Human Myeloid Dendritic Cells during Schistosoma haematobium Infection

To address this question, plasmacytoid DC from infected subjects displayed lower expression levels of HLA-DR compared to controls obtained from controls. Inhibition of myeloid DC showed lower activating capacity than those from healthy subjects, suggesting that inhibition of DC activation could be one mechanism involved involved in this phenomenon. Our results provide new insights into the mechanisms contributing mechanisms of T Cell Hyporesponsiveness.

title: Identifying Selection in the Within-Host Evolution of Influenza Using Viral Sequence Data
predicted summary: Influenza virus evolution is a vital component of its epidemiology. We describe here methods to measure selection acting upon influenza virus within individual hosts using time-resolved genome sequence data obtained from transmission studies conducted in pigs. Our method accounts for linkage disequilibrium between nucleotides at different positions within the haemagglutinin gene allowing for the analysis of viral populations in which multiple mutations are present at any given time. The results provide insight into the dynamics of influenza infection, providing detailed characterisation of the forces underlie viral evolution.

title: Estimated impact on birth weight of scaling up intermittent preventive treatment of malaria in pregnancy given sulphadoxine-pyrimethamine resistance in Africa: A mathematical model

However, current coverage is far from optimal across Africa. We combined estimates of the changing prevalence and impact of parasitological endpoints across African settings to estimate the incremental value of scaling up insecticidal treatment to match current CoverageAcrossAfrica coverage acrossAfrica from 2000–2015 across endemic settings across sub-Saharan Africa, including countries with sufficient recent data available to assess the extent of resistance mutations and coverage gaps across these settings. Based on previous estimates, we estimate that only 16.5% of potential MiP births prevented would have already had already been prevented by scaling Up IPTP-SP uptake. title: Large-scale genome-wide meta-analysis of polycystic ovary syndrome suggests shared genetic architecture for different diagnosis criteria

PCOS is diagnosed with two different sets of diagnostic criteria. Genetic similarities between cases diagnosed Based on the two criteria have been poorly understood, suggesting genetic similarities across genotypes based on metabolic markers such as body mass index, fasting insulin, type 2 diabetes, testosterone levels and coronary artery disease. Identified genetic variants associated with obesity, Fasting Insulin regulation and Type 2 Diabetes played a causal role in obesity-related diseases. title: Role of the Single-Stranded DNA–Binding Protein SsbB in Pneumococcal Transformation: Maintenance of a Reservoir for Genetic Plasticity

title: Distinct Roles for Intra- and Extracellular Siderophores during Aspergillus fumigatus Infection
