title: Non-equilibrium repressor binding kinetics link DNA damage dose to transcriptional timing within the SOS gene network
predicted summary: Sequential transcription regulation networks are often genetically encoded networks, where one transcription factor regulates the activity of multiple genes within a network. In the DNA damage repair pathway known as the SOS response of Escherichia coli, approximately 40 genes are separated into subsets of ‘early’, ‘middle’ and ‘late’ genes, which is temporally separated between genes. However, both the range and mechanism of this separation have not been experimentally defined. Here we show that the timing of gene activity is not separated at low levels of DNA Damage, but rather arises at higher levels and increases with higher doses. Our data provide insight into this remarkable feature of the genome-wide evolution mechanism involved in the evolution of living organisms by providing insights into mechanisms that regulate gene activation.

title: High susceptibility of magpie (Pica pica) to experimental infection with lineage 1 and 2 West Nile virus
predicted summary: Resident birds play important roles in flavivirus epidemiology since they can serve as reservoirs and facilitate overwintering of the virus. Herein we report the first experimental infection of magpie (Pica pica) with two strains of West Nile virus, lineages 1 (NY-99) and 2 (SRB Novi-Sad/12), which are currently circulating in Europe. Magpies were highly susceptible to WNV infection, with similar low survival rates (30% and 42.8%) for both linesages. Our observations shed light on the pathogenesis, transmission, and ecology of virus transmission between birds and humans.

title: Multiple Immune Factors Are Involved in Controlling Acute and Chronic Chikungunya Virus Infection
predicted summary: CHIKUNGUNYA virus infection has been associated with persistent persistence of steady-state persistent viraemias in persistently infected wild-type mice. Herein we provide evidence for the role of T cells (but not vaccine-induced immune responses) in chronic arthritis promotion. We show that persistent persistent antiviral responses are required for suppression of chronic inflammation. Our results highlight the relevance of persistent viral persistence to chronic disease, both as persistentLY persistent, steady state persistent inflammation and persistent activation of antibody responses post viral infection. Chronic inflammation promoted arthritis promoted osteoarthritic arthritis, with sustained persistence sustained up to 100 days post infection and subsequent succumbing to arthritis progression. These results provide support for development of novel therapeutic interventions to improve disease control.

title: Data-driven reverse engineering of signaling pathways using ensembles of dynamic models
predicted summary: Signal transduction networks are dynamic scaffolding scaffolds for dynamic models, which can be used for mechanistic interpretations and reliable dynamic predictions in new experimental conditions. The problem is particularly difficult when the objective is to obtain dynamic networks capable of predicting the effect of novel perturbations not considered during model training. Here we present SELDOM (EnSEmbLe of Dynamic lOgic-Based Models), which builds ensembles of logic-based dynamics models that combine their individual simulations into ensemble predictions. We show that its ensemble prediction is consistently consistently better than predictions from individual models and consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods used in the recent HPN-DREAM breast cancer challenge. Our results demonstrate the utility of this method beyond basic network inference methods, but also highly competitive against state of the art methods for the purpose of recovering network topology.

title: Complete Firing-Rate Response of Neurons with Complex Intrinsic Dynamics
predicted summary: Resonant neuronal responses depend on the intrinsic properties of its constituent neurons–integration and resonance–while resonance arises primarily due to slow adaptation with an intrinsic frequency acting to sharpen and adjust the location of the resonance peak. Here we identify six distinct response types and characterize the routes to resonance across all values of relevant timescales. We show that resonance emerges from its intrinsic resonance properties and contributes to its local area firing rate dynamics. In this paper, we provide an account of how resonance dynamics shapes dynamic population response properties in neurons containing populations of neurons located in brain areas of brain Areas of Brain Area neurons and provide insights into the dynamics dynamics involved in population activity.

title: IrSPI, a Tick Serine Protease Inhibitor Involved in Tick Feeding and Bartonella henselae Infection
predicted summary: Ixodes ricinus is the most abundant tick vector in Europe, frequently bites humans and is vector of several pathogens including Lyme disease, Tick-Borne Encephalitis, anaplasmosis, BabesioSis and Bartonelloses transmitted to vertebrate hosts via tick salivary glands during blood feeding. This study provides genomic information about this important disease vector. Using next generation sequencing techniques, we characterize transcriptomes of female IXOdes salivaries using high-throughput sequencing Techniques. We found that expression patterns of genes belonging belonging to the member of the BPTI/Kunitz family of serine protease inhibitors showed highest up-regulation in response to Bartonella infection than non-infected ticks, suggesting IrSPI is likely implicated as vaccine against tick-borne pathogenic diseases.

title: Specific Management of Post-Chikungunya Rheumatic Disorders: A Retrospective Study of 159 Cases in Reunion Island from 2006-2012
predicted summary: Post-chikungunya chronic inflammation syndromes (CIRs) were identified according to validated criteria: mechanical shoulder pains, bilateral distal polyarthralgia that frequently resulted with bone lesions detectable by radiographic imaging occurred in half of the patients (median time: 3.5 years pCHIK). These chronic pain disorders were managed with painkillers, local anti-inflammatory drugs (MTX), local antibiotics and/or general immunomodulatory biologic agents due to failure of contra-indication of methotrexate treatment. This retrospective retrospective study provides diagnostic algorithm to help physicians deal with chronic Pain Syndromes following tropical tropical arthritogenic virus infection in Reunion Island following Tropical Cyclonal ChikUNGUNYa outbreak in 2006.

title: Structural Bridges through Fold Space
predicted summary: Folds are structural units that partition proteins into five principal community structures: all- Sandwiches, All Barrels and all barrels. However these units sit relative to each other in a global structure space. In this paper we construct networks that describe such global relationships between folds in the form of structural bridges using four different structural alignment methods across multiple score thresholds spanning multiple scores. Our results suggest that evolutionary information encoded along these networks represents pivotal topological features which act as key attractors within our landscape landscape. We also show that unconnected fold pairs are associated with higher age differences than bridged fold pairings as well as higher Age Differences with the number of networks.

title: The host cell secretory pathway mediates the export of Leishmania virulence factors out of the parasitophorous vacuole
predicted summary: Lipophosphoglycan and metalloprotease proteins are released from host cells following parasitophorous vacuocytosis and redistributed to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of macrophages following host cell colonization by Leishmania glycoconjugates. Pharmacological disruption of this machinery hindered the trafficking of these proteins from the PV and dampened the transport of host proteins by Golgi proteins. Here, we show that lipophosphatychloride glycopeptide molecules were released following the parasite exiting the host Vacuolar plasma membrane following colonizing parasitocytes Following colonisation, transporting these molecules to host Cell Secretory machinery that mediates the spreading of parasitogenic effectors beyond the Endoderm membrane. Drug inhibition prevented the release of lipotropedylmaleimide-sensitive receptor attachment proteins Sec22b and syntaxin-5, which regulate the Transport Transport machinery between Endothermum and Endotromphocyte-GolGI transport machinery.

title: Loss of the Greatwall Kinase Weakens the Spindle Assembly Checkpoint
predicted summary: Chromosome segregation defects contribute to premature spindle assembly checkpoint silencing in MastlNULL MEFs. Here we show that although MasTL knockout cells enter mitosis, they progress through mitotic arrest without complete completion of Cdk1 activity. We further uncover the requirement for robust SpindLE assembly Checkpoint maintenance since the duration of SAC inhibition caused by microtubule poisoning occurs prematurely. Our findings establish a key regulatory function of the Greatwall kinase/Masetl->PP2A/B55 pathway in suppressing premature Stagsynthesis defects, mislocalization of MPS1 and Mad1 at the spinetochore. Furthermore, our findings reveal the necessity for sustained SpinDLE AssemblyCheckpoint Maintenance by inhibiting persistent spinDle Assembly CheckPoint Maintenance rather than defects in CSK1 activities.

title: In vivo zebrafish morphogenesis shows Cyp26b1 promotes tendon condensation and musculoskeletal patterning in the embryonic jaw
predicted summary: Integrating diverse tissues gives rise to a functional, mobile vertebrate musculoskeletal system. However, the genetics and interactions driving integration of muscle, tendon, and skeleton are poorly understood. Here we demonstrate that Cyp26b1 is critical for proper integration within the ventral pharyngeal arches, specifically in the mandibulohyoid junction where first and second arch muscles interconnect. Using time-lapse genetic mosaic analysis, we detail integration between first arch muscle attachment sites within wild-type fish and mutant vertebrafish using Timelapse Sequence Sequenzyme Sequential Analysis. We find CyP26B1 function is required to promote condensation of adjacent adjacent scxa-expressing cells during this time window that overlaps the dynamic window of tenoblast condensations during which neurons condense adjacent neighboring filamentous filamentates between adjacent filament filament condensation sites. Our results suggest that degradation by this previously undescribed population

title: Healthcare demand in response to rabies elimination campaigns in Latin America
predicted summary: Dog bite reports, dog bite reporting, and human post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) use have been shown to drive declines in human and canine rabies incidences across Latin American countries over the past decade. We estimate that 10% increase in dog vaccinations reduces human deaths by 12.4% overall, although both false negatives leading to death and false positives lead to costly unnecessary PEP prescriptions. Our findings highlight the importance of mass dog vaccine campaigns, increased awareness, treatment access and clinical algorithms to reduce cost-effectiveness and costs associated with animal vaccine-related outcomes such as Dog Rabies cases, reported human exposures, Human Post Exposure Prophylactic Therapy Use and Human Response Use.

title: Dysregulated Estrogen Receptor Signaling in the Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Ovarian Axis Leads to Ovarian Epithelial Tumorigenesis in Mice
predicted summary: Importantly, estrogen receptor alpha (ER) signaling in the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis leads to palpable epithelial tumorigenesis, abnormal cell proliferation, and elevated levels of estrogen hormones. Here we developed mutant mice, termed estrogend/d mouse model, in which abnormal estrogen regulation led to elevated estrogen production. This mutant model serves as useful experimental tool for studying the regulation pathways involved in estrogen-dependent gene expression pathways in this disease pathogenesis. We found that the loss of negative-feedback regulation by estrogen resulted in increased production of hormone production by luteinizing hormone produced by this tissue, producing high levels

title: Maternal care boosted by paternal imprinting in mammals
predicted summary: Mammalian mothers are the primary caregivers, programmed, in part, by hormones produced during pregnancy. High-quality maternal care is essential for the survival and lifelong health of offspring. We previously showed that the paternally silenced imprinted gene pleckstrin homology-like domain family A member 2 (Phlda2) functions to negatively regulate a single lineage in the mouse placenta called the spongiotrophoblast, which is important for maternal health during the evolution of mammals. Here, we show that wild-type mice exposed exposed in utero exposed to Offspring exposed with three different doses of the maternally expressed PhlDa2 gene showed changes in maternal hypothalamus and hippocampal regions involved for feeding and grooming of pups and increased focus on nest building behaviour, behaviour that was robustly maintained in absence of genetically modified dams exposed

title: Molecular recognition and packing frustration in a helical protein
predicted summary: Molecular recognition entails attractive forces for the functional native states and discrimination against potential nonnative interactions that favor alternate stable configurations is conceptualized as frustration. However, frustration is often minimal in evolved biological systems although native-centric possibilities are intuitively abundant. Here we make progress by studying the colicin immunity protein Im9. We compute free energies of association of various combinations of the four amino acids referred to as H1, H2, H3, and H4 by explicit-water molecular dynamics simulation simulations. Frustration is detected in H1-H2 packing by subtracting H3 and loop residues surrounding H4. We show that H1/H4 packing strongly favorably favoured nonNative packing orientations favored by H3/H4. Our results provide further insights into the physiological basis of minimal frustration during protein folding transition states.

title: Fine-scale variation in microclimate across an urban landscape shapes variation in mosquito population dynamics and the potential of Aedes albopictus to transmit arboviral disease
predicted summary: Aedes albopictus larvae were placed in artificial pots distributed across three replicate sites within three different land uses–urban, suburban, and rural–characterized by high proportions of impervious surfaces. We found mosquito microclimate variation significantly differed across the seasons as well as with land use, translating into decreased larval survival rates, smaller body sizes, lower vectorial capacity (VC), decreased body size and lower per capita growth rates of mosquitoes on urban sites translating to decreased mosquito survival. Our study explored the effects of fine-scale variation on mosquito life histories and vectorization potential.

title: The Smallest Capsid Protein Mediates Binding of the Essential Tegument Protein pp150 to Stabilize DNA-Containing Capsids in Human Cytomegalovirus
predicted summary: Among all human herpesviruses capsid contains genome-containing viral particles. However little is known about how SCP recruits SMP proteins to stabilize viral virion. Here, cryo electron microscopy reconstructs the structures of viral particle particles obtained from virally-infected cells. The structures show that Suppressor proteins recruit SSP proteins functionally binding proteins at the N-terminal half of SPP150. Inhibition of the inhibition abolished the formation of virus particles and reduced viral yield by 10,000fold. We further demonstrate that inhibition inhibiting STP proteins impairs viral formation by 100,000fold and reduce viral Yield significantly.

title: Simulating the Mammalian Blastocyst - Molecular and Mechanical Interactions Pattern the Embryo
predicted summary: Mammalian embryogenesis is dynamically driven by mechanical interactions between proliferating cells, which determine the lineage patterning of both the trophectoderm and endoderm tissues occurring at precise periods during the embryonic development. The precise nature of these interactions determines the Lineage Patterning involved in the development of tissues. Here we combine mechanical simulations with genetic networks within the context of animal-vegetal cells. We show that differential adhesion between different cell types is crucial for the formation of the Trophocyanid tissues, whereby gene expression is coupled with the mechanics of cell movement is important for both thermodynamically constrained by the zona pellucida. Our model provides the first attempt to combine cell-based spatiotemporal simulation frameworks coupled mechanical networks and Genetic networks together to explain mammal development dynamics. In this framework we provide the means to test hypotheses in vitro.

title: Molecular Epidemiology of A/H3N2 and A/H1N1 Influenza Virus during a Single Epidemic Season in the United States
predicted summary: To determine spatial dynamics of influenza A virus during a single epidemic season, we examined whole genome sequences of 284 influenza viruses collected across the continental United States during the 2006–2007 influenza season. Genome sequence sequence analysis revealed that multiple viral subtypes entered and co-circulated across regions far distant from major metropolitan areas during this season and exchanged genome segments through reassortment, producing both minor A/H3N2 viruses that appear to have acquired sensitivity to antiviral drugs as well as likely antigenically distinct influenza virus that became globally dominant following this Season. Our results reveal patterns of spatial spread that are far more complex than previously observed previously reported previously, suggesting both migration and migration influence spatial spatiotemporal dynamics in shaping epidemiological dynamics during influenza epidemic seasons.

title: An Essential Role for DYF-11/MIP-T3 in Assembling Functional Intraflagellar Transport Complexes
predicted summary: MIP-T3 is previously known to associate with microtubules and the neuronal protein Disrupted-in-Schizophrenia 1, but its function(s) remains unknown. Here we demonstrate that C. elegans mipt3 localizes to basal bodies and functions synergistically with the Bardet-Biedl syndrome protein Bbs4 to ensure proper gastrulation, a previously unknown but critical organelle-dependent developmental process critical to vertebrate development. Mutants lacking key components of the motor machinery, including Motor-II proteins, fail to enter Basal Body structures and/or mislocalize, leading to compromised structures, sensory functions, and abnormal lipid accumulation. Our findings provide insight into the evolutionarily conserved function

title: Intrinsic Epigenetic Regulation of the D4Z4 Macrosatellite Repeat in a Transgenic Mouse Model for FSHD
predicted summary: Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is progressive muscular dystrophies caused by decreased epigenetic repression of the D4Z4 macrosatellite repeats arrayed in the subtelomeric region of chromosome 4, associated with decreased expression of germline transcription factor DUX4, a retrogene encoded on each repeat, variegated expression variants observed in patients and controls, respectively. Here we generated transgenic mice carrying the same gene array arrays from mice with different genotypes. We recapitulate important epigenic features seen in Patients and Control mice, including high expression levels of genes expressed in mice as well as variably expressed genes found in mouse muscle nuclei as controls. Our mice recapitulated important functional gene groups in muscle cells that are characteristically similar to those expressed by mice–control mice. Furthermore, we show that increased expression differs markedly between mice from controls–Control mice both expressed differently than controls—specific variation between individuals.

title: A cyber-linked undergraduate research experience in computational biomolecular structure prediction and design
predicted summary: Computational biology research projects involve distributed teams of scientists located at geographically-distributed institutions. Introducing new training paradigms is one way to facilitate research progress in computational biology. Here, we describe a new undergraduate program in biomolecular structure prediction and design in which students conduct research at geographicly distributed labs while remaining connected through an online community. Students report outcomes comparable to students who participated in similar in-person programs. These outcomes include the development of sense of community and increases in their scientific self-efficacy, scientific identity, and science values, all predictors of continuing in research careers. Our results demonstrate the potential of this approach to broaden participation of young scientists from backgrounds traditionally underrepresented backgrounds.

title: Human β-D-3 Exacerbates MDA5 but Suppresses TLR3 Responses to the Viral Molecular Pattern Mimic Polyinosinic:Polycytidylic Acid
predicted summary: Increased copy number is associated with the development of autoimmune disease psoriasis which requires activation of the host defence mechanisms required for the initial trigger that leads to themplification stage. Using bone marrow cells from knockout mice, we show that infection with viral liposome mimic polyinosinic:polycytidylic acid suppresses transcriptional responses to polyI:C-induced viral infection. Inhibition of expression of transcription factor inhibitory genes abolished the expression and localisation of type I Interferon- by macrophage cells exposed to virally expressed genes. Here we demonstrate that the presence of copy copy Number Variant Complex 3 HBD3 peptide enhances cell responses mediated by the viral Liposomal response through MDA5 (IFIH1) and MAVS.

title: Glucose Phosphorylation Is Required for Mycobacterium tuberculosis Persistence in Mice
predicted summary: Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is thought to preferentially utilize carbohydrate metabolism to establish and maintain chronic infections. However, its metabolic network allows efficient co-catabolism of multiple carbon substrates for pathogenesis. To gain insight into the importance carbohydrates play a role during chronic infection, we evaluated glucose metabolism. We found that glycolysis allows glucose phosphorylation, the first reaction required for MtB metabolism, is dispensable for both growth and metabolism in mouse infections, suggesting that glucose is necessary for growth during Chronic infection. Our results demonstrate that both enzymes are capable of incorporating glucose into metabolic pathways involved in chronic Microbial pathogenicity. These results suggest that Mbacterial bacteria require glucose substrate substrate PPGK for normal growth while its second enzyme, GLKA, failed to survive normally in mice.

title: Influenza A Virus Migration and Persistence in North American Wild Birds
predicted summary: Wild birds have been implicated in the emergence of human influenza and livestock influenza outbreaks across North America. The successful prediction of viral spread and disease spread has been hampered by a critical lack of knowledge on viral movements between different host populations throughout the country. Here we analyze newly sequenced viral influenza A virus samples isolated over 34-year period of continuous systematic surveillance of North American wild bird flyways isolated during continuous surveillance surveillance. Our results provide vital insights to develop appropriately informed models critical for pandemic preparedness planning and Preparedness Plans Critical for livestock protection. We demonstrate that viral migration is independent of bird Flyways with migration between Bird Flyway flyway ranges.

title: Multi-Population Classical HLA Type Imputation
predicted summary: HLA genotyping has become established as a valuable tool for identifying and fine-mapping signals of disease association in case-control studies. Imputation into diverse populations has, however, remained challenging due to additional heterogeneity introduced by combining reference panels of different sources. Here we present an algorithm to build such models for the Hla region, accommodating genotype error errors and the need for maximum accuracy at loci and ethnicities where data available. We generalize the work of Browning (2007) and Ron et al. (1998). We present the probabilistic algorithm built to operate on multi-population Reference Panels.

title: T-cell derived acetylcholine aids host defenses during enteric bacterial infection with Citrobacter rodentium
predicted summary: The nervous system regulates host defense against enteric pathogens but immune responses are poorly understood. Here we report that ChAT+ T-cells recruited during infection with Citrobacter rodentium were recruited into intestinal epithelial cells during C. rodenteum infection. These cells did not exclusively belong to one Th subset and were able to produce the neurotransmitter acetylcholine released from these cells through conditional gene knockout approaches. Inhibition of protective effects was associated with increased expression of the pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1,IL-6, and TNF but without significant changes in host immune function during Enteroviral infections. Significantly increased colon burden was observed at 10 days post-infection in colon from Conditional Gene knockOut mice. This findings demonstrate that the protective effect released released by these T cells is important mediators that regulate host responses to enterobacterial infections

title: Frequency Response of a Protein to Local Conformational Perturbations
predicted summary: Protein Tyrosine Phosphatase 1B (PTP1B) is known to propagate long distances through proteins via backbone connectivity and nonbonded interactions. In this study, signal propagation from the flexible binding loop to the rest of proteins was investigated using frequency response techniques using Restrained Targeted Molecular Dynamics (TMD) potential on WPD and R loops at different frequency ranges. PTP1b was driven between its crystal structure conformations at higher frequencies than those obtained from crystal structures at lower frequencies and low enough low frequencies not to attenuate the propagating signal and enhance the contribution of the side chains involved in the dissipation of Signaling pathways. Our results provide insights into the role hydrophobic interactions and hydrophilic interactions may provide insight into signal transduction pathways of different proteins

title: SFPEL-LPI: Sequence-based feature projection ensemble learning for predicting LncRNA-protein interactions
predicted summary: LncRNA-protein interactions play important roles in post-transcriptional gene regulation, poly-adenylation, splicing and translational regulation. Identification of novel interactions helps understanding new interactions. Existing computational methods utilize multiple sequence-based features or multiple protein features to predict interactions but features are not available for all new proteins. In computational experiments, SFPEL-LPI accurately predicts interactions for novel proteins that don’t have known interactions, which are confirmed by literature. We construct a user-friendly web server, available at http://www.bioinfotech.cn/SFPELELPIP. Here, we propose novel feature projection ensemble learning method that predict novel interaction proteins (or proteins), which can be applied to new lNCRNAs.

title: Shifting Patterns of Aedes aegypti Fine Scale Spatial Clustering in Iquitos, Peru
predicted summary: Empiric evidence suggests that Aedes aegypti abundance is spatially heterogeneous and that some areas and larval habitats produce more mosquitoes than others. However, there is an understanding gap with regards to the temporal persistence of such abundance hotspots. In this study, we used longitudinal data collected from the city of Iquitos, Peru, to quantify spatial clustering patterns of adult mosquito abundance and pupa abundance over nine surveys spaced four months apart. We found clusters with significantly high vector abundance were common on every survey date but they were temporally unstable over the period of study. Our findings have implications implications for designing surveillance activities relying on household-level data sets and for the design of surveillance and control activities dependent upon household data.

title: Flow-Based Network Analysis of the Caenorhabditis elegans Connectome
predicted summary: Nematode C. elegans uses flow propagation on its neuronal network to reveal dynamically relevant features of its nervous system. We find flow-based groupings of neurons at different levels of granularity related to functionally relevant neurons and suggest potential candidates for further in vitro investigation. Here we exploit flow patterns motivated by biological input-response scenarios to identify flow profiles for neurons in the connectome without pre-imposing a priori categories.

title: Deep-learning-assisted diagnosis for knee magnetic resonance imaging: Development and retrospective validation of MRNet
predicted summary: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the knee is the preferred method for diagnosing knee injuries. However interpretation of knee imaging is time-intensive and subject to diagnostic error and variability. Deep learning methods are well suited for modeling the complex relationships between medical images and their interpretations. In this study we developed Deep Learning models for the detection of general abnormalities and specific diagnoses such as anterior cruciate ligament tears and meniscal tears on knee MRI exams performed at Stanford University Medical Center between January 1, 2001 and December 31, 2012. Our results support the assertion that deep learning algorithms can improve the performance of clinical experts during medical imaging interpretation.

title: Crystallography of a Lewis-Binding Norovirus, Elucidation of Strain-Specificity to the Polymorphic Human Histo-Blood Group Antigens
predicted summary: Noroviruses recognize the histo-blood group antigens (HBGAs) as host susceptible factors in strain-specific manner. In this study we determined the crystal structures of the binding interfaces between two genetically related Norwalk virus strains, the first Lewis-binding strain (VA207) and the predominant GII.4 strain Va387) that have distinct binding properties from those of both norwalk viruses and VA387 that target at the secretory epitope as major binding sites. Our results provide insight into the complex interactions between the two Genetically Related Norway viruses as well as the Polymorphic counterparts and highlight the role of human strainspecificity as a critical factor in noravian evolution.

title: Identification and Manipulation of the Molecular Determinants Influencing Poliovirus Recombination
predicted summary: Genomic variability within viral genomes is thought to influence viral replication patterns across regions of the genome. However, understanding the genetic properties of viral genetic variation is lacking. Here we utilize gene synthesis and deep sequencing to create a detailed map of genome homologous recombination maps within the poliovirus 1 coding region. We show the majority of breakpoints associated with known or predicted secondary structures are concentrated in small number of specific “hotspots” located within known primary structures. Our results suggest genetically stable live vaccine strains with altered phenotypes could be utilized for whole genome redesigns for the development of vaccine-resistant live viruses capable of attenuated vaccines. This map provides insight into the evolutionarily conserved RNA viruses.

title: Natural Selection Promotes Antigenic Evolvability
predicted summary: Many pathogens utilize similar strategies to establish chronic infections such as Lyme disease, Borrelia burgdorferi strains which utilize both classical genetic sequences and Bayesian population genetic analyses to test whether natural selection favors amino acid diversity among genetically conserved cassettes that promote long-term antigenicity. This hypothesis was supported by the conservation of highly repeatable tandem-repeat structures across each strain studied. Our results provide direct evidence that evolutionary adaptations promoted antiviral antigen VlsE promotes Long-Term Antigenic Variability (VlvE), which provides an experimentally tractable model for the evolutionary evolution of antibiotic antibiotics. These results support the hypothesis that evolution favours protein diversity between amino acids as well as amino Acid diversity favored by natural Selection.

title: The Triggering Receptor Expressed on Myeloid Cells 2 Inhibits Complement Component 1q Effector Mechanisms and Exerts Detrimental Effects during Pneumococcal Pneumonia
predicted summary: Triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells (TREM)-2 was proposed to negatively regulate TLR responses and enhance inflammation by macrophages during pneumococcal pneumonia, but the role of TREM-2 in respiratory tract infections is unknown. Here, we established the presence of trigger receptor Expression Marker-2 on Alveolar Macrophagocytes (AM) and explored its role in the immune response to respiratory pneumonia. Upon infection with S. pneumoniae Trem-2 mice displayed elevated complement component 1q levels in vitro and in vivo compared to their WT counterparts. This work is the first to disclose a previously unknown link between TreM-2activated receptor activity and opsonin production within the lungs. We show here that these increased complement components depended on Peroxisome proliferator receptor activation activity.

title: Dynamics of Th17 Cells and Their Role in Schistosoma japonicum Infection in C57BL/6 Mice
predicted summary: Schistosoma japonicum is a major tropical helminthic disease caused by parasitic parasites known to induce protective immune responses early in host infection. However, little is known about the dynamics of Th17 cells, another important CD4+ T cell subset that controls host protective responses against S. japonica infection in vitro. Here, we show that these cells were recruited along with Th1, Th2, Treg cells and their respective suppressive factors Promoted by Sylvesteridium japanensis early during infection and that decreased levels resulted in protective antibody levels and partial protection against infection early earlier in infection at different stages of infection stages. Furthermore, decreasing levels with neutralizing anti-IL-17 monoclonal antibody enhanced protective antibodies and partially protected host Immunopathological responses. This study provides important insights into host defense mechanisms that may aid in development of interventions to protect hosts from infection or Restrain immunopathology

title: SREB, a GATA Transcription Factor That Directs Disparate Fates in Blastomyces dermatitidis Including Morphogenesis and Siderophore Biosynthesis
predicted summary: Blastomyces dermatitidis belongs to a group of human pathogenic pathogens that exhibit thermal dimorphism at 22°C. The ability to switch between these forms is essential for survival in mammals and may enable these organisms to survive in soil environments. Here we identify genes that regulate this transition: phase transition from yeast to mold, cell growth at 22, and biosynthesis of siderophores under iron-replete conditions. We found that the transcription factor SREB regulates multiple fates in B. candidibacteria strains by altering gene expression defects independent of exogenous iron concentrations, suggesting that GATA functions as transcription Factor Regulation Regulation Promotes Phase Transition Regulation.

title: Sumoylation Influences DNA Break Repair Partly by Increasing the Solubility of a Conserved End Resection Protein
predicted summary: Here, we show that sumoylation regulates double-strand break repair partly by altering the end-resection factor Sae2. This modification is conserved from yeast to humans, and is involved in the processing and repair of multiple types of DNA breaks. How different modifications collaborate with each other is important questions to be answered. Here we map SumoYlation site of End Resection Factor 2 to a single lysine in its self-association domain and show collaboration between different modification sites leads to stronger regulatory effects. We also provide evidence that the two modifications act independently independently of their binding site to increase the amount of soluble forms of end repair proteins by increasing their ability to repair multiple kinds of Double Strand Break Repairs.

title: Early Severe Inflammatory Responses to Uropathogenic E. coli Predispose to Chronic and Recurrent Urinary Tract Infection
predicted summary: Chronic infections are an increasing problem due to the increase in antibiotic resistant organisms. Understanding host host interactions that result in chronic infection is of great importance. Here, we investigate the molecular basis of chronic cystitis. We establish that introduction of uropathogenic E.coli (UPEC) into the bladders of C3H mice results in resolution of acute infection or development of severe disease lasting months. Development of Chronic Cystitis is preceded by biomarkers of local and systemic acute inflammation at 24 hours post-infection, including severe bladder inflammation with mucosal injury. Furthermore, individuals with histories lasting at least 14 days are significantly more susceptible to developing severe Cystis upon infection upon exposure to antibiotic antibiotic challenge than individuals without these responses. This study has implications implications for understanding how host-pathogen interactions determine disease outcomes early in infection.

title: Macroscopic phase resetting-curves determine oscillatory coherence and signal transfer in inter-coupled neural circuits
predicted summary: Macroscopic oscillations of different brain regions have been implicated in routing information across timescales. However, it remains unclear how synaptic coupling determines the structure of these firing patterns. In this paper we describe the evolutionarily observed diversity of phase-locking patterns within bidirectionally delayed-coupled pyramidal-interneuronal oscillatory circuits, which arise from the interaction between neurons involved in the firing pathways. Here we identify the mechanism responsible for the formation of Phase Locking Mechanisms within both the interneuronal (ING) and Pyramidal networks. We show that Cylindrical Coherence states can lead to both Phase Advances and Phase Failures which leads to Phase Breaking. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms involved involved mechanisms that regulate the timing of the signal transfer between the two networks which determine the pathways involved.

title: Population Genomic Scan for Candidate Signatures of Balancing Selection to Guide Antigen Characterization in Malaria Parasites
predicted summary: Plasmodium falciparum malaria parasites carry polymorphisms in host tissues, leading to identification signatures of polychromosity-balancing selection targets. These identified targets are now prioritized for functional studies. In this study, we provide high-quality genome-wide sequence sequencing data for 65 malaria isolates grown to polymerozoite-containing stages that invade erythrocytes. Our data provide evidence for the presence of Polymorphic Antigen PF10_0355 among those isolated from Gambian malaria strains, including those belonging to PfMC-2TM, surfin, Surfin-like gene families.

title: Global Patterns of Protein Domain Gain and Loss in Superkingdoms
predicted summary: Domains are modules within proteins that fold independently and function independently during evolutionary timescales. Domain families are proteins comprised of proteins capable of folding and folding independently. Both gains and losses occurred frequently during proteome evolution. We found that both Gains and Losses of domains occurred regularly during the course of Evolutionary Time. Gain-to-loss ratios were much higher in Archaea than in Eukaryotes during evolutionary time compared to Bacteria. This suggests that domain gains may redefine the persistence strategies of organisms in superkingdoms, influence the make up of molecular functions and enhance organismal complexity by the generation of new domain architecture architectures across species. Our analysis provides useful insights into the evolutionarily conserved evolution of species and provides valuable insight into species evolution strategies for species conservation.

title: The Effect of Hygiene-Based Lymphedema Management in Lymphatic Filariasis-Endemic Areas: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
predicted summary: Lymphatic filariasis is associated with significant morbidity and disability in areas where hygiene-based lymphedema management has been shown to significantly reduce clinical manifestations of the parasitic filarial parasite Elephantia, known as elephantiaceae. Inclusion criteria included high heterogeneity across studies and variability across components of hygiene management. We conducted Random Effects meta-analyses to estimate the efficacy of Hygiene-Based Management Strategies on LF-related lymphemia. Our results highlight the potential to Significantly reduce the prevalence of acute lymphagioadenitis (ADLA), as well as the number of patients reporting at least one episode of ADLA during follow-up Follow-Up.
