title: Impact of a national deworming campaign on the prevalence of soil-transmitted helminthiasis in Uganda (2004-2016): Implications for national control programs
predicted summary: Soil transmitted Helminth infections can retard cognitive and physical growth in school-age children with great implications for national control programs in Africa. A cross sectional study was undertaken to assess impact of STH interventions on prevalence and intensity of soil transmitted infections among school children in Uganda. Stool samples were taken from 50 children aged 6–14 years and examined for presence of waterborne parasites. Results showed that prevalence of infection has been significantly reduced to levels where it is no longer of public health importance in most districts surveyed. These results suggest that regular evaluations are vital for monitoring effectiveness of interventions and guide programme implementation. Our results show that most children were aware of how one gets infected with soil transmissible organisms through eating contaminated food, drinking dirty water and playing in dirty places.

title: Comparing Bayesian and non-Bayesian accounts of human confidence reports
predicted summary: Bayesian confidence reporting requires subjects to take sensory uncertainty into account in a specific way. However, this hypothesis has not been rigorously tested against non-Bayessian alternatives. We found that subjects who report confidence can access low-level representations of uncertainty, which is not fully consistent with Baysian hypothesis. Our results suggest that adhering to rational account of confidence behavior may require implementational constraints. Both conclusions are robust to changes in the uncertainty manipulation, task, response modality, model comparison metric, and additional flexibility in uncertainty models. These results provide insight into the complexity and complexity involved in reporting confidence behaviors.

title: The Many Landscapes of Recombination in Drosophila melanogaster
predicted summary: Recombination is a fundamental biological process with profound evolutionary implications due to the lack of detailed description of genomic variation across genomes and among individuals. Here we report the first integrated high-resolution description that distinguishes between crossing over (CO) rates and gene conversion rates between individuals of Drosophila melanogaster. We show extensive intraspecific variation in crossing rates that is associated with hotspots at low frequency in our sample, suggesting that double-strand breaks favor double breaks. Furthermore, Crossover rates are more uniformly distributed across the genome than Crossing Over rates, which suggests that crossing Over Rates are highly punctuated along chromosomes along transcript regions that tend to occur within transcription regions. These results provide insights into the interaction between selection and linkage.

title: Variant Exported Blood-Stage Proteins Encoded by Plasmodium Multigene Families Are Expressed in Liver Stages Where They Are Exported into the Parasitophorous Vacuole
predicted summary: Many variant proteins encoded by Plasmodium falciparum-specific multigene families are exported onto the surface of red blood cells (RBC) and mediate interactions between host cells and host tissues resulting in tissue sequestration and rosetting. However, the precise function of most other exported variant protein families is unknown. Here, we analysed the expression and location by fluorescent-tagging of member proteins belonging to the var, stevor and rifin families of rodent malaria parasites (RMP). We found that several family members transported proteins into the plasma membranes of the parasitophorous vacuole, suggesting that both families have distinct histories unique functions unique to RMP. Importantly, most proteins transported into membrane membrane sites during the liver stage but not onto Plasma membrane. This suggests that these proteins may contribute to host host responses by manipulating host immune responses.

title: Comparative Genomic Characterization of Francisella tularensis Strains Belonging to Low and High Virulence Subspecies
predicted summary: Here we report the sequencing of five strains belonging to the Francisella subspecies mediasiatica FSC147 strain from the Central Asian Region and comparative genomic analysis with previously available public sequences. We find evidence for large-scale rearrangement events proximal to previously predicted breakpoints in F. tularensis pathogenicity islands. Our findings support previous proposals that further evolutionary subdivisions of the Type B clade are likely likely to occur. Previous studies suggest that evolutionarily distinct evolutionary events that differed these species from their common evolutionary ancestor that differentiated them from each other. Furthermore, we also find significant enrichment of genomic sequence similarity to genes associated with Regulation-modification defense systems.

title: HIV-1 Transmitting Couples Have Similar Viral Load Set-Points in Rakai, Uganda
predicted summary: HIV-1 viral load set-point is a surrogate measure of viral transmission. It has been hypothesized viral loads are subject to natural selection in the human host population. We retrospectively identified 112 heterosexual HIV-discordant couples with strong genetic support for HIV transmission in Rakai, Uganda. Individuals with suspected intracouple transmission (97 couples) had similar viral loading setpoints which explained 16% variance between HIV loads (23% adjusted). We assessed the proportion of variance explained by the similarity within couples (the Couple effect). This finding sheds light on viral factors involved in HIV pathogenesis and evolution of HIV viruses. Our results shed light both insights into viral mechanisms involved with HIV Pathogenicity and Evolution.

title: Association of a Functional Variant in the Wnt Co-Receptor LRP6 with Early Onset Ileal Crohn's Disease
predicted summary: Ileal Crohn's Disease (CD) is characterized by reduced levels of the antimicrobial proteins DEFA5 and HD-6 exclusively produced in Paneth cells (PCs) at small intestinal mucosal bases independently independently from the genotypes Carriers carry variants associated with early onset ileal CD. Here we identified low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 6 (LRP6) as a novel candidate gene involved in both early and early early stages of inflammation. LRP6 activity was significantly impaired independently independent from genotypic carriers carrying the variant. We found Low Density Lipogenic Protein 6 activity decreased significantly independently Independently independently of genotyping individual carriers who carried variant variant carrying variant–carrying variant carriers. Our findings suggest that the presence of Low density Lipopeptide receptor–related Protein6 has been implicated downstream downstream targets for novel therapeutic targets targeted targeting targeting targeted targets targeting specific targets.

title: Cucumber mosaic virus coat protein modulates the accumulation of 2b protein and antiviral silencing that causes symptom recovery in planta
predicted summary: Cucumber mosaic virus (CMVWT) invades the Shoot Apical Meristems (SAMs) transiently, but was eliminated from newly emerging leaves of newly infected plants. Here, we found that wild-type CMV WT persistently invaded the SAM, which resulted in visible reductions in the presence of severe symptoms with minimal antiviral silencing effects. Our findings suggest that the coat protein acts as a central hub mediating viral self-attenuation and long-term virus recovery mechanisms. Inhibition of posttranscriptional gene-SIMULATORY RNA-binding proteins is maintained by viral suppressors of viral suppression complexes mediated by these proteins. We further demonstrated that reduced accumulation of the 2b protein may serve as templates for viral replication inhibition and subsequent viral recovery into punctate Granulates.

title: P-loop Conformation Governed Crizotinib Resistance in G2032R-Mutated ROS1 Tyrosine Kinase: Clues from Free Energy Landscape
predicted summary: Tyrosine kinases are excellent targets for chemical drug therapy of carcinomas. However, under strong purifying selection drug resistance often occurs within the cancer cells within a very short therapeutic term. Drug resistance has been found to be associated with secondary mutations located at solvent front, which lead to the attenuated drug binding affinity. Recently, G2032R mutation was detected in the drug target, ROS1 complex from crizotinib-resistant patient who responded poorly to crizotic drugs within Short TherapyTerm. Using advanced molecular dynamics techniques, it was discovered that the more rigid P-loop region was responsible for the resistance. In this study, we show that phosphate-binding loop conformational change of the Drug Target-ROS complex was involved in both the bonding affinity and drug residence time involved by the flattened free energy surface. Furthermore, our simulation simulations revealed that this region played important roles in drug-target interactions induced by flattening Free Energy surfaces.

title: A Taxonomy of Bacterial Microcompartment Loci Constructed by a Novel Scoring Method
predicted summary: Bacterial microcompartments (BMCs) are proteinsaceous organelles involved in both autotrophic metabolism and heterotrophy metabolism. BMC loci encode genes adjacent to shell proteins but differ in their complement of enzymes; these are typically encoded adjacently adjacent carboxysome genes flanking their shell protein counterparts. This taxonomy provides a framework for understanding the horizontal transfer of these gene clusters and provides guidance for design of genetic modules for studying Bacteriophages in bioengineering applications. By placing these results in phylogenetic context, we identify 23 different types of Bactobacteria found in 23 candidate Candidatogenic Bacteries that share the same catalytic core and divergent set of carboxisome components. Our results provide insights into the evolutionary evolution and evolutionary evolution of Candidates involved with Bactridiumbacterium metabolism, providing the starting point for studies aimed at understanding Bacteropathobiology.

title: Co-occurring protein phosphorylation are functionally associated
predicted summary: Post-translational modifications (PTMs) add complexity to the proteome and regulate a wide range of biological processes across vertebrates. PTM modifications are structurally conserved together (co-occurrence). Co-occurring phosphorylation occurs significantly more frequently than randomly expected and includes many known examples of cross-talk or functional connections. We applied this analytical strategy to human protein sequence data collected under 88 different laboratory conditions. Comparison with existing methods further suggests that cooccurrence analysis can be useful complement to uncover novel functional interactions between PIM sites by testing their tendency to be modified together together under the same conditions under different conditions and applying it to mouse proteomics datasets. Together, our results support the hypothesis that these interactions are functionally associated. Our results provide new insights into the functional implications of post-transcriptional modification sites as well as their ability to coexist independently.

title: Digital Signal Processing Reveals Circadian Baseline Oscillation in Majority of Mammalian Genes
predicted summary: Statistical analyses of periodicity are limited by the small size of datasets and high levels stochastic noise levels. Here, we propose a new approach applying digital signal processing algorithms separately to each group of genes oscillating in the same phase independently. We identify circadian baseline oscillation in almost 100% of all expressed genes. Combined with the statistical analyses, this method identifies baseline periodicities in most genes expressed during the daytime period. The results show that changes in gene expression caused by mutations or regulation of environmental factors (such as feeding) should be considered in any study related to biological pathways Related toBiological pathways.

title: Re-wiring of energy metabolism promotes viability during hyperreplication stress in E. coli
predicted summary: Chromosome replication is initiated by DnaATP which is essential for formation of ATP nucleoprotein complexes which promote cell death by accumulation of DNA breaks leading to uncontrolled overinitiation of replication. Mutations that suppress RIDA deficiency either dampen Overinitiation or permit growth. We characterize mutations of the last group that have in common that distinct metabolic routes are rewired resulting in the redirection of electron flow towards the metabolic pathways directed towards mitochondrial electron flux pathways which decrease the formation reactive oxygen species and consequently oxidative damage to the DNA in general. Here we propose a model where mutation mutation mutant mutant mutation Mutation mutation abolished Reactive Oxygen Transport Transport pathways that increase the processivity of Replication forks generated by overoverinitiation to maintain viability.

title: Dual microRNA Screens Reveal That the Immune-Responsive miR-181 Promotes Henipavirus Entry and Cell-Cell Fusion
predicted summary: Hendra viruses (family Paramyxoviridae) are bat-borne viruses that cause fatal disease in humans and other mammalian species. Understanding host pathways exploited by henipaviruses for infection may identify targets for new antiviral therapies. Here we performed genome-wide high-throughput screenings at biosafety level 4 to identify host-encoded microRNAs impacting infection by the parasitically significant mononegavirusHendra virus. Immune-responsive miR-181 expression levels were also upregulated in the biofluids of ferrets and horses infected with this parasitium. Our results suggest that inhibition of several Eph receptors contributes to enhanced infection and enhanced disease severity, suggesting that the host immune response may promote host infection.

title: Detection of Crimean-Congo Haemorrhagic Fever cases in a severe undifferentiated febrile illness outbreak in the Federal Republic of Sudan: A retrospective epidemiological and diagnostic cohort study
predicted summary: Undifferentiated febrile illness (UFI) is one of the most common reasons for people seeking healthcare in low-income countries. However, many high consequence infectious diseases, including Ebola virus, are frequently poorly-quantified and their impact underappreciated. Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) represents an important cause of fever in Darfur but not the sole major source of UFI outbreaks in Sudan. We report retrospective cohort study of 2015/2016 outbreak samples received by Public Health England Rare and Imported Pathogens Laboratory samples obtained at the National Public health Laboratory collected samples collected by public health laboratory sample volumes and epidemiological features including fever (95.8%), bleeding, headache (51.6%) and headache (42.2%) Clinical features included fever (95.2%) clinical features indicative of person-to-person transmission or health worker cases. This study reinforces the need to boost surveillance capacity, laboratory capacity and investigative capacity to underpin effective response, and for local and international health security.

title: The sero-epidemiology of Rift Valley fever in people in the Lake Victoria Basin of western Kenya
predicted summary: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is zoonotic arbovirus affecting livestock and people in western Kenya where RVFV outbreaks have not previously been reported. This study investigated RVV seropositivity between community members and slaughterhouse workers who are considered high-risk groups. The results show that slaughtering animals is significantly associated with RV fever infection. These risk factors have been previously previously reported in other studies providing further evidence for RVRV circulation in Western Kenya. We investigated whether slaughtered animals represent a Risk Factors Significantly associated to RVPV infection in the community. Using Structured questionnaire tools, we assessed the Seroprevalence and Risk factors involved in RVVFVI infection among individuals recruited from randomly selected homesteads. Serum samples were found to be associated significantly significantly correlated between slaughtermanship meat meat products and ruminant slaughter house workers. Participants were recruited to slaughter cattle at slaughter houses who were considered High Risk Groups

title: Pyrethroid Resistance Reduces the Efficacy of Space Sprays for Dengue Control on the Island of Martinique (Caribbean)
predicted summary: Dengue fever is reemerging on the island of Martinique, where mosquito vector control programs are facing operational challenges with the development of highly resistant mosquito populations resistant to deltamethrin space sprays. Efficacy was assessed by monitoring mortality rates of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes placed in sentinel cages before, during and after spraying, larval and adult mosquito population densities were estimated. This study emphasizes the need for alternative tools and strategies for dengue vector Control Programs to reduce vector transmission.

title: Vitamin D status contributes to the antimicrobial activity of macrophages against Mycobacterium leprae
predicted summary: Macrophages of the immune system serve distinct functions in vitro. However, how vitamin D status affects primary human monocyte differentiation is unknown. Here, we show that the presence of Vitamin D during differentiation enhances the ability to mount vitaminD-dependent antimicrobial responses against intracellular Mycobacterium leprae infection but does not alter function or function of these M subsets. Our data suggest vitamin status alters vitamin response response against Intrinsic Bacillus enteritivirus infection. We found that vitamin Status during the differentiation of Primary Human Monocytes into primary Human macrophage differentiation increased the expression of cathelicidin, including both CAMP mRNA and the encoded proteins involved in the vitamin pathway during maturation of primary MY cells into Primary My cells.

title: A Putative Small Solute Transporter Is Responsible for the Secretion of G377 and TRAP-Containing Secretory Vesicles during Plasmodium Gamete Egress and Sporozoite Motility
predicted summary: Plasmodium berghei PAT regulates exocytosis of highly specialised secretory vesicles during malaria parasite life cycle progression and transmission between mammalian host and mosquito vector. Regulation of proteins from the pantothenate transporter PantoTHENATE Transporter is essential for gamete motility and malaria transmission. Here we identify conserved roles for the membrane component PATA in two distinct classes of gametes and parasitophorous vacuole membranes located on the surface of Gametocytes and Micronemes in Sporozoites. PATT is required for regulation of the establishment and movement of membrane proteins to the cell surface upon activation rather than acting as panthenic transporters during parasitistic malaria Transmission between the host host rodent host hosts to malaria vector vectors.

title: Environmental Mapping of Paracoccidioides spp. in Brazil Reveals New Clues into Genetic Diversity, Biogeography and Wild Host Association
predicted summary: Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and P. lutzii are easily isolated from human patients due to human migration and long latency period. However, clinical isolates do not reflect the spatial distribution of these pathogens, and their isolation from wild animals such as armadillos is important for monitoring their environmental distribution. This study used Nested Genetic Sequencing and In situ Hybridization techniques to identify genetic variants present in soils and aerosol samples that have never been detected previously in either clinical or non-endemic areas of the environment, suggesting greater genetic variability in the Environment than in vertebrate hosts. Sequences from both species were detected from soil samples collected in regions with high prevalence of PCM infection by Pseudomycosomal parasites (PCM). Sequential sequences obtained from Aerosol Samples were detectable either from the soil Sample Sample sample collected from either soil/Aerosol sample samples, as well as aerial samples taken from seven wild animal burrows evaluated in areas with High prevalence/High prevalence

title: Computational geometry for modeling neural populations: From visualization to simulation
predicted summary: Neural networks are highly dynamical processes that are not available in 1D systems. Here we present a method for simulating neuron populations based on two dimensional (2D) point spiking neurons models that replicates results obtained in the diffusion limit and generalizes them to regimes of large jumps. Our method is highly modular: variations of the dynamics and stochastic processes can be investigated independently without even recompiling the code. We show here that our method ideally suited to investigate noise in such systems, replicating Results obtained obtained by simulations carried out in both diffusion limits and limit cycles. Moreover, we show that noise is important complementary to noise experimental models. This suggests that the study of neurons subjected to Noise is useful complementary complementary

title: Crovirin, a Snake Venom Cysteine-Rich Secretory Protein (CRISP) with Promising Activity against Trypanosomes and Leishmania
predicted summary: The neglected neglected human diseases caused by trypanosoma cruzi are currently treated with toxic therapy with limited efficacy. Here, we describe the purification of CRISP proteins from Cvv snake venom with promising anti-trypanotic activity against human trypomastigotes including intracellular tryptosome forms. We purified cysteine-rich secretory proteins which could be used as drugs or drugs leads for the development of novel drugs against neglected diseases. Our results suggest that other members of this family might have potential as drug leads or Drug Leads for drug development.

title: Viral Replication Protein Inhibits Cellular Cofilin Actin Depolymerization Factor to Regulate the Actin Network and Promote Viral Replicase Assembly
predicted summary: Tomato bushy stunt virus (TBSV) targets host cells by co-opting host proteins/lipids and escape host antiviral responses. Previous genome-wide screens have identified 18 genes that are part of the actin network, which are central nodes in viral pathways. In this paper, we show that Act1p interacts directly with Actin filament proteins to block the formation of new filamentous filament filaments around ActIN filament hub hubs in infected plant cells. Using temperature sensitive mutants at semi-permissive temperatures we find increased levels of Act1/Act1P activity of tombusvirus replicase activity and increased Activity of RNA accumulation in yeast cells and elevated Activity in Act1. Our results provide insight into the mechanisms by which viruses could gain supremacy in subversion

title: Stable, Precise, and Reproducible Patterning of Bicoid and Hunchback Molecules in the Early Drosophila Embryo
predicted summary: Mutations in protein molecules and their precise reading out are of critical importance in embryonic development. Here we develop stochastic models of the early Drosophila embryo. We show that the dynamical structure change is suppressed by the random arrival of Bicoid molecules at the promoters of Hunchback proteins, which gives rise to the precise patterning of distributions with small fluctuations in each embryo-to-embryo fluctuation without loss sharpness of sharp edges of boundary boundary boundaries. Inhibition of fluctuations arising from dynamic structural structure changes contributes to stability and reproducibility through noiseful dynamics involved in the development of embryogenesis.

title: Nitazoxanide Stimulates Autophagy and Inhibits mTORC1 Signaling and Intracellular Proliferation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis
predicted summary: Tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculase infection and causes morbidity and mortality in the world today. It hijacks the catabolic trafficking pathway to escape clearance from infected macrophages. Here we report that the antiprotozoal drug nitazoxanide strongly stimulates autophagy and inhibits signaling by its active metabolite NQO1, a major negative regulator of Autophagosome activity. We identify human quinone Oxoxidoreductases NqO1 as targets and propose, based on experiments with peripheral monocytes and human cells, that this inhibition may lead to improved treatment.

title: Trends of Mycobacterium bovis Isolation and First-Line Anti-tuberculosis Drug Susceptibility Profile: A Fifteen-Year Laboratory-Based Surveillance
predicted summary: Mycobacterium tuberculosis causes the majority of Tuberous Tuberosis (TB) cases in humans; however, human cases caused by M. bovis may be frequent but undetected. We report high prevalence and rising trend of M isolates from human clinical samples and first-line drug susceptibility rates during a 15-year period in tertiary care hospital located in Mexico City during the period 2000–2014. Primary antibiotic resistance rates were higher among both strains and Secondary antibiotic Resistance Rates were 38.5% and 34.4% for both species, respectively. Our data shows high rates of primary anti-tuberculotic resistance and secondary MDR rates in both Microbial straines. In addition, the number of firstline drugs: streptomycin, isoniazid and ethambutol was significantly higher than previously reported in previous reports. Furthermore, Micillin resistance Rate significantly increased from 7.8% in 2000 to 14.6% in 2014. Previous reports showed high rate of Primary Antibiotic Resistance rates among M

title: Genomic Variation and Its Impact on Gene Expression in Drosophila melanogaster
predicted summary: Understanding the relationship between genetic variation and gene expression variation is one of the great outstanding challenges in biology. To meet this challenge comprehensive genomic variation maps of human as well as model organism populations are required. Here we present a comprehensive catalog of single-nucleotide genomic variants in 39 Drosophila melanogaster Genetic Reference Panel inbred lines. We map quantitative quantitative trait loci (cis-eQTLs) for more than 800,000 genes and found that the majority of high SNP density regions are not mutation-prone regions, suggesting that regions with high genetic variant density are Not Mutagenic regions. Our data provide insights into the regulatory architecture of gene Expression variation in adult flies by mapping quantitative traits for over 2,000 genes across the genomes. These maps reveal the importance of genetic factors in mediating genetic architecture between the sexes and the role genomic factors play in regulation.

title: Gene-environment interaction study for BMI reveals interactions between genetic factors and physical activity, alcohol consumption and socioeconomic status
predicted summary: Previous genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified hundreds of genetic loci associated with body mass index (BMI) and risk of obesity. Genetic effects vary depending on lifestyle factors such as smoking habits, physical activity, socioeconomic status, mental health, sleeping patterns, smoking frequency and Townsend deprivation index. In this study we examined gene-environment interactions among 362,496 individuals with Caucasian ancestry from the UK Biobank resource to characterise genetic effects of gene interactions on BMI for Lifestyle Factors related to Body Mass Index and Risk of Obesity. Our analyses indicate that many lifestyle variables modify the Genetic Effects on body Mass index by altering gene effects depending upon lifestyle traits and environmental factors. However, some groups of individuals had more than double the effect of the genetic score after omitting the FTO locus from genetic scores. Linear regression modeling was used to construct weighted Genetic Scores for BodyMass Index based on cross-sectional data alone and controlled experiments are required to fully characterises the causal mechanisms

title: A Hidden Markov Model for Single Particle Tracks Quantifies Dynamic Interactions between LFA-1 and the Actin Cytoskeleton
predicted summary: Complex interactions within complex systems are the result of multiple phenomena, and new methods for uncovering changes in molecular processes are needed. We have developed a two-state hidden Markov model capable of extracting hidden information from complex perturbations within experimental systems, which can be used to identify the key biophysical parameters for such systems such as diffusion coefficients and rates of transition between these states. Using simulations of single particle tracks of lymphocyte function-associated antigen-1 proteins on live T cells, we show that particle Tracks can reveal multiple states of diffusion within experiments. Our analysis reveals that the diffusion of LFA-1 is indeed approximately two states within single-particle tracks upon activation of LiveT cells upon activated cells-activated cells.

title: Sequence features of viral and human Internal Ribosome Entry Sites predictive of their activity
predicted summary: Translation of genes through Internal Ribosome Entry Sites (IRESs) has emerged as a prominent mechanism of viral translation, supporting Cap-dependent translation of select genes under normal conditions and in conditions where Cap dependent translation is inhibited. However, due to the small number of IRESs known, there has been little systematic investigation of the sequence dynamics involved in this process. Here we present the first systematic computational analysis of large body of retroviral retrovirus genomes, exploring sequence features predictive of transcriptional activity dependent on their sequence number, number and position. We found predictive features resembling sequence binding features across human and viral Retroviruses differ from that of other viruses, suggesting that their architecture differs from those exposed to nuclear environments. Our results also suggest RetroViral Retrovirals differ in architecture depending upon their exposure to Nuclear Environments.

title: Gene Expression Switching of Receptor Subunits in Human Brain Development
predicted summary: Synaptic receptors regulate plasticity and information processing by switching from one protein variant to another across brain regions and developmental stages. This phenomenon has been demonstrated in several neurotransmitter systems including NMDA and GABA. Here we present methods to quantify age-corrected expression correlations across postmortem data collected in donors at various ages and Brain Regions measured using microarray and RNA-seq methods. We find multiple new pairs of receptor-subunit variants that switch during the lifetime of the human brain that differ from the known known switch observed in rodents. Our results provide a systematic map map of developmental switching occurring during developmental developmental transitions in the nervous system including neuroprotective mechanisms such as the regulation of neuroplasticity during development.

title: Development and Assessment of a Geographic Knowledge-Based Model for Mapping Suitable Areas for Rift Valley Fever Transmission in Eastern Africa
predicted summary: Rift Valley fever (RVF) is one of the most important viral pathogens in East Africa. RVF is transmitted by mosquitoes and affects livestock in livestock outbreaks reported in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and Ethiopia between 1998 and 2012. The purpose of this study was to develop a geographic information system-based multicriteria evaluation method to synthesize available scientific knowledge and assess the predictive accuracy of RVV suitability maps. Our results confirm the capacity of Geographic Information System-Based Multicriterion Evaluation Method to Synthesize Available Scientific Knowledge and provide users with easy updating maps according to data availability or the further development of scientific Knowledge. This approach provides Users with straightforward update maps based on RVVF outbreak locations reported from cattle outbreak data from Kenya and Tanzania from 1998–2012. The results demonstrate the ability of Genetic Knowledge Based Multi Criteria Evaluation method (GIMES) model provides user-friendly and easy update Maps depending on available information available or further Development

title: The Molecular Clock of Neutral Evolution Can Be Accelerated or Slowed by Asymmetric Spatial Structure
predicted summary: Population genetics asserts that the rate at which mutations accumulate accumulate coincides with mutation rate: K = u. Here we show that spatial structure can alter the molecular clock rate for Neutral Mutations, leading to either Ku or K>u depending on where they arise. Our results apply to general classes of spatially structured Population Structures. We show here that population structure alters the timing rate of mutation accumulation depending upon whether mutation arises unequally at different sites and have different probabilities of fixation dependent upon where mutation occurs. Furthermore, our results can be applied to haploid populations with a general class of genetically structured populations.

title: Autogenous Translational Regulation of the Borna Disease Virus Negative Control Factor X from Polycistronic mRNA Using Host RNA Helicases
predicted summary: Borna disease virus encodes at least three open reading frames (ORFs): upstream ORF-termination-coupled translation and downstream polycistronic translation. However, the translation mechanism used by the PolyCISTRonic Regulation Protein has not been determined in detail. Here we demonstrate that PolycISTRNA regulates translational regulation via interaction with host regulatory proteins involved in viral polymerization via interactions between host proteins. Our results provide insights into the regulation mechanisms employed by polyCistRNA regulation using viral regulators. We also show that P interacts directly with the 5′ untranslated regions of the X/P polycoding region by interference with its interactions via interference by interactions with protein interaction interactions.

title: Fate of the H-NS–Repressed bgl Operon in Evolution of Escherichia coli
predicted summary: Enterobacteriaceae express horizontally acquired genes with higher than average AT content that are repressed by the nucleoid-associated protein H-NS. Here, we investigated the evolutionary evolution of the transcriptional locus bgl (aryl-D-glucoside) operon of Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica at laboratory growth conditions. Typing mutant strains of phylogenetic groups A, B1, and B2 showed that they evolved clonally and that it is functionally present in most isolates belonging to group B2, suggesting a functional role played by this gene in enterobacterial pathogenic E. Colibacterium. Our results suggest that evolutionarily evolved mutations may provide insights into the evolutionary mechanisms responsible for the establishment of functional genes that could be used to regulate the expression of these genes.

title: Comparison of Visceral Leishmaniasis Diagnostic Antigens in African and Asian Leishmania donovani Reveals Extensive Diversity and Region-specific Polymorphisms
predicted summary: Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is caused by infection with the yeast L. donovani complexes, which is known to be fatal if left untreated. Rapid field diagnosis relies principally on demonstration of anti-VLEISHmania antibodies in clinically suspect cases. The rapid diagnostic test is based on the synthetic antigen rK39 encoded by a fragment of genetically conserved gene fragmented from Brazil. Genetic diversity between strains differs significantly between regions of East Africa and South Asia. Here we show that there is extensive genetic diversity among East African isolates and between EastAfrica and East Asia with significant diversity from gene sequences obtained from genomic DNA amplified sequence variants used to flank genes flanking gene products designed to reduce variability of Variable Field Diagnostic Assays performance.

title: Intrinsic Noise Induces Critical Behavior in Leaky Markovian Networks Leading to Avalanching
predicted summary: The role intrinsic statistical fluctuations play in creating leaky Markovian networks is examined using broad classes of probabilistic models that employ a potential energy landscape perspective coupled with macroscopic description based on statistical thermodynamics to characterize system behavior at near-critical or subcritical network sizes. Using this broad class of models, we demonstrate that intrinsic noise-induced deformation of the system topographic surface can cause avalanches, patterns of complex bursting activity with scale-free properties that dominate system dynamics at Near Critical or Subcritical Network Sizes. We also demonstrate here that appreciable levels of intrinsic Noise can account for this complex mode of operation, which dominates System Behavior in many biological interactions between biological, physical and manmade interactions.

title: Explaining the Linguistic Diversity of Sahul Using Population Models
predicted summary: The region of the ancient Sahul continent (present day Australia and New Guinea) is home to extreme diversity of languages. Even apart from the huge Austronesian language family which spread into the area after the break-up of SAHUL continent in the Holocene, there are hundreds of language families from many apparently unrelated families. We have inferred structural characteristics of these languages under an admixture model, using recombining genetic markers originally developed to discover populations on the basis of structural markers. The results show striking evidence of early dispersals between members of big phylogenetic groups can be identified with clearly defined structural features under the assumption that they are related to each other at a depth which is inaccessible to standard methods. Our results also show evidence for early contact effects between member member of large families, which can in some cases have been previously hypothesized but never demonstrated.

title: The Mediator co-activator complex regulates Ty1 retromobility by controlling the balance between Ty1i and Ty1 promoters
predicted summary: Ty1 retrotransposons present in Saccharomyces cerevisiae belong to the large class of mobile genetic elements that replicate via an internal transcriptional co-activator complex and constitute a significant portion of most eukaryotic genomes. In spite of their known function in the nucleus, previous studies have implicated Mediator in regulation of post-translational steps in Ty1. To resolve this paradoxical paradox, we investigated the effects of deletion of non-essential MediATOR subunits on the frequency and levels of genomic Ty1, Ty2RNA levels. Our results reveal that loss of Mediators alters the ratio of Ty3RNA positively positively or negatively over an >10,000-fold range by altering Ty4 transcript levels positively and negatively. These results resolve the paradox by systematically examined the Effects of deleting Non-Mmediator Subunit deletions abolishing their effects positively negatively or positively over more than 10,000fold Range.

title: Is Protein Folding Sub-Diffusive?
predicted summary: Protein folding dynamics is often described as diffusion on a free energy surface considered as function of one or few reaction coordinates. However, increasing number of experiments and models show that when projected onto this coordinate protein dynamics are sub-diffusive. This raises the question as to whether the conventionally used diffusives description of protein folding is adequate. Here, we numerically construct the reaction Coordinate projection trajectory of Go models of proteins. We show here that the higher the trajectory trajectory projection profile (cut-based profile) for the putative reactions coordinate, the more diffuse the dynamics become when projectioned on this trajectory. The results suggest that whether projected dynamics depends on whether projection dynamics change depending on the response profile depends upon the choice of response profiles. Moreover, projection projections projected on suboptimal reactions exhibit different dynamics.

title: Characterizing the Impact of Category Uncertainty on Human Auditory Categorization Behavior
predicted summary: Categorization is an important cognitive process. However, the correct categorization of auditory-category decisions is often challenging because categories can have overlapped boundaries. This phenomenon has been extensively studied in vision, but the analogous phenomenon in audition has yet to be explored. Here, we test whether and how human subjects learn category distributions and prior probabilities early in testing and whether subjects employ optimal decision strategies to make decision behavior. We found that subjects learned probability-matching behavior if they utilized nonstationary categories formed over a short stimulus history. Our results provide insights into whether human Subjects learn categories early during testing, as well as whether they employ additional noise sources may influence their decision behaviors when making decisions.

title: Excitatory Local Interneurons Enhance Tuning of Sensory Information

title: Identification and validation of genetic variants predictive of gait in standardbred horses

This highly accurate algorithm could be used by owners/trainers to identify horses with the potential to race independently according to genotyping and would enable fine tuning breeding programs with designed mating programs prior to initiating training.

Here we studied how humans select actions under such extrinsic and intrinsic uncertainty in view of exponentially expanding number of prospects on a branching multivalued visual stimulus. The task was to maximize the cumulative reward by touching one disk at the time in rapid sequence, while every step along the path constrained the part of the grid accessible in the future. We found that humans traded off depth of computation for the recalculation period. This tradeoff was consistent with brute-force exploration of all possible paths up to the resource-limited finite depth.

title: Community-based benchmarking improves spike rate inference from two-photon calcium imaging data

title: Fast Reconstruction of Compact Context-Specific Metabolic Network Models
