These oscillations are visible in all populations, but the origins cannot be deduced from the observed spectra. In this paper we present connectivity maps which identify connections crucial for the generation of low- and high- noises observed in V1, composed of leaky integrate-and-fire neurons. We demonstrate how small perturbations of the crucial connections have significant impact on V1 connectivity networks while impairment of other connections leaves the dynamics on the population level unaltered

title: Single Strand Annealing Plays a Major Role in RecA-Independent Recombination between Repeated Sequences in the Radioresistant Deinococcus radiodurans Bacterium
predicted summary: Deinococcus radiodurans is one of the most radioresistant organisms known. It reconstructs functional genomes from hundreds of radiation-induced DNA sequence fragments separated by intervening sequences of various lengths ranging from 1,479 bp to 10,500 Bp. Here we show that deletion events between direct repeats between RecA and RecO deletions occur spontaneously in recA+ bacteria as well as recO bacteria exposed to radiation exposure. We found that absence of RecF proteins strongly reduces the frequency of deletion Events between the direct sequence Sequences. Our results suggest that RecB proteins are involved in DNA double repeat break repair through Single Strike Repair pathways. RecC proteins were also shown to be involved by Regulation of DNA Double Break Repair through single Stride Repair pathway.

title: Hippocampal Remapping Is Constrained by Sparseness rather than Capacity
predicted summary: Grid cells encode spatial information with firing fields that are arranged on the nodes of spatiotemporal hexagonal lattices. Potential candidates for feeding this information are hippocampal place cells providing feedforward input to grid cells. We show here that the spatial decoding capacity is determined by spatial acuity and the number of different spatial environments that can be represented. Our results suggest that both populations may encode different aspects of space simultaneously. Inhibition can also be used to store information for more environments by partitioning the population such that learning affects only small fractions of them in each environment.

title: A simple real-time model for predicting acute kidney injury in hospitalized patients in the US: A descriptive modeling study
predicted summary: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is an adverse event that carries significant morbidity and mortality. However, integration of real-time prognostic modeling into the electronic health record (EHR) system has been challenging, as complex models increase the risk of error and complicate deployment. In this study, we developed a simple model using readily available laboratory data to accurately predict acute kidney Injury within 24 hours of AKI observation. This model could be easily integrated into existing EHR systems without sacrificing the performance seen in more complex model designs. We found that simple models could easily integrate easily within existing Electronic Health Records System integration without complicating deployment and integration with existing systems. Simulations were performed using discrete-Time logistic regression modeling in both training sets and external validation sets within Hospital 1 and External Validation Sets.

title: Mass Administration of Ivermectin for the Elimination of Onchocerciasis Significantly Reduced and Maintained Low the Prevalence of Strongyloides stercoralis in Esmeraldas, Ecuador
predicted summary: Analysis of data collected during surveys conducted in areas where mass distribution of ivermectin was administered annually to the entire population for control of strongyloidiasis and other soil transmitted helminthiases was carried out. We conducted retrospective analysis of samples collected in Esmeraldas, Ecuador between 1990 and 2013 (six years after interruption of the intervention). We found that Mass distribution had a significant impact on the prevalence of StrongYloid infections. In areas not covered by Mass Distribution there was no effect on Hookworm infections compared to Areas Not Covered by mass Distribution Population Survey Surveys. The results suggest that mass drug distribution did not have effects on Strongylid infections in the presence of hookworm infection.

title: Cryo-electron Microscopy Structure of the Native Prototype Foamy Virus Glycoprotein and Virus Architecture
predicted summary: Foamy viruses (FVs) belong to the Spumavirus lineage which forms distinct lineages in the Retroviridae family. FV replication well replicates well in human cells making it an attractive gene therapy vector candidate candidate. Here we present cryo-electron microscopy ultrastructural data obtained from purified prototypic FoAmyvirus particles infected with FEVs and FVEs. Our data provide important new insights into the molecular architecture of FAV particles and its distinct evolutionary relationship with other members of the retrovirus family, suggesting that FVA glycoproteins have distinct structures with distinct structural structures between the capsid and membrane likely formed by the Gag N-terminal domain and the Env leader glycopeptide gp18LP.

title: A human judgment approach to epidemiological forecasting
predicted summary: Emerging epidemics can be helpful in mitigating outbreaks and preparedness for epidemic targets, especially short-term targets such as influenza and chikungunya seasons. Collective judgment can provide useful predictive power in combination with statistical models and computational methods. However, collective judgment is often more accurate than statistical predictions made by statistical systems alone. We created the web-based “Epicast” forecasting system which aggregates epidemic forecasts made in real-time by human participants. Together, we show that Collective judgement predicts influenza flu seasons far more accurately than other statistical methods combined together than individual statistical approaches combined statistically combined predictions for influenza seasons, particularly for short term targets. This approach provides valuable predictability for flu season predictions, and discusses benefits and drawbacks of Collective Human judgment approaches.

title: PoCos: Population Covering Locus Sets for Risk Assessment in Complex Diseases
predicted summary: Susceptibility loci identified by GWAS account for a limited fraction of heritability. Predictive models based on identified genomic variants have modest success in risk assessment and therefore are of limited practical use. Many methods have been developed to overcome these limitations by incorporating prior biological knowledge at the level of genes, limiting analyses to genotypes that are collectively associated with diseases that have similar biological mechanisms and biological relevance. However, most of the information utilized by these methods relies on genetic variant information that is present within genomic regions. Here we propose integrating protein protein interaction datasets and expression quantitative trait locus data into heterogenous network models. We show that the proposed framework significantly outperforms individual variant Based Risk Assessment Models as well as the state-of-the-art polygenic score predictive model to be used in Risk assessment for seven complex diseases, type 1 diabetes (T1D), type 2 diabetes and multiple sclerosis (MS).

title: FAK Acts as a Suppressor of RTK-MAP Kinase Signalling in Drosophila melanogaster Epithelia and Human Cancer Cells
predicted summary: Receptor Tyrosine Kinases regulate multiple signalling pathways including mitogen activated protein pathway downstream pathways. Here we investigated how Focal Adhesion Kinease regulates receptor recycling pathways downstream of receptor receptor proteins. This regulation was observed in MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer epithelia, suggesting it is conserved phenomenon in humans. We found that FAK suppressed RTKs Signalling by impairing Mitogen-Activated Protein pathway by restricting receptor recycle into plasma membrane pool, which results in lower MAPK activation. These results suggest that this regulation may have potential implications in designing therapeutic strategies targeting cancer targets targeting tumour suppressor targets.

title: High-Density SNP Mapping of the HLA Region Identifies Multiple Independent Susceptibility Loci Associated with Selective IgA Deficiency
predicted summary: Selective immunodeficiency (IgAD) is the most common form of human primary immune disease, affecting approximately 1600 individuals in populations of Northern European ancestry. The polygenic nature of this disease is underscored by the recent identification of several new genetic variants contributing to disease pathogenesis. We performed a high-density SNP mapping of the HLA locus and imputed the genotypes of common alleles associated with common haplotypes across the entire genome-wide association loci from 772 patients and 1,976 controls from 3 independent independent European populations. Our results support the use of large multi-ethnic populations to characterize shared genetic association signals that contribute to diseases regardless of ethnic backgrounds. Furthermore, we provide evidence for the location and location of these shared associations.

title: Hydrodynamic Radii of Intrinsically Disordered Proteins Determined from Experimental Polyproline II Propensities
predicted summary: Structure properties of disordered proteins are thought to depend on intrinsic conformational propensities for polyproline II structure that quantitatively match structural behavior measured in sequence-dependent proteins. However, the ability of these experimentally determined PPII structures to quantify structural properties has not been established. Here results from molecular simulations show that the hydrodynamic radius (Rh) can be quantified from experimentalLY determined structures with good agreement, even when charge-based considerations are omitted. The results demonstrate that hydrogen dynamics are evidence of substantial structural behaviors measured across wide ranges of protein lengths, net charge composition, and sequence composition. Simulation simulation simulation results provide evidence that Hydrodynamic dimensions are responsible for structural structures that qualitatively reproduce structural functions measured by chemically encoded structurally conserved structures, although Charge effects on Rh are generally weak.

title: Immunity to Distinct Sand Fly Salivary Proteins Primes the Anti-Leishmania Immune Response towards Protection or Exacerbation of Disease
predicted summary: Phlebotomus papatasi salivary gland homogenate protects mice against Leishmania major infection delivered by needle-inoculation with SGH or by infected sand fly bites. Immunization with distinct salivaRY proteins produced distinct immune profiles that correlated with resistance or susceptibility to infection. Here, we analyze the immune responses of mice immunovaccinated with either PpSP15-immunized mice or pre-exposed mice exposed to L. major infections. Mice immunomimunely Immunized with PPHP15 were protected against the parasites transmitted by the presence of parasitic salivaries. The resultant immune response was abolished by exposure to these distinct proteins from two different parasitoplasmic parasitogenic proteins, PhPPP15 and PPPAPS44-mice. Our results show that immunomunitions exposed mice exhibit lasting protection against parasitemias delivered through needle injections either by either needle vaccinations with LGH-treated needles or antibiotics administered by mice that were exposed either preexpressed to either of these two proteins.

title: Elucidating the Ticking of an In Vitro Circadian Clockwork
predicted summary: Circadian oscillators display the salient properties of circadian rhythms, including self-sustained 24-h periodicity that is temperature compensated, consistent with biophysical observations of individual individual Kai proteins interactions. We quantify the time-dependent interactions between the three proteins (KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC) by electron microscopy and native gel electrophoresis to determine the timing of the formation of complexed proteins among these proteins. The data are used to derive a dynamic model that accurately reproduces the rhythmRhythms of KaiABC complex formation by using fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) to confirm monomer exchange among the Kai molecules involved in the reaction may maintain synchrony among individual proteins in order to sustain high-amplitude oscillations. This model provides the first perturbation analysis of this unique clockwork by applying temperature pulses to reset the phase of its phase reset Phase.

title: Cluster randomized trial comparing school-based mass drug administration schedules in areas of western Kenya with moderate initial prevalence of Schistosoma mansoni infections
predicted summary: Mass drug administration (MDA) using Mass Drug Administration using Praziquantel is the WHO-recommended approach for control of Schistosoma mansoni infection in school children in western Kenya. However, few studies have evaluated the impact of different MDA schedules on the resultant infection levels. We performed a cluster randomization trial of 3 different frequency regimens annually, the first 2 years, or every other year over 5 year period in 75 villages with moderate initial prevalence (10%-24%) infection intensity in first year students either within or between arms. Our results suggest that mass drug Administration strategies may be more effective than less frequent treatments for controlling community-level infections, even if provided only once each year.

title: Voltage-dependent calcium channel signaling mediates GABAA receptor-induced migratory activation of dendritic cells infected by Toxoplasma gondii
predicted summary: The intracellular parasite Toxoplasma gondii exploits cells of the immune system to disseminate to target organs. Upon infection, calcium signaling triggers a hypermigratory phenomenon in dendritic cells (DCs) by unknown signal transduction pathways. Here, we show that inhibition of voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels by GABA induces calcium entry into DCs required for host cell migration. Inhibition of calcium channels abolished the presence of cell-associated parasitosomes in bone marrow cells and reduced dissemination to targets Organs by inhibiting calcium channel activation. Furthermore, inhibition either by short hairpin RNA or selectively suppressing Cav1.3 prevented the appearance of parasitic cells in blood circulation. We show here that calcium-mediated calcium pathways are essential for Toxicity-induced DC hypermotility and transmigration.

title: Chaperone-Mediated Autophagy Protein BAG3 Negatively Regulates Ebola and Marburg VP40-Mediated Egress
predicted summary: Filovirus matrix proteins are essential for assembly and budding of viral particles involved in hemorrhagic fever outbreaks. They interact with specific host proteins such as Nedd4 and ITCH to facilitate the late stage of virus-cell separation. Here we identified BCL2 Associated Athanogene 3 (BAG3), a member of the BAG family of molecular chaperone proteins that regulates intracellular protein homeostasis and cell survival by regulating both virus assembly-associated VLPs as well as infectious VSV-EBOV virus particles. Our results show that BCG3 interacts with the PPxY motif of both Ebola viruses and Marburg viruses by inhibiting Budding both viral-like particles and infectious viral viruses. Importantly, our results suggest that the role of BGC3 exerts stress-induced autophagy functions to counteract the function

title: Locus Coeruleus tracking of prediction errors optimises cognitive flexibility: An Active Inference model
predicted summary: Two modes of locus coeruleus firing have been associated with distinct cognitive states: changes in tonic rates of firing correlate with global levels of arousal and behavioural flexibility, whilst phasic firing patterns are evoked by salient stimuli. Here, we unify these two modes by modelling the response to states firing as an emergent feature of belief updating under Active Inference (AI). We show that when contingencies change, AI agents can update their internal models more quickly by feeding back state-action prediction errors–reflected in LC firing and noradrenaline release–to optimise learning rate, enabling large adjustments over short timescales.

title: Distinct phenotype and function of circulating Vδ1+ and Vδ2+ γδT-cells in acute and chronic hepatitis B
predicted summary: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) persists with global and virus-specific T-cell dysfunction regardless of clinical status. We examined the frequency, function and function of peripheral blood V1+/V2+T cells by multiparameter cytometry in patients with chronic chronic HBV infection and acute acute hemorrhagic influenza virus infection as part of lymphoid stress surveillance surveillance with potential role in clinical outcomes beyond clinical resolution of CHB flares. Our results suggest that peripheral plasma lymphocytes display distinct activation and differentiatiation in chronic infection without significant differences between chronic infections, acute infections and uninfected control subjects.

title: Toxin-Induced Necroptosis Is a Major Mechanism of Staphylococcus aureus Lung Damage
predicted summary: Staphylococcus aureus USA300 strains cause highly inflammatory necrotizing pneumonia. Toxin-induced necroptosis is a major cause of lung pathology in this strain, suggesting the possibility of targeting components of this signaling pathway as therapeutic strategies. Inhibition of cell death through inhibition of either RIP1/RIP3/MLKL signalling adica mutant mutant mice lacking either MLKLK inhibitory pathway showed significantly improved outcome and retained an alveolar macrophage population with CD200R markers suggesting increased susceptibility of these mice to infection during acute infection. Necrotoxicity could be prevented by inhibiting either Rip3/MLKL Signaling pathways.

title: Integrating transcriptomic network reconstruction and eQTL analyses reveals mechanistic connections between genomic architecture and Brassica rapa development
predicted summary: Brassica rapa growth curves are genetically correlated with growth rates, final sizes, and herbivore resistance/wounding responses/cellular division responses. Therefore, understanding the genetic architecture of plant development and ontogenetic dynamics is critically important for agricultural production and evolutionary ecology. Here we use Hierarchical Bayesian Function-Valued Trait (FVT) models to estimate plant growth dynamics across two treatments and in two growing seasons. We find genetic variation for plasticity of growth Rates and Final Sizes, but not the transition from acceleration to decelerating growth. Our results provide strong evidence for regulatory hotspots for FVT QTL than any single single data type alone.

title: The ins and outs of vanillyl alcohol oxidase: Identification of ligand migration paths
predicted summary: Vanillyl alcohol Oxide catalyzes the conversion of vanillin (4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzaldehyde) from vanilLYL alcohol oxidase (VAO) and hydrogen peroxide, respectively. In vitro simulations have been performed to understand how different enzymes enter and exit the active site during catabolism. Here we show that the entry/exit pathway is the most probable route to enter active sites. We argue that entry pathways lead to exit pathways leading to the re side of FAD, which leads to phenolic ligands dioxygen/hydrotheronal hydrogen PeroxidE pathways. A fourth pathway leading towards the si side has been identified for the co-ligases DioxyGEN. Importantly, we have identified four pathways that could act as gateways of activatory reactions between the two reactions.

title: Convex Clustering: An Attractive Alternative to Hierarchical Clustering
predicted summary: Hierarchical clustering operates on multiple scales simultaneously simultaneously in order to make qualitative inferences about how lower-order relationships such as gene modules lead to higher order relationships like pathways or biological processes. Here we develop and test a novel algorithm designed specifically to minimize the objective function of convex Clustering. The algorithm accommodates missing data and supports prior information about relationships between clusters that are hidden by static methods. Our algorithm CONVEXCLUSTER is implemented on graphics processing units (GPUs) for maximal speed to handle high-dimensional problems. This algorithm preserves its visual appeal while ameliorates its propensity to lie in the presence of outliers and noise. We developed and tested proximal distance algorithm for minimizing the Objective Function of ConveX Cluster Analysis.

title: Neglected Tropical Diseases outside the Tropics
predicted summary: The neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide due to growth in international travel and immigration growth. However, there has been no specific focus in the literature on imported NTDs. Retrospective study of a cohort of immigrants diagnosed with one of the 13 core neglected Tropical Diseases acquired at Tropical Medicine Referral Unit in Spain during the period April 1989-December 2007. We found that the most frequent cases occurred in immigrants, followed by travelers from sub-Saharan Africa, Chagas disease (n = 95,3.6%) acquired from South America and ascariasis found most frequently among travelers acquired outside tropical settings. In addition, importation programs may have an impact even outside Tropical settings and may create unique opportunities for research in future development. Recognising importations abroad would allow specific prevention and control measures to be implemented.

title: The Eukaryotic Mismatch Recognition Complexes Track with the Replisome during DNA Synthesis
predicted summary: During replication, mispaired bases escape the proofreading activity of DNA polymerase proteins that escape proofread activity during replication. In yeast, Mismatch Recognition Complexes are proteins involved in mismatch recognition that efficiently repair the entire spectrum of mutations during S-phase. This work provides evidence that both MutS/ proteins are located adjacent regions of the newly synthesized DNA. Using genomic methods coupled with custom DNA immunoprecipitation arrays, we show that mismatched bases can be easily repaired by misfolding their neighboring regions. Our data support the model that the proximity of MutA proteins within proximity proximity determines the dynamics of movement dynamics during the repair of both mutant mutants and defective mutant strains of defectively repaired mutant proteins.

title: ATP and MO25α Regulate the Conformational State of the STRADα Pseudokinase and Activation of the LKB1 Tumour Suppressor
predicted summary: Mutagenesis studies reveal interactions between STRAD and the scaffolding protein MO25 involved in activating the LKB1 tumour suppressor cyclin A. Here we describe structures characteristically characteristic of active pseudokinases. Our structures reveal that activation is dependent upon close conformations maintained by either binding of binding residues of either substrate proteins required for activity. Inhibition of association with either catalytic residue binding promotes interaction between either protein binding proteins. We demonstrate that binding substrate binding enhances the affinity of both substrates to maintain the activity required by the ability to activate tumour suppression associated with tumor suppression. These structures are typical structures typical for active protein protein interactions.

title: Exploiting Single-Cell Quantitative Data to Map Genetic Variants Having Probabilistic Effects
predicted summary: Genomewide association studies (GWAS) are limited by a statistical power issue: many polymorphisms contribute little to common traits and thus escape detection. In such cases genetic mapping may benefit from the wealth of data produced by single-cell technologies. Genetic mapping allows to scan genomes for genetic links that are missed by classical genomic mapping methods. We present here the development of novel GeneticMapping Method that allows genome-wide associations obtained from single cell simulations and yeast experimental datasets. Our results illustrate how single cells can be exploited to improve the genetic dissection of common genetic traits. The method detects genetic linkages that were missing by Classical Genetic Mapping methods and identifies novel genes associated with elevated gene expression noise of galactose regulon.

title: WDR23 regulates NRF2 independently of KEAP1
predicted summary: NRF2/NFE2L2 is a key regulator of stress responses in C. elegans alongside human cell culture models, and loss of negative regulation by the KEAP1-CUL3 proteasome system is implicated in several chemo- and radiation-resistant cancers. Here we establish WDR23 as an alternative regulator independently independently of the canonical proteomics system involved in NNF2 activity and capacity for proteostasis independent of inhibition of NFE2. We show that the addition of Neh2 domains within NeH2 regulate NEF2 Activity independently from inhibition by inhibition independent regulators independent from inhibitory inhibition. In addition, we also uncover novel regulatory pathways downstream downstream of inhibitorY Regulation independent independently Independently independent regulation independently independent independent regulatory regulator-dependent regulation. We demonstrate that deletion of Negative Regulation Regulation23 abolishes negative Regulation by regulation independentdependent regulator activity independently dependent on inhibition

title: Digital Quantification of Human Eye Color Highlights Genetic Association of Three New Loci
predicted summary: Previous studies have successfully identified genetic variants in several genes associated with human iris color; however, they all used simplified categorical trait information. Here we quantified continuous eye color variation into hue and saturation values using high-resolution digital full-eye photographs and conducted genome-wide association studies on 5,951 Dutch Europeans from the Rotterdam Study. Three new regions, 1q42.3, 17q25.3, and 21q22.13 served as promising functional candidates. The latter two loci served to explain over 50% of trait variance. Our results demonstrate that fine phenotyping is a useful strategy for finding genes involved in human complex traits.

title: Sheep Skin Odor Improves Trap Captures of Mosquito Vectors of Rift Valley Fever
predicted summary: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is transmitted by blood-feeding arthropods that feed directly into human bloodstreams. Effective surveillance for RVFV requires the use of appropriate vector sampling tools. Here we tested the standard light trap alone alone and baited with CO2 traps in two highly-endemic areas in Kenya, Marigat and Ijara Districts from March–June and September–December 2010. These trap captures differ significantly from those recorded trapping alone trap. We found that the presence of attractive compounds present in these natural aromatic compounds should lead to development of an effective odor bait baitping system for population density monitoring especially during the inter-epidemic period. Our results suggest that this approach could improve RVVV surveillance particularly during interEMANIC periods. These results have implications for the development and implementation of effective insecticide-baiting systems.

title: The Prevalence of Scabies and Impetigo in the Solomon Islands: A Population-Based Survey
predicted summary: Scabies and impetigo are very common skin conditions in the Western Province of the Solomon Islands. Population control strategies may reduce the burden of both conditions and their downstream complications. This study used data collected from 10 rural villages in western Solomon Island villages to integrate data collection into existing projects investigating clinical markers and serological markers of yaws. Participants were interviewed and examined by paediatric registrars, who recorded relevant demographic information and made clinical diagnoses of disease severity and distribution. We found that the most severe cases were found in infants aged 1–4 years and children aged 1-years1 year of age. The highest prevalence was found among children  1 year olds (18–14 years) and Infants >1 years (Table 4). Community control Strategies for active impregular infections could reduce burden and associated complications associated with both Conditions. Community Control Strategies

title: Investigation on predominant Leptospira serovars and its distribution in humans and livestock in Thailand, 2010-2015
predicted summary: Leptospirosis is a worldwide zoonotic bacterial disease caused by infection with the bacteria Shermanibacteria serovars. Seroprevalence was 23.7% in humans, 24.8% in buffaloes, 28.1% in cattle, and 11.3% in pigs during 2010 to 2015. These findings may guide public health policy makers to implement appropriate control measures and help reduce the impact of the disease in Thailand. Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) was used to identify antibodies against multiple SerovARs per one Samples across species as well as regions across Thailand regions. The results indicate that livestock acts as reservoirs for infection and reservoir reservoir sources for human infection.

title: Novel inference models for estimation of abundance, survivorship and recruitment in mosquito populations using mark-release-recapture data
predicted summary: Mark-release-recapture experiments involve marking limitations due to small individual size, short lifespan, low efficiency in trapping devices such as traps, and individual removal upon capture. These limitations often make MMR analysis restricted to only abundance estimation or a combination of abundance and survivorship estimates and often generate great degree of uncertainty about the estimations. We present Bayesian biodemographic models designed to fit data from most common Mark Release Repatriation experiments using field data and simulations to estimate abundance, survival rates, removal rate and recruitment rates of marked and unmarked mosquito populations. Model models permit estimation of survival rate between marked mosquitoes released from captured individuals and released individuals, as well as capture efficiency, Survival Rate, Removal Rate and Recruitment Rate. Our models are important both to reduce uncertainty and help planning future MRR experiments.

title: A Competition between Stimulators and Antagonists of Upf Complex Recruitment Governs Human Nonsense-Mediated mRNA Decay
predicted summary: Mutations with premature termination codons (PTCs) are subjected to rapid decay pathways when translation terminates prematurely. Here we show that PTC recognition is mediated by a competition between 3′ UTR–associated factors that stimulate or antagonize recruitment of the Poly(A)–binding protein (PABP) to the terminating terminus. We speculate that this competition has evolved to concentrate NMD-inhibiting factors, such as PABP, distally close proximity to termination sequences. Previous models postulate central roles played by the polyphosphate–ligase complex in yeast cellpopulations, suggesting that the interaction between Upf1–3 interacts with the translation release factors eRF3–related proteins triggers NMPP recruitment to terminated transcriptional translational termination. In contrast, most human cells contain longer filamentous filamentosomes than other cells.

title: Fundamental Limits to Position Determination by Concentration Gradients
predicted summary: Position determination within biological systems is often achieved through protein concentration gradients. However, position determination must be robust to biochemical noise perturbations. Here we provide fundamental constraints on positional precision supplied by concentration-measuring apparatuses due to unavoidable Biochemical Noise perturbing the gradient proteins. We demonstrate the existence of optimal length scales for both single and double concentration proteins for which precision is maximized, as well as analyse how precision depends on the size of the concentration measuring apparatus. Using both Single and Double Concentration-Measure proteins with first-order reaction reactions, we show that, through time-averaging, Positional Precision close to its centre improves more slowly with increasing copy number.

title: Secondary Mapping of Lymphatic Filariasis in Haiti-Definition of Transmission Foci in Low-Prevalence Settings
predicted summary: Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is considered a public health problem by the World Health Organization (WHO). Areas of low-antigen prevalence (1%) are thought to pose little risk for continued transmission of LF and suggest better surveillance methods may be needed to detect microfoci of transmission. In this study, we assessed whether localized transmission was present even within low prevalence communes located within 20 meters of neighboring index cases. Using global positioning system coordinates and immunochromatographic tests for filarial antigenemia, our results suggest that Localized Transmission is present Even in Low-Prevalence settings.

title: Mitigation Strategies for Pandemic Influenza A: Balancing Conflicting Policy Objectives
predicted summary: Influenza outbreaks can have high social and economic costs. Mitigation of influenza epidemic dynamics can be achieved using a range of interventions to reduce transmission and buy time until vaccines are developed, but strategies crucially depend on the precise aim of the intervention. National pandemic influenza plans rarely contain clear statements of policy objectives or prioritization of potentially conflicting aims such as minimizing mortality or peak prevalence or restricting socio-economic burden of contact-reducing interventions prior to vaccine availability. These analyses highlight the need for more precise statements about Policy Objectives and their assumed consequences when planning and implement strategies to mitigate influenza outbreak dynamics.

title: Population Genetics of Two Key Mosquito Vectors of Rift Valley Fever Virus Reveals New Insights into the Changing Disease Outbreak Patterns in Kenya
predicted summary: Rift Valley fever outbreaks in Kenya have increased in frequency and range to include northeastern Kenya where viruses are increasingly isolated from known vectors such as Aedes mcintoshi and newly-associated viruses. However, the factors contributing to these changing outbreak patterns are unclear and the genetic structure of key vector associations remains under-studied. We conducted mitochondrial DNA analyses on >220 specimens from RVF outbreak-prone sites in Senegal, where newly isolated viruses appear to be expanding rapidly. The results reveal high levels of vector complexity which may partly explain the disease outbreak pattern. Our results strongly suggest that unlike known viruses, newly associated viruses from both countries may be of greater epidemiological importance than previously assumed. Furthermore, we identified genetic linkages between the two viruses belonging to both strains, suggesting that both viruses belong to different regions of RVV outbreak sites. In addition, our results provide insights into the evolutionary evolution of virus populations in both regions.

title: Transcriptional Dynamics Elicited by a Short Pulse of Notch Activation Involves Feed-Forward Regulation by E(spl)/Hes Genes
predicted summary: Signaling pathways, such as Notch, are key regulators of development and homeostasis. However, most studies assess output hours or days after initiating signaling, once the outcome has been consolidated. Here we analyze genome-wide changes in transcript levels, binding of transcription factor Supressor of Hairless, Su(H), following Short Pulse stimulation. We show that regulatory interactions, driven by early-responding regulator E(spl)bHLH/Hes proteins, play critical roles in many developmental and disease contexts, explaining the critical functions these genes play. Our data support the view that feed-forward feedforward feeding regulates the response of late Responding genes by feeding Forward Feedforward Feeder-Feedforward repression by Early Responder genes early Responders early responders.

title: A single gp120 residue can affect HIV-1 tropism in macaques
predicted summary: Mutations in HIV-1 envelope glycoproteins, proteins that aid virus replication determine the ability of viruses to jump between host species. These differences facilitate the development of animal models for HIV infections, including models based on SIVs that express HIV envelope proteins. We show here that mutations at the amino acid A281 significantly altered viral envelope activity during adaptation by virus passage in macaques and prevented the elimination of pathogenic viruses. Importantly, MutationA281, abolished HIV Env neutralization properties during adaption to Macaque adaptations and thus enhanced its ability to use macaceous CD4 as a receptor during adaptive adaptation. Here, we identify amino acids that consistently changes virus envelope enzymes duringAdaptAdaptive adaptation and enhance their ability for viruses to utilize macacian-tropic HIV viruses as receptors. Inhibiting mutationA280 regulates viral passage between hosts.

title: The Transcriptional Regulator Rok Binds A+T-Rich DNA and Is Involved in Repression of a Mobile Genetic Element in Bacillus subtilis
predicted summary: Bacillus subtilis encodes the transcription factor Rok that regulates expression of several genes not related to competence development. Here we show that the rok gene serves as a negative regulator of competence Development and Regulation of Expression of many genes that appear to have been acquired by horizontal gene transfer. Some regions of the genome are known or believed acquired horizontally by Horizontal gene Transfer. Interestingly, deletion of this region resulted in higher excision of one such element, ICEBs1, located integrated in the Gram negative Gramnegative E.coli genome. Our findings suggest that this protein functions functionally analogous to H-NS, which serves to regulate expression and regulation of gene expression. These findings provide insight into the role played by the presence of other proteins involved in gene regulation networks involved with the development of new genes.

title: Female Bias in Rhox6 and 9 Regulation by the Histone Demethylase KDM6A
predicted summary: The Rhox cluster contains reproduction-related homeobox genes expressed in sexually dimorphic manners prior to embryonic stem cell differentiation and thus poised for activation by KDM6A, a histone demethylase with female-biased expression. We report here that Kdm6a regulates the expression of genes important for reproductive regulation in mouse ovary and other reproductively important tissues. Our study implicateKDM6, the gene that escapes X inactivation, in the regulation of reproductive genes involved in reproduction and reproduction. Inhibition abolished by knockdown has no effect on transcriptional regulation.

title: Flip/flop mating-type switching in the methylotrophic yeast Ogataea polymorpha is regulated by an Efg1-Rme1-Ste12 pathway
predicted summary: Mutations in the structure of chromosomes result from nitrogen starvation, which induces changes in structure depending on the orientation of the region. Mating-type switching occurs in mutant cells of Ogataea (Hansenula) polymorpha that are subjected to nitrogen depletion. Here we describe the genetic pathway controlling mating switching that regulates filamentous growth and white-opaque switching in Candida albicans. We found that the transcription factor EFG1 encodes genes necessary both for switching and for changing structure. Our results show that either overexpression of gene knockout mutant mutant strain Candida is sufficient to induce switching without nitrogen-depleted cells, but lacks other genes required for matination genes other than genes involved in switching. The genetic defect is not related to the regulatory genes Regulation Regulation pathway Regulation genes

title: Nuclear Entry of Hepatitis B Virus Capsids Involves Disintegration to Protein Dimers followed by Nuclear Reassociation to Capsids
predicted summary: Assembly and disassembly of viral capsids are essential steps in viral life cycle processes. In vitro studies on their kinetics allow application of biochemical, biophysical and visualizing techniques. The transferability of these models to the nucleus remains poorly understood. Here we show that nuclear genome release is different from other viruses, which employ irreversible genome destruction for genome assembly. Our results allow us to propose a model HBV genome Release strategy that utilizes genome disintegration differently than other viral viruses. We show here that the unique environment of nuclear nuclear membrane favors nuclear glycolysis reactions that favor genome entry and subsequent genome reorganization reactions.

title: Phosphorylation of the Conserved Transcription Factor ATF-7 by PMK-1 p38 MAPK Regulates Innate Immunity in Caenorhabditis elegans
predicted summary: Caenorhabditis elegans requires PMK-1–activated protein kinase pathway that regulates basal expression of immune effector genes associated with pathogenic pathogens. However, it has not been well understood mechanisms by which ATF2/ATF7 functions as transcriptional regulators required for the regulation of immunity. Here, we show that C. cerevisiae ATK7 plays pivotal roles in regulation mechanisms critical for control of the expression pathways involved in immune responses in yeast responses to stress–induced stress responses. Genetic analysis of both loss-of-function alleles and gain-out mutants revealed that Mutations in atf7 abolished the switch from transcriptionally activated genes into activators upon activation by activating transcription factor activator activity in response to activatory activity. Our results suggest that mutant mutant mutations in Atf-7 function as repressor proteins that undergo switching modes of activity upon inhibition by phosphorylation with PMPK-1.

title: FOXO3 Regulates CD8 T Cell Memory by T Cell-Intrinsic Mechanisms
predicted summary: Cell proliferation regulates the magnitude of CD8 T cell memory during acute infection with Lymphocytic Choriomeningitis virus (LCMV). However, the role of transcription factors FOXO3 is poorly understood. Here we show that both global and non-lymphoid mice exposed to intracellular pathogens exhibit marked increases in the number of memory precursor effector cells, preferentially in lymphocyte organs during viral infection. This marked increase in memory was not associated with increased proliferation rates, but rather was linked to reductions in cell viability. We found that the increased accumulation of growth factor-deprived proliferatingCD8T cells during expansion was driven by transcriptional activation of both transcription factor transcription Factor activator genes that regulate homeostasis in vitro during infectious viral infections.

title: Quantifying Transmission Investment in Malaria Parasites
predicted summary: Transmission strategies can rarely be observed directly directly and must typically be inferred from infection dynamics, where the true transmission investment is known. We show that existing methods for separating transmission stages produced by different generations of parasites are inadequate and potentially very misleading. Applying this approach to real data generated from mice infected with Plasmodium chabaudi strains, we estimate transmission investments vary from zero to 20%, with evidence for variable investment over time in some hosts but not others. This suggests that even experimental infections where host genetics and environmental factors control transmission strategies may exhibit variable patterns of transmission Investment.

title: Signalling crosstalk at the leading edge controls tissue closure dynamics in the Drosophila embryo
predicted summary: Cell sheet sealing regulates cell shape changes essential for tissue sealing dynamics. However, how signalling pathways interact to determine and coordinate these domains remains poorly understood. In this study we sought out new genes specifically expressed in the leading edge morphogenetic domain of the Drosophila epithelium. Our results reveal complex patterning along the AP axis involving crosstalk between the JUN N-terminal Kinase Signalling pathway, segmentation genes and HOX genes necessary for regulation of cell pattern patterns. We found that the Leading Edge domain is highly heterogeneous and complex patterns sculpted along both anterior/posterior and posterior regions along this region. Furthermore, we identified new targets genes specifically expressed within the LE that play key roles in regulation. These findings provide new insights into the complexity and complexity of this new set of newly identified target genes

title: Prions amplify through degradation of the VPS10P sorting receptor sortilin
predicted summary: Prion diseases are fatal neurodegenerative disorders caused by abnormal folded isoforms of the abnormally folded proteins PrPC and PrPSc which are involved in progressive accumulation of prions in brains. Prions are responsible for a large number of fatal neurological disorders including Parkinson's disease and Parkinson disease. However, the mechanism by which Prionism accumulates in neurons is poorly understood. Here, we show that Sortilin acts as sorting receptors that sort proteins to sort them to degradation sites for degradation. SortILin-knockdown abolished Preptides accumulation by stimulating degradation of sortILIN downstream downstream Sortin receptor Sorting proteins involved with sortin degradation pathways, ultimately leading to Progressive accumulation PrIPSc accumulation in cells after infection with PrION infection.
