title: Brucella Induces an Unfolded Protein Response via TcpB That Supports Intracellular Replication in Macrophages
predicted summary: Brucella melitensis is a facultative intracellular Bacteria that causes the most prevalent zoonosis worldwide known as Brucellosis. However, host-pathogen interactions associated with Bruceella replication remain poorly understood. Inhibition of the Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) may provide novel therapeutic targets for treatment and vaccine development. Here we show that inhibition of proteins involved in UPR regulates expression of protein targets BiP, CHOP, and ERdj4 targets in murine macrophages. Purified tauroursodeoxycholic acid, chaperone that ameliorates the URP, also enhances the regulation of genes involved downstream pathways involved within the pathway involved. These results have implications for other bacteria that rely on host stress responses for replication such as the Endoplasmic Reticulum Replicatory Response Regulation Regulation.

title: Epidemiology of Sleeping Sickness in Boffa (Guinea): Where Are the Trypanosomes?
predicted summary: Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) is transmitted by the malaria parasite Glossina palpalis gambiense transmitted to humans by Lycosoma brucei transmitted from Guinea to Guinea. In Guinea, human carriers of the disease were found in areas frequented by humans, livestock and domestic animals. We carried out cross-sectional surveys on the distribution and abundance of HAT cases and vector vector carriers in the focus area of Boffa. High densities of Tsetse were detected in places frequent frequent by human contact areas, such as pirogue jetties, narrow mangrove channels and watering points. Our results highlight the limits of vector control strategies targeting patients only. This strategy will combine medical surveillance to find and treat cases, vector Control activities should combine vector surveillance activities to protect people from mosquito bites carried by mosquitoes

title: Programmatic factors associated with the limited impact of Community-Directed Treatment with Ivermectin to control Onchocerciasis in three drainage basins of South West Cameroon
predicted summary: Community-Directed Treatment with Ivermectin (CDTI) is known to have enhanced community participation in planning and resource mobilization toward the control of Onchocerciasis, leading to better individual acceptance of the intervention and hence high Treatment Coverage. However, after 10–12 rounds of treatment prevalence of disease was still high in three drainage basins of South West Cameroon and transmission was going on. We conducted 83 semi-structured questionnaires and conducted 12 interviews with Community Drug Distributors and Community Heads to explore the role of operational challenges in the failure of CDTI to control the disease as expected. Funding was reported to be inadequate and not timely partly due to transportation challenges which reduced the ability of Health Service staff to thoroughly sensitize Communities and Conduct Community Self Monitoring activities effectively; Communities were not meeting and discussed time and mode of distributions with individual communities partly Due to Transportation Challenges

title: A Pan-Lyssavirus Taqman Real-Time RT-PCR Assay for the Detection of Highly Variable Rabies virus and Other Lyssaviruses
predicted summary: Rabies virus infection is responsible for up to 70,000 estimated human deaths worldwide each year. Rapid diagnosis is essential for timely administration of post-exposure prophylaxis in humans and control of the disease in animals. However, there is currently no widely accepted rapid real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay for the detection of all Lyssavirus variants. In this study, we demonstrate the validation of a newly developed Multiplex Real-Time RTPCR Assay named LN34, which utilizes combination of primers and probes along with probe modifications to achieve superior coverage of LyS viruses while maintaining robustness and specificity for both ante-mortem and post mortem diagnosis of over 200 clinical isolates as well as field derived surveillance samples.

title: Identification of Type 1 Diabetes–Associated DNA Methylation Variable Positions That Precede Disease Diagnosis
predicted summary: Childhood-onset Type 1 Diabetes (T1D–MVPs) can arise early in the pathogenesis process that leads to overt diabetes–associated diseases such as type 1 diabetes. We performed an epigenome-wide association study using genetically and non-genetically relevant cell types relevant to this disease. Our results suggest that the temporal origins of disease-associated epigenic variation could underlie some of the genetic components involved in childhood Diabetes–related diseases. These results provide insights into how genetic variation arises early during the development of childhood diabetes and the mechanisms that lead to Overt Diabetes are poorly understood. Together these results support the idea that epiGenetic Variability plays important roles for both genetic Variants and Non Genomic Variance–specific epigenesis.

title: Evolutionary diversification of the HAP2 membrane insertion motifs to drive gamete fusion across eukaryotes
predicted summary: Chlamydomonas reinhardtii HAP2 is structurally homologous to viral class II transmembrane proteins, which initiate viral membrane interactions with host cells via amphipathic loops into host cell membranes. However, the functional conformation of the HAPLESS2 protein has remained unclear. Here, we report structure-guided crystal structures that identify key residues essential for membrane interaction between flowering plants, Flowering Plants, Trypanosomes and host Cell membrane environments. We show that Arabidopsis has evolved multiple modes of membrane insertion to accommodate the diversity it encountered during its evolutionary evolution during plant evolution. Our results suggest that the evolutionarily conserved, gamete-expressed proteins that initiate gametogenesis may have evolved Multiple modes

title: Crossover recombination and synapsis are linked by adjacent regions within the N terminus of the Zip1 synaptonemal complex protein
predicted summary: Most meiosis recombination intermediates that give rise to crosstalk between homologous chromosomes are embedded within hallmark structural structures called synaptonemal complexes. However, the mechanisms that coordinate these processes remain poorly understood. Here we report that adjacent regions within Zip1’s N terminus are differentially critical for its functions in crossover assembly and crossover activity. Among known structural components of budding yeast SC is Zip1, specifically required for the large subset of crossover events that also depend on the MutS complex. We show that deletion of ZIP1 residues 2–9 or 10–14 abolished tripartite SC assembly but allowed excess MutSA crossover crossovers within close proximity of neighboring regions adjacent Zip1. Moreover, deletion deleted Zip3 mutant mutants allowed excessive MutSUMOylation of the SC central element component, Ecm11, but MutSSA crossover proteins are strongly diminished.

title: STRFs in primary auditory cortex emerge from masking-based statistics of natural sounds
predicted summary: Auditory cortex represents the structural primitives out of which auditory nerves are composed. We hypothesize auditorY cortex is composed of structural components which approximate the nonlinear transformations natural sounds undergoes from outer ear through the cochlea nerve. Our model captures salient data properties and links inhibitory subfields to explain away effects as captured by linear approaches such as sparsecoding or maximal causes analysis (MCA).

title: The memory for time and space differentially engages the proximal and distal parts of the hippocampal subfields CA1 and CA3
predicted summary: Segregation of spatial and non-spatial information has recently been described using memory tasks with salient spatial dimensions, such as episodic episodes. Here we investigated whether spatiotemporal information bound to items recruits similar subnetworks as items or locations per se. Our results suggest that the concept of segregated networks and the traditional model are reconcilable to large extent by studying whether activity within temporal information Binding Area1 and Distal Area3 retains affinity for temporally bound information. We report robust spatial discrimination ratios proximal and distal regions of the hippocampus, as is the case for episodes, suggesting that these networks retain affinity to objects with respect to spatial information binding pathways.

title: Lipopolysaccharide structure impacts the entry kinetics of bacterial outer membrane vesicles into host cells
predicted summary: Gram-negative bacteria shed outer membrane-sized microvesicles shed from outside membrane membranes into host cells and play important roles in immune priming and disease pathogenesis. However, our current understanding of these interactions is limited by a lack of methods to study the rapid kinetics of entry and cargo delivery between bacteria. Here, we describe genetically encoded genomic probes that allow bacteria to bypass endocytosis by bypassing lipopolysaccharide O antigen transport. We show that the composition of cell wall composition determines entry rate and efficiency during Gramnegative infections. Furthermore, the presence LipoPolypeptide O Antigen enhances both Entry Rate and Efficiency of Enterobacteria cells entering host cell cargo cargo transport pathways.

title: Perfluoroalkyl substances and changes in body weight and resting metabolic rate in response to weight-loss diets: A prospective study
predicted summary: Perfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) may interfere with body weight regulation and metabolism in humans. However, whether exposure to these chemicals interferes with metabolic regulation remains poorly understood. In this study, baseline plasma concentrations were significantly associated with greater decline in resting metabolic rate during the weight-loss period and greater weight gain in both men and women, possibly explained by slower regression regression of RMR levels. Participants lost an average of 6.4 kg of bodyweight during baseline and then regained 2.7 kg during period of 6–24 months (weightgain period). Higher baseline levels of plasma plasma levels significantly increased the likelihood of greater changes in metabolic parameters. These data suggest novel pathways through which environmental chemicals interact with human metabolism, such as glucose, lipids, thyroid hormones and leptin-dependent metabolic rates. This study provides insights into the effects of Environmental chemicals on the obesity epidemic

title: Detection of a microbial metabolite by STING regulates inflammasome activation in response to Chlamydia trachomatis infection
predicted summary: Chlamydia trachomatis is an important intracellular human pathogen that causes significant immunopathology. Inflammasome activation requires the ability to distinguish between infectious insult and non-infectious insult to prevent inappropriate inflammation. Here we sought to identify critical host factors that contribute to host immune responses. Using primary murine bone marrow cells infected with live organisms, we found that Live organism activates both canonical and Non-canonically inflammable bacteria in vitro and activated both types of inflammation independently of host metabolism. By immunoblotting macrophages exposed to Live Bacillary Bacteria displayed elevated levels of type-1 Interferon responses and suppressed Type-1 interferonic activity. We identified STING, independent of Replicating Bacteriolytic Activity as central mediators involved in initiating host inflammation and inflammation that could be therapeutically targeted therapeutic targets.

title: Drosophila microRNAs 263a/b Confer Robustness during Development by Protecting Nascent Sense Organs from Apoptosis
predicted summary: MiR-263a/b are members of a conserved family of microRNAs expressed in peripheral sense organs across the animal kingdom. Here we present evidence that miR/263b protects Drosophila mechanosensory bristles during developmentally programmed wave of cell death that prunes excess cells in order to refine the pattern of the pupal retina. Mutations mutant mutants lacking the gene head involution defective promote robustness of patterning processes by maintaining robust survival of these functionally specified cells during the Developmentally Programmed Wave of Cell Death. This suggests that the role of MicroRNA proteins may be to ensure robust patterns by protecting the interommatidial Bristle Patterning process by Promoting robustity of patterns.

title: Feasibility and Effectiveness of Basic Lymphedema Management in Leogane, Haiti, an Area Endemic for Bancroftian Filariasis
predicted summary: Primary lymphatic filariasis is caused by repeated episodes of acute acute lymphedemphangioadenitis (ADLA), which leads to progression of lymphocyte proliferation. However, few studies have prospectively evaluated the efficacy of basic lymphemia management, which emphasizes hygiene, skin care, exercise, and leg elevation, to reduce ADLA frequency in resource-poor settings. During the first phase of the study, compression bandages were associated with reductions in leg volume using compressive compression bands. Inclusion criteria included age, gender, Stage 2 lymphomasthesisemia, illiteracy, self-care, use of compression Bandages, age grouping, physical activity and Leg elevation. We retrospectively assessed the effectiveness of Basic Lymphatic Dermatolymphaemia Management Program programs in Resource-limited areas that are endemic for Wuchereria bancrofti. Briefly, we assessed whether this program could be feasible and effective for patients living in resources limited areas with lymphEdema.

title: Population dynamics of engineered underdominance and killer-rescue gene drives in the control of disease vectors
predicted summary: Two classes of gene drive systems are currently under development in Aedes mosquitoes, engineered underdominance and killer-rescue vector control systems. They have gained attention for their potential to aid in the fight against various mosquito-vectored diseases. Here we present mathematical models combining the population dynamics and population genetics of both systems that combine ecological factors such as strengths of larval competition; numbers of breeding sites; and the relative fitness of transgenic mosquito populations compared to wild-type counterparts. We also extend our models to consider the effects that may be obtained as result of differences between neighbouring populations. Our models combine genetic factors not previously studied using alternative modelling methodologies and allow the potential effects of environmental factors on these two systems to be disentangled.

title: A high-throughput and open-source platform for embryo phenomics
predicted summary: Phenomics has the potential to facilitate significant advances in biology but requires the development of high-throughput technologies capable of generating and analysing high dimensions of data during dynamic processes such as embryonic development, during which high rates of temporal, spatial, and functional change are inherently difficult to capture. Here we present EmbryoPhenomics, an accessible platform for phenomics in aquatic embryos comprising an Open-source Video Microscope (OpenVIM) that produces high resolution videos of multiple embryons under tightly controlled environmental conditions. We demonstrate broad-scale applicability of this platform in experiments assessed chronic, acute responses to environmental change (temperature and salinity) responses during the developmental process of aquatic larval development—the pond snail Radix balthica and marine amphipod Orchestia gammarellus—both species had markedly different patterns of development. This platform can acquire and process data capturing functional responses in the most dynamic life stages and is potentially game changing for those interested in studying development more widely.

title: Early Mesozoic Coexistence of Amniotes and Hepadnaviridae
predicted summary: Endogenized sequences of Hepatitis B viruses (HBVs) have been discovered in bird genomes where they constitute direct evidence for the coexistence of these viruses and their hosts from the late Mesozoic until present. However, little is known about the ancient host range of this virus family in other animals. Here we report the first HBVs from crocodilians, snakes, turtles that endogenize >207 million years ago. We provide multiple lines of evidence that the tumor-promoting X protein of mammalian viruses lacks homologous genes involved in tumor replication along that time span. Our results provide novel insights into the evolutionary evolution of viral viruses throughout their long-lasting association with amniote hosts at least since the Late Mesolithic.

title: Quantifying and Predicting the Effect of Exogenous Interleukin-7 on CD4+T Cells in HIV-1 Infection
predicted summary: Exogenous Interleukin-7 (IL-7), supplement to antiretroviral therapy, leads to substantial increase of all CD4+ T cell subsets in HIV-1 infected patients involved in phase I/II studies. However, the quantitative contribution of the several potential mechanisms of action of this supplement is unknown. In this study we performed mathematical analysis of repeated measurements of total and peripheral lymphocytes and Ki67 expression from HIV infection involved involved with three phase II studies (N = 53 Patients involved). We show that besides transient increases of peripheral proliferation, additional effects exert Additional effects that play a significant role up to 52 weeks upto 52weeks upstream that exert significant effects. Our simulation study shows that repeated administration of intracytoplasmic immunomodulatory drugs may allow sustained sustained restoration with limited exposure during prolonged exposure over period of two years. This study reveals the potential for sustained Restoration with Limitative Exposure to Chronic Immunity Therapy.

title: The CD14+CD16+ Inflammatory Monocyte Subset Displays Increased Mitochondrial Activity and Effector Function During Acute Plasmodium vivax Malaria
predicted summary: Plasmodium malaria infection results in strong activation of monocytes, which are important components of both systemic immune response and parasite control response. Here, we demonstrate that P. vivax malaria patients display significant increase in CD14+CD16 levels than classical CD16+ cells, suggesting that they play important roles during malaria resistance. These results provide key information on the mechanism by which Pseudomonas malaria controls malaria burden. This study provides key insights into the mechanisms involved in malaria control mechanisms, supporting the hypothesis that these cells play a role in resistance to malaria malaria.

title: CD4+ T Cells Are as Protective as CD8+ T Cells against Rickettsia typhi Infection by Activating Macrophage Bactericidal Activity
predicted summary: Rickettsia typhi is an intracellular bacteria that causes febrile diseases such as pneumonia, hepatitis and meningoencephalitis which can be fatal due to complications including pneumonia and Meningogaster complications. Here, we show that CD4+ immune CD8+ effector cells produced in RAG1-/- mice survive the infection without showing symptoms of disease at any point in time and protected only approximately 60% of the animals from death. Our data suggest that the release of immunomodulatory Factor IFN is sufficient for protection against R. typhus infection. We show here that cytotoxic CD9+ cells are protectively protective against Rickected macrophages by stimulating the expression of antiviral factors that can contribute to bacterial killing but accelerate pathology and accelerate Pathology.

title: Phase Variable O Antigen Biosynthetic Genes Control Expression of the Major Protective Antigen and Bacteriophage Receptor in Vibrio cholerae O1
predicted summary: Vibrio cholerae lipopolysaccharide O1 antigen is a major target target of pathogens and the human immune system and is of critical importance for vaccine design and vaccine development. Here we identify phase Variant Phase Variants required for O-1 heterogeneity, manA and wbeL phase variants that are attenuated for Infectivity, providing functional evidence to further support the critical role of the O 1 Antigen biosynthetic locus for virulence. We provide the first report of phase variation modulating the capacity of V. influenzae to modulate its O-specificity. Our findings provide insights into the mechanism by which this organism can modulates Olfactory cells needed for infecting the host intestinal tract and escape predation by phagophages.

title:
Suboptimal Activation of Antigen-Specific CD4+
                    Effector Cells Enables Persistence of M. tuberculosis In
                    Vivo
predicted summary: Adaptive immunity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis controls progressive growth and disease but does not eradicate infection without ex vivo restimulation. We hypothesized that one mechanism whereby adaptive immunity prevents elimination is by restricting activation of antigen specific CD4+ effector T cells at the site of infection in the lung. Our results suggest that activating effects specific for Ag85B proteins may be effective strategy for the treatment of chronic pathogen-specific pathogenic bacteria. Inhibition of activated antifungal activators may also be a successful strategy to prevent elimination without apparent host effects.

title: Population Genetics of Plasmodium vivax in the Peruvian Amazon
predicted summary: Plasmodium vivax malaria remains a major health problem in Peru. We genotyped 292 isolates from Iquitos, the main city in the Peruvian Amazon region and 25 neighbouring periurban as well as rural villages along the Nauta Road between April and December 2008. Our data provide useful information to understand the dynamics of transmission dynamics and population structure providing useful insights into reservoir dynamics. Our results show that Pseudomonas senzatiella parasite population dynamics are important from public health perspective and for formulation of future control policies for malaria control strategies.

title: Conformational Change-Induced Repeat Domain Expansion Regulates Rap Phosphatase Quorum-Sensing Signal Receptors
predicted summary: The large family of Gram-positive receptors known as the GramSensing Protein family comprises receptor homologous to Rap proteins that regulate transcriptional activities by imported autoinducers termed autoinducer competence and sporulation factor PhrC. Here we present the crystal structure of RapJ complexed with the centrally important oligopeptide autoInducer competence Factor (CSF), a member of the PhR family. We show that Rap structures undergo radical conformational change-induced repeat domain expansion along the TPR superhelical axis. Comparative crystal structures reveal new intramolecular contacts that lock Rap molecules locked Rap cells in an inactive state, suggesting novel scaffold scaffolds could be used for engineering novel affinity scaffold-switchable affinity reagents for affinity products.

title: Bayesian Phylogeography Finds Its Roots
predicted summary: The geographical distribution of viruses has been frequently interpreted in light of their genetic histories. However, statistical approaches provide little insight into the temporal setting of the spatiotemporal settings of viral dispersal patterns. The introduction of probabilistic models of evolution offers unique opportunities to engage in this statistical endeavor. Here we present a Bayesian framework for the reconstruction of time-scaled viral distributions while accommodating phylogenetic uncertainty. This framework provides the ability to reconstruct timescale viral diffusion patterns that can be easily generalized to biogeogeography for many organisms. We describe how our framework will make an important asset in molecular epidemiological epidemiology that could be readily generalizable to generalize genetic data from genomic data.

title: Masculinization of the X Chromosome in the Pea Aphid
predicted summary: Aphids display an alternative mode of inheritance of chromosomes with differences between male-beneficial alleles and autosomes, suggesting that sexually antagonistic mutations accumulate differentially on the X and Autosome genomes. Using gene expression data from males of the pea aphid, we show that male genes should be more favorable to the spread of male beneficial genes than female genes. We argue that other mechanisms than the resolution of sexual conflicts may lead to conflicts raised by sexual antagonism, such as the alternation between sexual reproduction and reproductive reproduction. In contrast to predictions for standard systems, these results are not affected by the dominance of Mutations. Our results highlight the relevance of organisms displaying alternative modes of gene inheritance to understanding the forces shaping gene evolution.

title: SNF5 Is an Essential Executor of Epigenetic Regulation during Differentiation
predicted summary: Chromatin remodelers, such as the BAF complexes, regulate the accessibility of the transcription machinery to DNA regulatory regions and serve an instructive role for gene expression during cell differentiation. ChIP-sequencing experiments followed by extensive genome-wide analyses showed that SNF5 negatively regulates cell fate during differentiation by generating nucleosome-depleted regions (NDRs) at the regulatory sites of OCT4-activated target genes including PAX6 and NEUROG1, critical for cell survival during pluripotent stem cells. In vitro experiments were carried out assaying the extent to which the remodeling machinery changes the occupancy patterns of genes that were activated by the remodelling machinery. Here we demonstrate that transcription factors play dual roles during PlURIpotency by antagonizing the expression of targets activating genes. This study highlights the role of remodeling proteins and transcription Factors involved in the regulation of cell death chromatin configuration, which ultimately affects gene Expression during Cell Differentiation.

title: Transmission risk of two chikungunya lineages by invasive mosquito vectors from Florida and the Dominican Republic
predicted summary: Between 2014 and 2016 more than 3,800 imported human cases of chikungunya fever in Florida highlight the high risk for sustained local transmission of both emergent lineages of the virus. We examined whether local populations of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes show differences in susceptibility to infection, rapid viral dissemination into the hemocoel, and transmission to emerging lines of vectors, Indian Ocean genotype (IOC) strains that were lower than for Florida vector populations. Our results suggest that geographic variation in vector competence among mosquito populations may contribute to regional differences between geographic competence between mosquito population populations from the Dominican Republic and other regions of Florida.

title: Atrophy of skin-draining lymph nodes predisposes for impaired immune responses to secondary infection in mice with chronic intestinal nematode infection
predicted summary: Intestinal intestinal nematodes suppress immune responses in the context of allergy, gut inflammation, secondary infection and vaccination. In this study, we show that chronic intestinal infection leads to reduced peripheral responses to vaccination following Bacillus Calmette-Guerin vaccination in mice that are chronically infected with the intestinal intestinal parasite Heligmosomides polygyrus. We found that superficial skin-draining lymph nodes (LNs) draining the footpad injection site do not reach the same amount of lymphocytes upon subsequent BCG infection, suggesting that time after de-worming is critical to restore full-scale LN Cellularity. Our findings suggest that Chronic intestinal infections lead to decreased peripheral lymphatic responses at these sites due to a generalized reduction in lymph cells available for vaccination responses, which reduces the efficacy of vaccine responses.

title: DENV up-regulates the HMG-CoA reductase activity through the impairment of AMPK phosphorylation: A potential antiviral target
predicted summary: Changes in HMGCR activity have been associated with the formation of replicative complexes necessary for viral replication. Inhibition of enzyme activity in endoplasmic reticulum of dengue virus-infected cells leads to cholesterol-rich environment required for replication pathways. These results suggest that inhibition mechanisms involved in host metabolism during replication are mediated through inhibition of compound C inhibitor compounds. Here, we show that the elevated activity of compounds involved by compound inhibition exerts antiviral effects against host cells by increasing cholesterol levels required to promote replication and increase the number of viral genome copies formed. Our results provide new insights into the Mechanisms involved involved during the replication cycle and identify new potential targets for DENV replication targets.

title: Dek overexpression in murine epithelia increases overt esophageal squamous cell carcinoma incidence
predicted summary: Esophageal cancer occurs as either squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) or adenocarcinoma, which comprise almost 90% of cases worldwide and have less than 15% five-year survival rate despite available treatments. Identification of new drivers and therapeutic targets is critical for improving outcomes. Here we report that expression of the human DEK oncogene is strongly upregulated in SCC development based on data obtained from the Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA). We have generated and validated genetic mouse models referred to as Bi-L-Dek Transgenic Mouse model to demonstrate that Dek overexpression in the basal cells of stratified epithelium is sufficient to promote growth and development in vitro. Our data provide insight into the consequences of high expression levels in human cells adica adica cells that mimic human skin cells. Furthermore, high DeK expression resulted in hyperplasia in cells mimicking porcine skin cell cultures.

title: A Model of Compound Heterozygous, Loss-of-Function Alleles Is Broadly Consistent with Observations from Complex-Disease GWAS Datasets
predicted summary: Complex disease Risk in humans remains poorly understood. Genomic genomic regions harboring genetic variants associated with complex disease risk remain poorly studied. However, the genetic components contributing to Complex Disease Risk remain unknown. Here we use forward simulation to model a genomic region evolving under the balance between deleterious mutation and Gaussian stabilizing selection. We demonstrate that the model of gene-based recessivity has qualitative effects on several relevant aspects of the population genetic architecture of complex traits. Our results suggest the need for improved statistical tools for genome-wide association Estimation and the power of statistical tests for genotype partitioning along the allele frequency spectrum. In this study, we describe multiple genetic and demographic models that relate genetic processes to the maintenance

title: Coordinated regulation of core and accessory genes in the multipartite genome of Sinorhizobium fredii
predicted summary: The soybean microsymbiont Sinorhizobium fredii benefits from having accessory genes during niche adaptations to new niches. However, it remains unclear how accessory proteins can be linked with the regulatory network when adapting to niche adaption. Here we determined Hierarchical Core/Accessory subsets in the multipartite pangenome (composed of genes from the chromosome, zinc transporter and accessory multi-drug efflux system) shared by two soybean strains at midlog growth phases and in stationary growth Phases obtained by comparing 12-SINORHizoBium genomes of S. fungi obtained at medium-log Growth Phase. These results highlight the importance of integrative regulation of accessory components involved in host-specific adaptation and provide insights into the regulation networks involved during adaptation.

title: Replication and Active Partition of Integrative and Conjugative Elements (ICEs) of the SXT/R391 Family: The Line between ICEs and Conjugative Plasmids Is Getting Thinner
predicted summary: Integrative and Conjugative Elements (ICEs) of the SXT/R391 family disseminate multidrug resistance among pathogenic Gammaproteobacteria such as Vibrio cholerae by binding to other bacteria by conjugation upon cell division. In vitro experiments show that the ICE R391, provided by Providencia rettgeri, is highly stable upon Cell Division. We found that deletion of either the relaxin-encoding gene traI or origin of transfer (oriT) abolishes conjugative transfer but instead stabilizes the frequency of loss of its circular circular form, which is thought to be non-replicative, hence expected to remain highly unstable. Here we find that srpMRC contributes strongly to stabilization of single-stranded DNA translocation from host cells through the matingpore.

title: The thermodynamics of Pr55Gag-RNA interaction regulate the assembly of HIV
predicted summary: The interactions that occur during HIV assembly are essential elements that facilitate viral biogenesis. However, mechanistic details of these interactions are not clearly defined. Here we have overcome previous limitations in producing large quantities of full-length Pr55Gag required for isothermal thermodynamic studies by mimicking the interactions between Adenosine(A)-containing RNA binding in immature HIV. We have shown here that the temperature response that occurs during viral assembly is enhanced sequentially by the oligomerization of ChIPRNA. Our data provide direct evidence on how nucleic acids sequence sequences regulate the amount of heat released during the thermogenesis of HIV genome assembly. These results suggest the potential unknown role of p6 during this thermogenic process may help facilitate the process of virus assembly during genome selection.

title: IL-10 and NOS2 Modulate Antigen-Specific Reactivity and Nerve Infiltration by T Cells in Experimental Leprosy
predicted summary: Tuberculoid tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium leprae infections. The development and maintenance of chronic inflammation involves ongoing networks of communication via immune modulators. IL-10 has immunosuppressive properties and genetic variants associated with resistance and inflammation have been implicated with neurological involvement. Here we investigated the role of immunomodulators in the evolution and Maintenance of granulomatous inflammation during early infection, peak development, and chronic infections using mice deficient in both Inducible nitric oxide synthase (NOS2/) and Chronic inflammation. This study provides insight into the mechanisms involved in inflammation and resistance development in chronic forms of M. leprosy and presents a new model for investigating the pathogenesis of neurodevelopmental involvement in neuroplasticity.

title: Stage-Specific Inhibition of MHC Class I Presentation by the Epstein-Barr Virus BNLF2a Protein during Virus Lytic Cycle
predicted summary: EpsteinBarr virus encodes proteins encoded during early phase viral replication that allow virally infected cells to be recognized and eliminated by CD8+ T cell targets specific for EBV-encoded indicator antigens. Ectopic expression of this protein causes decreased surface MHC class I expression and inhibits presentation of indicator proteins to CD4+ cells. We have recently identified the immune transporter involved in antiviral signaling pathways associated with early stage replication, BNLF2a, which is expressed during Early Phase replication. Here we sought to examine the role of early protein expression during late phase replication by comparing the ability of late expression-specific markers expressed by both wild-type virus-transformed virus transformants and wild type virus transformed viruses to recognize early proteins specific to specific targets Specific for specific markers identified by late stage viralLY expressed proteins. Inhibited Expression of both early and late proteins was found to play roles downstream of the transporters involved with peptide-binding functions involved during the production of indicators

title: Transient Duplication-Dependent Divergence and Horizontal Transfer Underlie the Evolutionary Dynamics of Bacterial Cell–Cell Signaling
predicted summary: Rap–Phr cell–cell signaling pathways have undergone massive expansion independently independently in Bacillius subtilis lineages alone. Rap expansion requires acquisition of a novel homologous pathway and divergence of specificity during evolutionary shifts in Specificity. title: Hard Selective Sweep and Ectopic Gene Conversion in a Gene Cluster Affording Environmental Adaptation

Together, these results provide insight into how evolutionary evolutions contributes to the evolutionary maintenance of gene duplicates that are conserved by natural Selection for enhanced genes.

title: Trypanosome Motion Represents an Adaptation to the Crowded Environment of the Vertebrate Bloodstream
predicted summary: Only few parasites survive the harsh physical conditions within vertebrate bloodstream and prosper despite being constantly attacked by host antibodies. Here we show that the mode and dynamics of trypanosome locomotion are characteristic traits of life within highly viscous environments. By using high-speed fluorescence microscopy and ordered micropillar array arrays, we demonstrate how flagellates adapt their mode of motility to the density of cells contained within blood cells. We show here that flagellates swim backwards in order to avoid getting trapped. Importantly, the presence of particles with the shape, size and spacing of blood cell structures is required and sufficient for them to reach maximum forward velocity. Our simulation results provide a functional simulation method for trying parasitic bacteria with complex swimming strategies within crowded environments with low Reynolds numbers.

title: Optimal Recall from Bounded Metaplastic Synapses: Predicting Functional Adaptations in Hippocampal Area CA3

Our framework organizes existing data about the regulation of excitability, feedback inhibition inhibition and network oscillations in area CA3, and provides novel insights into how memories can be efficiently readout efficiently with biologically plausible neural dynamics that implement approximate approaches to solve this problem efficiently efficiently.

title: Trading Speed and Accuracy by Coding Time: A Coupled-circuit Cortical Model

title: Rodent control to fight Lassa fever: Evaluation and lessons learned from a 4-year study in Upper Guinea

Our results demonstrate that chemical treatment provides effective tools for controlling local rodente populations, as measured by bait intake varied between 3.6–16.7% before Treatment and decreased significantly to 1–2% after Treatment.

title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection modulates adipose tissue biology

title: Genetic exchanges are more frequent in bacteria encoding capsules

We found that bacteria encoding capsules have more antibiotic resistance genes than bacteria with capsular systems, especially those involved efflux pumps. Our results are valid for Bacteriobacterium independently independently of their ability to be naturally transformable.

title: A Spatial Model of Mosquito Host-Seeking Behavior
predicted summary: Mosquito host-seeking behavior and heterogeneity in host distribution are important factors in mosquito-borne infections such as dengue fever, malaria, chikungunya, and West Nile virus transmission dynamics. The model includes hosts generated by spatially distributed hosts, wind velocity, mosquito behavior depending on both the wind and the odor plume. Our results show that two different models of host finding are capable of producing comparable results given appropriate parameter choices and that host Finding is optimized by FlyingAcross the Wind until the host is intercepted.

title: Multiple Pairwise Analysis of Non-homologous Centromere Coupling Reveals Preferential Chromosome Size-Dependent Interactions and a Role for Bouquet Formation in Establishing the Interaction Pattern

We found the presence of the synaptonemal complex protein Zip1 plays a role in the establishment of spatiotemporal interactions between these yeast CentROMERS early in early early embryonic development. Using this variant of 3C-qPCR assays, we found that the size-dependent interaction patterns are observed in diploid-diploid cells as well as wild-type Diploid cell lines, but abolishing bouquet-deficient mutants abolished them.

title: Determinants of drug-target interactions at the single cell level
predicted summary: Drug incorporation occurs within cells three orders of magnitude slower than observed in vitro due to anomalous drug diffusion within cell nuclei. This slow diffusion leads to virtually irreversible binding of drugs to specific DNA targets in cells. Here, we show that nonspecific interactions drive slow Drug diffusion manifesting as slow reaction front propagation manifested by slow reactions between cells specific targets. We identify differential compartment effects in different compartment compartments that influence drug-target interactions. Our results provide basis for a comprehensive model of the mechanisms involved in intracellular drug incorporations and the consequences of these processes on drug Binding reactions. These findings provide bases for comprehensive models on the role of non-specific drugs and macromolecules.

title: Mapping the geographical distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon using parasitological, serological, and clinical evidence to exclude other causes of lymphedema
predicted summary: Podoconiosis is a nonfilarial elephantia which causes massive swelling of the lower legs. It was identified as neglected tropical disease by WHO in 2011. This study was conducted house-to-house in Cameroon to map the geographic distribution and distribution distribution. We found low prevalence but almost nationwide distribution among individuals with lymphoedema. Our study provides insights into the Geographic Distribution of podoconiatic Elephantiopsis globally. Using qPCR analyses of night blood samples collected housetohouse, we stratified the country by environmental risk factors associated with the disease. title: High Rate of Recent Transposable Element–Induced Adaptation in Drosophila melanogaster
predicted summary: Transposable elements (TEs) are potent sources of mutations, but their contribution to recent adaptive evolution has never been systematically assessed. We identify 13 putatively adaptive elements that increased population frequency sharply after spreading outwards. Our results also suggest that these adaptive changes arise more often from standing variants than new mutational changes. The majority of these adaptive elements are likely involved in regulatory changes consistent with these elements playing a role in adaptation to temperate climates inconsistent with the number of fixed elements present in the genome.

title: Hyperdiverse Gene Cluster in Snail Host Conveys Resistance to Human Schistosome Parasites

title: Update on the current status of onchocerciasis in Côte d’Ivoire following 40 years of intervention: Progress and challenges

title: From Birdsong to Human Speech Recognition: Bayesian Inference on a Hierarchy of Nonlinear Dynamical Systems
predicted summary: One difficulty in deciphering the exact mechanisms by which humans recognize speech is that there are scarce experimental findings at a neuronal microscopic level. Here we show that our understanding of speech learning and recognition may be vastly improved by looking at an animal model, the songbird, which faces the same challenge as humans: to learn complex auditory input in an online fashion. We translate birdsong models into novel human sound learning models with an emphasis on speech recognition and learning systems that can learn speech samples rapidly and recognize them robustly even when words are spoken by different speakers and with different accents—an everyday situation in which current state-of-the-art speech Recognition models often fail. title: Restriction of Francisella novicida Genetic Diversity during Infection of the Vector Midgut

title: Assessment and Treatment of Pain during Treatment of Buruli Ulcer

HCP reported fear of side effects of pain medications, shortage and irregularities in supply of Pain medication supplies, and time constraints among medical doctors for Pain Management. title: High-Resolution Genome-Wide Dissection of the Two Rules of Speciation in Drosophila

We find that hybrid male incompatibilities outnumber dominant ones, whereas dominant introgressions cause Hybrid Male Steriles. Our results thus confirm the large-X effect—substitution of one species' X chromosome segments for another species has disproportionately large effects on hybrid fitness.

title: Up-regulation of FOXD1 by YAP alleviates senescence and osteoarthritis

Here, we identified a critical role for Yes-associated protein (YAP), an important effector of Hippo signaling, in maintaining youthful state of human stem cells (hMSCs), maintaining ageless state and ameliorating osteoporosis in mice. Our findings reveal the role of Yes–FOXD1 gene regulation regulators as potential targets for gene therapy strategies to alleviate osteopathic disorders. We found that inhibition of expression of genes that regulate the Expression of forkhead box D1 abolished premature development of aged cells. Moreover, intraarticular administration of vector vectors encoding genes with genes encoded by Yes proteins activated ageing stem cell development and alleviation.

title: Unraveling the role of the secretor antigen in human rotavirus attachment to histo-blood group antigens
predicted summary: Rotavirus is the leading agent responsible for acute gastroenteritis in young children, with the P[8] genotype accounting for more than 80% of infections in humans. However, differences in binding affinity between members differed markedly among member lines belonging to distinct lineages. Here we show that both protein binding proteins interact directly with each other through binding pockets shared by members belonging within different strains. We also provide insights into the role and potential applications of milk proteins as antiviral targets. Our results provide insight into possible applications for milk protein as a building block of Type-1 proteins that could be utilized as Antivirals against infectious diseases.

title: Efficient Olfactory Coding in the Pheromone Receptor Neuron of a Moth
predicted summary: Sensory neurons encode natural auditory and visual stimuli through adaptive adaptations to their natural stimulus characteristics. Our results demonstrate that both the statistical properties of the predicted plume characteristics are in good agreement with those measured experimentally in the field under experimental conditions. These results should stimulate further quantitative studies on how neurons adapt physiologically to plumage characteristics that are most informative for the ‘sniffer’.

title: Low Levels of Awareness Despite High Prevalence of Schistosomiasis among Communities in Nyalenda Informal Settlement, Kisumu City, Western Kenya
predicted summary: Intestinal intestinal schistosomiasis is widely distributed around Lake Victoria in Kenya where about 16 million people in 56 districts are at risk of infection with over 9.1 million infected. Its existence in rural settings has been extensively studied compared to urban settings where there is limited information about the disease coupled with low level of awareness. This study assessed community awareness on existence, signs and symptoms, causes, transmission, control and risk factors for contracting intestinal intestinal parasites to identify knowledge gaps that need to be addressed in order to augment prevention efforts and control interventions in informal settings such as informal urban settlements of Kisumu city.

title: Influenza virus differentially activates mTORC1 and mTORC2 signaling to maximize late stage replication
predicted summary: Influenza viruses utilize signaling machinery called translation machinery to regulate viral replication, growth and motility during viral infection. However, the mechanisms that regulate translation pathways during influenza virus infection have not been established. Here we show that transcription machinery regulates translation proteins upon influenza infection, which is required for viral protein expression and replication. Inhibitory substrates involved in translation regulation can promote translation and translate viral proteins into translation products that support translational translation mechanisms. We also show here that mutant strains lacking both inhibitory substrate components Rictor and Torin differentially induce translation substrate activation by influenza viruses. Moreover, inhibition of the viral substrateTOR inhibitor REDD1 by the virus M2 protein also promotes transcription downstream downstream AKT activity by viral cells.

title: Identification of a Topological Characteristic Responsible for the Biological Robustness of Regulatory Networks
predicted summary: It is widely believed that the topological characteristics of biological regulatory networks determine their dynamic behavior, yet the actual mechanism remains poorly understood. Here, we define a novel structural feature termed regulation entropy to quantitatively assess the influence of regulatory features on biological robustness. Using the cell-cycle control networks of budding yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) and the fission yeast Schuster pombe as examples, our work establishes the association between regulation feature and dynamic stability of the regulatory network topology. We further establish general generality of this approach with broad spectrum biological and random networks, suggesting that regulation features are an effective order parameter in evaluating robustity in biological systems biology.

title: Determining Treatment Needs at Different Spatial Scales Using Geostatistical Model-Based Risk Estimates of Schistosomiasis
predicted summary: Schistosomiasis control is going to scale with repeated large-scale administration of praziquantel (a safe and highly efficacious drug) to at-risk populations. The strategy of choice is preventive chemotherapy, which is often based on prevalence data summarized at arbitrarily chosen administrative levels. We used spatially explicit risk estimates to classify each country into distinct endemicity classes that govern the frequency of treatment needs for the school-aged population according to World Health Organization guidelines. Our results revealed that most countries are classified as moderately severe (prevalence 10–50%) while four countries (i.e., Ghana, Liberia, Mozambique and Sierra Leone) are Highly Endemistic (>50% highly endemisic).

title: Active Trachoma and Ocular Chlamydia trachomatis Infection in Two Gambian Regions: On Course for Elimination by 2020?

We found that only 0.3% (3/940) of children aged 1–9 years had clinical signs of C. TRACHOmatiS infection. Our results suggest that repeated infection is required for progression to blinding sequelae in both regions may lead to unnecessary treatment.

title: Laboratory Colonisation and Genetic Bottlenecks in the Tsetse Fly Glossina pallidipes
predicted summary: Glossina pallidipes is a vector vector of human and animal African trypanosomiasis in eastern Africa. The source population of this colony is unclear and its genetic diversity has not previously been evaluated and compared to field populations. Genetic diversity associated with traits important for Sterile Insect Technique programs may potentially have been lost during this genetic bottleneck which could lead to suboptimal competitiveness of colonY males in the field. We performed classical population genetics analyses and combined historical and genetic data using Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC). We found that the foundation and establishment of the IAEA colonial area of origin is located in north Zimbabwe and the Kenya/Uganda border area. Our results suggest that Genetic Bottleneck may have resulted in loss of 35.7% of alleles and 54% expected heterozygosity associated traits that are Important for SIT Programs.

title: Wikipedia Usage Estimates Prevalence of Influenza-Like Illness in the United States in Near Real-Time
predicted summary: While up-to-date information is critical, traditional surveillance systems can have data availability lags of up to two weeks. We developed Poisson models that accurately estimate influenza-like illness activity in the United States by monitoring the rate of particular Wikipedia articles being accessed each day between December 2007 and August 2013 and compare these data to official influenza activity levels provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). We found that Wikipedia usage accurately estimated the week of peak influenza activities 17% more often than Google Flu Trends data and was often more accurate in its measure of influenza intensity than google flu trends data, suggesting that this method could potentially be implemented for continuous monitoring and provide support for traditional influenza surveillance tools.

title: A Novel Role for the NLRC4 Inflammasome in Mucosal Defenses against the Fungal Pathogen Candida albicans

NLRC4 is important for controlling candidemia and protects against systemic dissemination of infection. Inhibition of Candida immune responses results in severely attenuated antifungal responses in oral tissues, as well as severely compromised pro-inflammatory responses.
