Here we investigated the mechanisms of antigen presentation by targeting CD4+ T-cell receptor-bound CD14+ cells and macrophages in peripheral blood samples obtained from active PTB patients, healthy donors, and umbilical cords. Results suggest that there is a relatively low level of MTB-specific CD44+ CD47+ Monocyte-positive rates after treatment. These results provide valuable insights into the Mechanisms of Antibiotic Presentation in advanced and convalescent patients. Our results show that antibiotic drugs induce Live Bacillary Bacteromycobacterium induces necrosis in CD34+ moncells during treatment, which is likely related to the inhibition of live bacteria.

title: Oxidative Stress and DNA Lesions: The Role of 8-Oxoguanine Lesions in Trypanosoma cruzi Cell Viability
predicted summary: 8-oxoguanine is the base that is most susceptible to hydrogen peroxidation due to its low redox potential. It generates double-strand breaks during replication, which can result in genomic instability and lead to cell death. Here we investigated the role of the enzyme MutT during parasitemia caused by Trypanosoma cruzi parasite infection of mammalian cells. We determined whether Mutt-expressing cells differed markedly from wild-type parasitocytes when exposed intracellularly. These results suggest the importance of this enzyme repair system for cell viability of parasitosome infections. Inhibitor cells heterologously expressed either overexpressing the MutX enzyme or MutMTH enzyme. Our results demonstrate the significance of MutTA repair enzyme protein levels to determine parasitogenicity.

title: GRHL3 binding and enhancers rearrange as epidermal keratinocytes transition between functional states
predicted summary: Differentiating progenitor keratinocytes form complements of typical enhancers and super-enhancers that are unique for each cell state linking genes that confer functions associated with cell lineage commitments to differentiation and migration transitions. Here we show that when cells enter transient transition states such as migration they reorganize their transcription factors to regulate their transition from differentiation to migration. We show here that transcription factor binding regulates both transition and transition between different cell states as well as transitioning cells into Transient Transition states. Our results provide insight into how transcription Factor binding molecules regulate cellline transition transition pathways and how they regulate gene expression involved in cellLINE transition Transition pathways.

title: Inactivation of p53 Rescues the Maintenance of High Risk HPV DNA Genomes Deficient in Expression of E6
predicted summary: The human papillomavirus genome undergoes three distinct stages of replication: establishment, maintenance and amplification. We show that the HPV16 E6 protein is required for maintenance of extrachromosomal copies of the human genome. Inactivation of p53 was found to correlate with the ability of E6, independent of inactivating protein degradation proteins, to maintain copies identical to copies obtained from the wild-type genomes maintained at copy number comparable to copy numbers obtained at copies similar to those obtained with wild type copies at early passages. Based upon mutational analyses, we found that deletion-dependent degradation of proteins involved in maintenance proteins required proteins to support maintenance maintained copies maintained by these genes. These results suggest that additional functions independent functions Independently independent function proteins may contribute independently to maintenance

title: POT1a and Components of CST Engage Telomerase and Regulate Its Activity in Arabidopsis
predicted summary: Protection of Telomeres 1 (POT1) is a conserved nucleic acid binding protein implicated in both replication and chromosome end protection. We previously showed that POT1a associates with the TER1 telomerase RNP as well as STN1 and CTC1. Here we further dissect the function and interactions of Pot1/STN1/TEN1 complex proteins involved in the maintenance of long repeat arrays by proteasomes. Our data support two-state model in which pot1/Arabidopsis plants promote extendable repeat states via contacts with their respective receptor binding sites. Inhibitory interactions between pot1 mutant mutants revealed that Pot1A promotes extended Repeat array synthesis by activating repeat addition processivity in vitro by stimulating the production of Long RepeatArrays, likely by augmenting repeat Addition Processivity.

title: A Temporal Role Of Type I Interferon Signaling in CD8+ T Cell Maturation during Acute West Nile Virus Infection
predicted summary: Typhibition of type I IFN signaling was associated with markedly enhanced viral burden and altered adaptive immune responses at discrete stages of infection by West Nile virus (WNV). Here we describe temporal functions of Type IIFN Signaling in the context of WNV infection in mice that lack CD8- dendritic cells. We show that Blockade of Typ1-5A3 inhibited maturation of antiviralCD8+ T cells at distinct stages distinct from the initial priming event. Our results suggest that blocking type IIIII regulates later maturatory responses prior to and after virus infection. Moreover, blocking TypIIII inhibition initiated developmental responses with dysfunctional responses and phenotypic markers suggesting exhaustion

title: PRL1, an RNA-Binding Protein, Positively Regulates the Accumulation of miRNAs and siRNAs in Arabidopsis
predicted summary: The evolutionary conserved protein PRL1 plays important roles in immunity and development. Here we show that prl1 is required for the accumulation of microRNA primary transcripts (miRNAs) and small interfering proteins (SIPs). Our results suggest that PRLP1 may function cooperatively as a general factor to enhance DCLR1 activity. PrLP1/CDC5 interacts with PRLK1 and regulates both miRNA accumulation and processing efficiency of priRNA primacy transcript levels, which results in synergistic effects on DCRL1. We further reveal the genetic interaction between PrLK1/cdc5 and DCLK3/CDC5, which cooperated together as co-factors together to Enhance DCLL1 Activity.

title: Noise-invariant Neurons in the Avian Auditory Cortex: Hearing the Song in Noise
predicted summary: Noise-invariant neural responses are well described in the visual system but high-level auditory neurons that can represent the same behaviorally relevant signal in a range of listening conditions have yet to be discovered. Here we show that noise invariance is partly achieved by selectively responding to long sounds with sharp spectral structure. This noise filtering algorithm can be used as well as other state-of-the-art de-noising algorithms to separate song or speech from noise. We also show how noise-filtering neurons can explain Noise Invariants by separating song stimuli presented in silence and over the background of naturalistic noises.

title: Molecular Mimicry by an F-Box Effector of Legionella pneumophila Hijacks a Conserved Polyubiquitination Machinery within Macrophages and Protozoa
predicted summary: Legionella pneumophila recruits polyubiquitinated proteins within macrophages, Dictyostelium discoideum, and Acanthamoeba within within 5 min of extracellular attachment to host host bacteria. Ankyrin B (AnkB) is essential for intracellular bacterial proliferation within evolutionarily distant hosts such as microorganisms within aquatic environments. We show here that the presence of conserved residues of the mutant mutant Mut9L10P/AA mutant proteins is required for rapid acquisition and acquisition of PolyubiQUINEXY proteins by Enterobacteria pneumoniabacterium-containing vacuoles (LCV) within intrapulmonary Legionnaires disease hosts within the mouse model of Legionaires disease. Here we demonstrate that deletion of gene expression mutations promotes rapid recruitment and recruitment of polyvacuolar bacteria within colonized hosts. In addition, deletion

title: Automated and Accurate Estimation of Gene Family Abundance from Shotgun Metagenomes
predicted summary: Shotgun Metagenome Annotation Pipeline (ShotMAP) is an analytically flexible, end-to-end annotation pipeline that can be implemented either on a local computer or cloud compute clusters. ShotMAP uses statistical simulations to rigorously assess whether different annotation databases impact annotation accuracy and speed, given parameters of input data like read length and library size. We find that gut microbiota collected from Crohn’s disease patients differ functionally from gut bacteria collected either from ulcerative colitis patients or healthy controls, with differential abundance of metabolic pathways related to host host-microbiome interactions that may serve as putative biomarkers of disease. However, little is known about how decisions made during annotation impact the reliability of annotation results.

title: ClassTR: Classifying Within-Host Heterogeneity Based on Tandem Repeats with Application to Mycobacterium tuberculosis Infections
predicted summary: Complex infection is increasingly recognized as a determinant of treatment outcome for infections like tuberculosis, which arises through mutations within host hosts and reinfections that result in mixed infections. Understanding the mechanisms driving within-host diversity is critical for understanding the natural history of disease trends and effects of interventions. Here we describe ClassTR, MLVA genotyping technique used to distinguish complex infections from clonally heterogeneous infections by using tandem repeat evolution data collected from isolates collected in populations collected during treatment. By explicitly modeling tandem repetition evolution, Complex infections are resolved into their constituent strains by assigning alternate classification to 18 of the 92 complex infection sequences, suggesting important differences in treatment outcomes and outcomes associated with Treatment outcomes. Our results suggest that this method can improve our understanding of how pathogen diversity affects clinical outcomes across populations.

title: Epstein-Barr Virus Latency in B Cells Leads to Epigenetic Repression and CpG Methylation of the Tumour Suppressor Gene Bim
predicted summary: EpsteinBarr virus induces epigenetic regulation of the pro-apoptotic Bcl-2-family member Bim that enhances cell survival. This regulation involves the activities of latency-associated virus gene products EBNA3A and EBA3C and appears to be predominantly directed towards Regulation of Cancer suppressor gene expression. Here we show that EBV initiates events that lead to transcriptional inhibition of this gene promoter. Our results suggest that these events may have important implications for understanding the mechanisms involved in this regulation. Inhibitors of DNAmethyltransferase enzyme enzymes may also play roles in the Regulation pathways involved during the early stages of development and pathogenesis of disease.

title: Emergence of a Small-World Functional Network in Cultured Neurons
predicted summary: Complex functional networks evolved from isolated neurons during early developmental stages, yet little is known about how complex functional network structure evolves during maturation. In vitro cultured neurons exhibit complex connectivity properties similar to those found in vivo neurons. It provides an ideal platform for observation of developmental changes in neuronal connectivity. Network properties were quantified using graph theory and used to compare cultures obtained from young neurons obtained at different stages of development during the first 5 weeks of Development during vegetative growth. We found that neurons evolve from random seeding to small-world topologies that balance integration of network areas with segregation of highly connected areas and efficiency increases with age, suggesting complex intrinsic biological mechanisms responsible for the evolution of functional connectivity between neurons at mature age.

title: Sexuality Generates Diversity in the Aflatoxin Gene Cluster: Evidence on a Global Scale
predicted summary: Aflatoxins are carcinogenic compounds produced by Aspergillus flavus and A. minisclerotigenes in oil-rich seed and grain crops and are a serious problem in agriculture. Sexual reproduction occurs between individuals belonging to different vegetative compatibility groups (VCGs). We examined natural genetic variation in 758 isolates from single peanut fields in the United States, Africa (Benin), Argentina (Córdoba), Australia (Queensland) and India (Karnataka). The reproductive nature of the population (more sexually versus more reproductive) was associated with higher recombination rates and less significant differences between populations from each locality/species. Our results suggest that genetically reproduced individuals from different localities play important roles in fixing and maintenance of aflatoxin diversity in these agriculturally important species.

title: Reversible and Rapid Transfer-RNA Deactivation as a Mechanism of Translational Repression in Stress
predicted summary: Regulation at the level of translation provides the necessary plasticity for immediate changes of cellular activities and protein levels. In this study we demonstrate that exposure to stress results in rapid changes in translation by activating aminoacyl-ends of all transfer-RNA (tRNA) transcriptional activity at low metabolic costs. Through this mechanism the eukaryotic cell dynamically represses translation and rapidly repairable translation-mediated changes. We demonstrate here that stress-induced changes regulate translation within conserved single-stranded 3′-CCA termini of TransferRNA transferRNAs, thus blocking their use during translation. These changes are quickly repaired by the CCA-adding enzyme, angiogenin, which deactivates transcriptionally blocks translation proteins that are used for translationATPATPTransferase.

title: The DAF-16/FOXO Transcription Factor Functions as a Regulator of Epidermal Innate Immunity
predicted summary: The Caenorhabditis elegans transcription factor DAF-16 is critical for diverse biological processes, including longevity and stress resistance conferring resistance to killing by pathogenic bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterococcus faecalis pathogens. Inhibition of this signaling cascade promotes activation of transcription factors downstream downstream of the cell membrane pathways involved in epidermal damage responses following fungal infection and wounding in wild animals. Here, we demonstrate that the transcription Factor EGL-30-Ca2+-BLI-3-CCST-1-DAF-16 gene regulates the release of reactive oxygen species in the epidermis after Fungal infections. Our results suggest that this gene is required for survival following infection, which is independent of previously unknown mechanisms involved downstream pathways.

title: MoSET1 (Histone H3K4 Methyltransferase in Magnaporthe oryzae) Regulates Global Gene Expression during Infection-Related Morphogenesis
predicted summary: Mutant mutant mutants of Magnaporthe oryzae showed the most severe defects in infection-related gene expression defects, including conidiation and appressorium formation. These results suggest that MoSET1 plays an important epigenetic mark for infection processes including signal perception and resistance against host-specific resistance. Lack of moSET1, however, resulted in up-regulation of significant portions of the Microbial pathogen genes during vegetative growth. Inhibition of histone H3K4methyltransferase activity led to increased expression of a substantial portion of genes involved during infection. This suggests that lack of MoSet1 disruptants may play roles either directly or more likely indirectly indirectly on gene regulation. Here we report that Mutations lacking Mutants were still infectious on the super-susceptible barley cultivar Nigrate.

title: Evaluating Paratransgenesis as a Potential Control Strategy for African Trypanosomiasis
predicted summary: Genetic modification strategies are currently being developed to reduce transmission of vector-borne diseases, including African trypanosomiasis, to control vector transmission among vector hosts. Paratransgenic strategies involve modification of the bacteria Sodalis into the host population by Wolbachia bacteria, which can then be driven into host host reservoir hosts by Cytoplasmic Incompatibility-conferring products. To evaluate the effectiveness of paratransgenetic strategies in controlling vector infection among humans and animals, we developed mathematical models of malaria transmission between humans, mammals, and animal reservoir host hosts, using empirical estimates of experimental parameters of antibiotic resistance parameters. We found that paraTransgenes are effective at controlling experimental infection, provided that additional mortality caused by extra mortality is low and parasitic infections are low. Our results show that ParaTransGenetic Strategies have the potential to Eliminate malaria Transmission among tsetse.

title: Structural and Functional Characterization of a Caenorhabditis elegans Genetic Interaction Network within Pathways
predicted summary: Genetic interactions are defined when mutation of one gene modifies expression associated with the Mut Mutation of another gene. Genome-wide efforts to map genetic interactions revealed structural and functional properties of genes and networks belonging to two distinct classes of Genetic Interaction Networks (GIs). This provides insights into the mechanisms underlying robustness of yeast against genetic and environmental insults, as well as the link existing between genotype and phenotypic manifestations. Our study provides the first structurally-structured structural mapping of genetic interaction networks within pathways of nematode Caenorhabditis elegans suggesting mechanisms linking genes within proteins and network structures. We identify and characterize six distinct classifications belonging proteins belonging within Protein-protein interaction dense dense Subnetworks (PDS), including protein interactions dense subnetwork interactions and pathways, molecular and biological functions, gene essentiality and Pleiotropy.

title: A survey of inter-individual variation in DNA methylation identifies environmentally responsive co-regulated networks of epigenetic variation in the human genome
predicted summary: Variably Methylated Regions (VMRs) are clusters of CpGs with high interindividual epigenetic variation that differ between cell types but differ strongly between cells. VMR networks have low heritability, differing between Cell Types and are sensitive to environmental conditions. By culturing genetically-identical cells undervarying environments, we show that environmental factors underlie this variation. Our findings provide a detailed map of common epigenic variation within the human genome that shows both genetic and environmental causes underlies these variations. This map provides insight into the mechanisms underpinning these networks, suggesting that both Genetic and Environmental causes Underlie variation at these sites are responsible for variation involved in the regulation of tissue growth.

title: Prefrontal Markers and Cognitive Performance Are Dissociated during Progressive Dopamine Lesion
predicted summary: Progressive progressive progressive dopaminergic lesions are thought to directly influence the neurophysiological mechanisms of performance monitoring and cognitive control—two processes critically linked in many neurological and psychiatric conditions. However, the working model of this system as a whole remains poorly understood. We provide longitudinal longitudinal recordings of frontal markers over many months during progressive Progressive Progressive Parkinson’s Disease in non-human primates that fail to support this causal chain between frontals function and cognition. Our results suggest that functional markers of cognitive function are not directly predictive of Parkinson Parkinson disease, suggesting they are engaged in complex nonlinear sets of mechanisms involved in the brain responses to Parkinsonism. These results challenge the direct causal link between these mechanisms and neurobiological markers throughout progressive Parkinsons disease progression and Cognitive Control.

title: Saccharomyces cerevisiae DNA Ligase IV Supports Imprecise End Joining Independently of Its Catalytic Activity
predicted summary: DNA double-strand breaks are repair joints between DNA Double-Standard Breaks (DSBs). This repair repair mechanism is catalyzed by DNA Ligase IV (Dnl4) that functions independently of its catabolic activity. However, the role of DNA-ligased DNA repair has mainly been studied using gene deletions. Here, we show that both mutant mutants heterozygously recruited to Double Strikes and mutant strains hyper-recruited to double doublestretch Repair joints differ markedly different than wild-type DnL4-catalytically inactivated homologous DNA Repair Complexes, suggesting differences between mutant-induced NHEJ activity in vitro and non-homologously active mutant regions. Furthermore, our findings suggest that mutagenic end joining occurs independently independent of catATPalysis activity-dependent repair mechanisms, likely by a mechanism that involves DNA

title: Patterns of Migration and Risks Associated with Leprosy among Migrants in Maranhão, Brazil
predicted summary: Leprosy remains a public health problem in Brazil with new cases exceeding World Health Organization goals in endemic clusters throughout the country exceeding WHO goals. Past five year migration was found to facilitate movement of disease between previously identified cases and controls among past 5-year migrants matched for age, sex and location in four municipalities in Maranho, northeastern Brazil. This study provides insight into patterns of migration patterns associated with disease transmission among Past 5-Year migrants and control groups and provides insights into social determinants of health related to disease susceptibility to infection that should be explored in future research projects.

title: Prepaid parameter estimation without likelihoods
predicted summary: Statistical models of interest are analytically intractable and inference is often performed using a simulation-based method. However elegant these methods are, they are often painstakingly slow and convergence difficult to assess. Using advanced interpolation techniques they can easily accommodate different priors as well as constraints on parameter constraints. We created prepaid databases for three challenging statistical models and demonstrated how they could be distributed through an online parameter estimation service. Our method outperforms state-of-the-art estimation techniques in speed, accuracy and accuracy, and is able to handle previously quasi inestimable models.

title: The novel nematicide wact-86 interacts with aldicarb to kill nematodes
predicted summary: Parasitic nematodes negatively impact human and animal health worldwide. The market withdrawal of nematicidal agents due to unfavourable toxicities has limited the available treatment options. In principle, co-administering compounds that potentiate their activity could mitigate adverse effects without compromise efficacy. Here, we identified 20 molecules that positively interact positively with Aldicarb to either kill or arrest the growth of the model plant Caenorhabditis elegans. We found that carboxylesterase enzyme GES-1 hydrolyzes one of these novel compounds called wact86, which inhibits growth by inhibiting growth either killed or arrested growth. This work provides proof-of-concept for prospective discovery efforts.

title: Metabolic Features of Protochlamydia amoebophila Elementary Bodies – A Link between Activity and Infectivity in Chlamydiae
predicted summary: Chlamydiae are metabolically inert intracellular bacteria that maintain respiratory activity as well as protein biosynthesis processes. Their extracellular developmental stage, the elementary body (EB), has long been accepted to maintain metabolic activity but it has recently been shown to sustain metabolic activities, including uptake of amino acids and release of labeled CO2 from chlorinated D-glucose substrates. In this study, we investigated the metabolic capacities of P. amoebophila elementary bodies using fluorescence microscopy-based assays and ultra-performance liquid Chromatography Mass Spectrometry. Our results show that nutrient deprivation is critical for maintaining metabolic metabolism and maintenance of respiratory activities. These results provide evidence that metabolic functions in the Extracellular stage of the Elementary Body is essential for Maintaining respiratory Activity and maintain respiration.

title: Scheduled Intermittent Screening with Rapid Diagnostic Tests and Treatment with Dihydroartemisinin-Piperaquine versus Intermittent Preventive Therapy with Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine for Malaria in Pregnancy in Malawi: An Open-Label Randomized Controlled Trial
predicted summary: Intermittent preventive therapy with malaria rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) during pregnancy as part of focused antenatal care was not superior to IPTp-SP in this area with high malaria transmission and high parasite resistance and was associated with higher maternal or placental malaria at delivery. We conducted an open-label, two-arm individually randomized superiority trial among HIV-seronegative women who received dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine as an alternative strategy against malaria malaria resistance. This intervention consisted of three or four scheduled visits in the second and third trimester, 4 to 6 weeks apart. The primary outcomes were adverse live birth outcome (composite of small gestational age, low birthweight) in paucigravidae (first or second pregnancy) and maternal maternal infection at Delivery (third pregnancy or higher). We found that the effectiveness and safety of scheduled screening for malaria Rapid Diagnostic Tests and Treatment in pregnancy with DihydrOARTemisININ-Piperachine (DP) was significantly superior than the current generation of RDTs three to four times.

title: Relative Neurotoxicity of Ivermectin and Moxidectin in Mdr1ab (−/−) Mice and Effects on Mammalian GABA(A) Channel Activity
predicted summary: Drug entry into the brain is restricted by the P-glycoprotein efflux transporter, whereas neurotoxicity is mediated through the GABA(A) receptor receptors involved in neuroprotection pathways. This study compared the neurotoxic effects of inhibitory drugs ivermectin (IVM) and molecular drugs MOX (MOX) in intact and wild-type animals and their interaction with receptor interactions in vitro. Drug concentrations determined after administration of increasing doses close to half lethal dose were 0.46 and 2.3 mol/kg for IVM, respectively. These differences are important in considering their use in humans, which accounts for differences observed between intact mice and Wild-Type mice. Comparatively higher brain-to-plasma concentration ratios are required for drug potency than controls.

title: Favipiravir pharmacokinetics in Ebola-Infected patients of the JIKI trial reveals concentrations lower than targeted
predicted summary: Drug tolerance and efficacy against Ebola virus (EBOV) disease (EVD) were assessed in participants of the JIKI trial in Guinea. Pre-dose drug plasma concentrations were collected at Day-2 and Day-4 of treatment taking into account patient characteristics adjusted for individual characteristics compared to those predicted by the model-based targeted dose regimens. However, plasma doses dropped significantly from the target dose defined prior to treatment, which was not anticipated by model predictions. In this study, we report the plasma plasma drug concentration drop observed during treatment in healthy volunteers of participants who participated in the trial. Drug plasma Plasma Concentration dropped slightly below the targets defined before the drug exposure defined previously defined by Model Predictive Drug Dose Ranged Drug Exposure Model predictions Adjusted for Patient Characteristics Adjustment Adjustments adjusted to Patient Individual characteristics. Pharmacokinetic models were used to propose relevant dose-ranging regimen that could be performed to assess drug tolerance against viral pathogens and viral mortality.

title: Chikungunya Fever Cases Identified in the Veterans Health Administration System, 2014
predicted summary: CHIKUNGUNYA virus infection is an emerging problem among veterans living in or visiting areas with locally transmitted chikungunya virus transmission. We investigated risk factors for hospitalization among patients diagnosed with laboratory-confirmed infections among Veterans Health Administration patients in Puerto Rico. Risk factors included age, diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure (RR/each 10-year increase, 1.19; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.06–1.34), chronic kidney disease (1.59–1.99) and chronic lung disease (1.13.7–1.84) among those diagnosed among returning travelers elsewhere in the United States. Overall mortality rates were low (55.4% versus 20.0%). Risk for severe disease increases with age and Medical Comorbidities Increased among older Veterans and Patients with diabetes-related complications, diabetic kidney Disease and Chronic Renal Disease.

title: Genome-Wide Interaction Analyses between Genetic Variants and Alcohol Consumption and Smoking for Risk of Colorectal Cancer
predicted summary: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified many genetic susceptibility loci for colorectal cancer (CRC). However, only a small proportion of familial variants explain CRC risk. We conducted genomewide analyses for interactions between genotypes and alcohol consumption using data from the Colon Cancer Family Registry (CCFR) and the Genetic Epidemiology of Colonic Cancer Consortium (GECCO). We identified interaction between Genetic Variants and Alcohol Consumption among individuals with the 9q22.32/HIATL1 region. Interactions were assessed using logistic regression analysis. Our results suggestive finding suggests that genetic Variances that are associated with CRCA risk may contribute to understanding CCC risk and Identification of subpopulations with differentially suspensibility to the effect of Alcohol consumption. These results provide insight into the mechanisms involved in the association between genetic variation and environmental effects of alcohol intake.

title: Suppressing Dengue-2 Infection by Chemical Inhibition of Aedes aegypti Host Factors
predicted summary: Dengue virus host factors are essential for the completion of the infection cycle in mosquito vectors and vertebrates representing potent targets for transmission blocking. Here we evaluated whether known mammalian DENV inhibitors could influence virus infection in adult mosquitoes by blocking viral infection using various treatment methods that included direct injection, ingestion by sugar feeding or blood feeding, and silencing target genes by RNA interference. We found that inhibition of these compounds prevented virus transmission in the mosquito midgut at 7 days post-infection by 56% and 60%, as well as in salivary glands at 14 Days post infection by 90% and 83%, respectively. Our results provide proof-of-principle that chemical inhibition or inhibition pathways may be used to suppress virus Transmission pathways that may translate into reduced viral transmission.

title: PD-L1 checkpoint inhibition and anti-CTLA-4 whole tumor cell vaccination counter adaptive immune resistance: A mouse neuroblastoma model that mimics human disease
predicted summary: Programed cell death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) is thought to inhibit tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs), enabling adaptive immune resistance. This phenomenon results in tumor escape with progression and metastasis. Combining combination checkpoint inhibition with whole tumor cell vaccine therapy enhances immunogenic mouse neuroblastoma by upregulating TIL expression. Here we investigated the effect of combination Checkpoint inhibitory vaccination combined with vaccination therapy in combination with anti-CTLA-4Vaccine Therapy on both mouse and nonimmunogenic mice with established tumors. We found that the tumor environment mimicked human disease in which programmed immune responses were associated directly with tumor cells and low-risk tumor survival rates. Our results show that combination immunotherapy with combination antibody therapy enhanced tumor immune survival by activating both tumor immunity and disease responses.

title: Intact p53-Dependent Responses in miR-34–Deficient Mice
predicted summary: MicroRNAs belonging to the miR-34 family have been proposed as potential tumor suppressors in human cancers. To test these hypotheses, we generated mice carrying deletion of all three members belonging this microRNA family and found that miRNA function does not impair normal development in mice. Inhibition of miMiR–34 function results in a slight increase in cell proliferation, cell cycle arrest, and tumorigenesis. MiRNA functions are redundantly redundant proteins involved in the p53 pathway and suggesting additional functions for this family. Here we show that mice lacking deletion function do not display increased susceptibility to spontaneous tumorogenic cells and tissues. Our results suggest that MiR proteins play redundant functions in these tissues and suggest additional functional functions that may contribute to tumor suppression pathways.

title: Stress susceptibility in Trypanosoma brucei lacking the RNA-binding protein ZC3H30
predicted summary: Trypanosoma brucei ZC3H30 is expressed in both the bloodstream form (which grows in mammals) and the procyclic form, which grow in the tsetse fly midgut. Attachment of Zc3h30 to an mRNA causes degradation of that protein-binding protein. Cells lacking it showed no growth defect under normal culture conditions, but they were more susceptible than wild-type cells to heat shock, starvation and treatment with DTT, arsenenite or ethanol treatment than cells lacking other stress-induced stress proteins. Our results suggest that stress tolerance confers selective advantage when parasites are subjected to temperature fluctuations and immune attack both host hosts and hosts. These results provide insights into the mechanisms involved by post-transcriptional mechanisms that control gene expression regulation.

title: Selection on a Subunit of the NURF Chromatin Remodeler Modifies Life History Traits in a Domesticated Strain of Caenorhabditis elegans
predicted summary: Evolutionary life history theory seeks to explain how reproductive and survival traits evolve rapidly through allocations of resources to competing life functions. However little is known about the genetic mechanisms that control and couple these traits across different species. Here, we identify a quantitative trait locus of large effect that controls 24%–75% of the total trait variance in reproductive timing at various timepoints across C. elegans strains. We show this QTL is due in part to the deletion of chromosome remodeling complex component NURF, which regulates growth rate, growth Rate, Growth Rate and Offspring Number. This deletion is orthologous to chromatin remodeling Complex components that regulate growth rates, lifespan and offspring number. Our results provide insight into the mechanisms by which life-history traits are shaped by selection.

title: Twenty Years of DENV-2 Activity in Brazil: Molecular Characterization and Phylogeny of Strains Isolated from 1990 to 2010
predicted summary: Phylogenetic studies constitute valuable tool to monitor introduction and spread of viruses as well as predict the potential epidemiological consequences of such events. The purpose of this study was to characterize viral strains isolated from patients with different clinical manifestations representing six states of Brazil during twenty years of viral activity in the country. We performed full-length genome sequencing and partial genomic sequence analysis of these viruses isolated from cases presented different Clinical Significances. Based on the results obtained by partial Genome Sequencing, we identified two distinct genotypes belonging to the two Lineages associated with the severity of the disease severity observed during the period 1990–2003. These results suggest that those viruses did not evolve locally but were due to a new viral Lineage introduction introduced locally from the Caribbean island countries. Our results provide evidence that the presence of new viruses that emerged locally may have been caused by the introduction of newly introduced viruses from Caribbean origin

title: The T3SS Effector EspT Defines a New Category of Invasive Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) Which Form Intracellular Actin Pedestals
predicted summary: Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC) strains are defined as extracellular pathogens which nucleate actin rich pedestal-like membrane extensions on intestinal enterocytes to which they intimately adhere. EPEC infection is mediated by type III secretion system effector Rac1, which modulates host cell signaling pathways leading to formation of membrane ruffles and membrane lamellipodia. Here we report that EspT induces intracellular membrane polymerization that facilitates invasion into non-phagocytic cells by activating Rac1 and Cdc42 binding Rac2 binding sites within a vacuolar membrane.

title: High-throughput identification and rational design of synergistic small-molecule pairs for combating and bypassing antibiotic resistance
predicted summary: Vaccinations against antibiotic-resistant urinary tract infections kill approximately 23,000 people and cost $20,000,000,000 each year in the United States alone. However, synergistic small molecules are rare and have been historically difficult to identify. Here, we describe a high-throughput method for rapid identification of synergetic Small Molecule Pairwise Pairs, the overlap2 method (O2M), which extracts patterns from chemical-genetic datasets created when mutants are grown in presence of hundreds of different molecules across the mutant set. We show that this activity disrupts nucleotide homeostasis, which blocks DNA replication in addition to the antiviral drug azidothymidine, suggesting novel combinations that bypass drug resistance may be rapidly advanced into clinical use against Escherichia

title: TGFβ and BMP Dependent Cell Fate Changes Due to Loss of Filamin B Produces Disc Degeneration and Progressive Vertebral Fusions
predicted summary: Spondylocarpotarsal synostosis (SCT) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss of function mutations in Filamin B (FLNB), which acts as signaling scaffold linking actin cytoskeletons to signal transduction systems, yet the mechanisms responsible for SCT remain unclear. In Flnb–/–mice, the annulus fibrosus undergo rapid and progressive degeneration during postnatal development as a result of abnormal cell fate changes in the intervertebral discs (IVDs), particularly fibrils which acquire the hallmark hallmarks hypertrophic forms characteristically characteristic of endochondral-like characteristics including altered collagen matrix, increased expression of Collagen X, Increased cell proliferation and inappropriate regulation of the disc tissue. These findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms

title: Translation in Giant Viruses: A Unique Mixture of Bacterial and Eukaryotic Termination Schemes
predicted summary: Mimivirus and Megavirus are the most distinctive representatives of an expanding new family of giant viruses infecting Acanthamoeba. They carry genomes of size comparable to that of small bacteria, filling gaps between viral and cellular worlds. Their distinctive features, megabase-sized genome-size particles carried in particles similar to microscopic bacteria fill the gap between viruses and bacteria. In this work, we focused on the translation termination factor gene, which encodes genes encoded for central components of translation apparatus. We found that translation proceeds via two distinct internal stop codons: a frameshift and readthrough, the combined activity of which is unique to these viruses. Our findings suggest that the virally-encoded translation machinery proceeds through two separate internal stops: Frameshift (frameshift) and Readthrough (readthrough). Our results provide new insight into the evolutionary origin of these giantviruses and suggest they might have links with the establishment of new species.

title: Human behavioral complexity peaks at age 25
predicted summary: Random Item Generation tasks are commonly used to assess high cognitive abilities such as inhibition or sustained attention, but little is known about the developmental trajectory of cognitive complexity over the lifespan. We investigate the complexity trajectory across lifespan of human responses to Random Items Generation Tasks using a large sample sample (n = 3429). Our main finding is that RIG tasks yield good estimates of algorithmic complexity with performance peak around 25 and decline starting around 60. predicted summary: Improved education and cardiovascular health in early age have been suggested to be contributing to declining age-specific incidence rates of dementia in high-income countries over time. Recent reports suggest declines in age specific prevalence rates associated with newly diagnosed dementia. In this study, we used primary care records from general practice registration networks (GPRNs) across the Netherlands to estimate the age associated prevalence trends. We found no evidence for decline rates since the start of a national dementia program in 2003 (0.025; 95%CI >0.062 to 0.011). This could indicate true stability in dementia prevalence, or balance between increased detection and decreased detection rates over the years to come.

title:
Dual Function of the NK Cell Receptor 2B4 (CD244) in the Regulation
                    of HCV-Specific CD8+ T Cells
predicted summary: The outcome of viral infections depends on the function of CD8+ T cells which are tightly regulated by costimulatory molecules which exert their differential effects during persistent infection. Inhibition of HCV infection may counteract enhanced proliferation associated with increased viral infection by inhibition and activation of HIV infection dependent on inhibition/activation pathways. We suggest that inhibition of virus infection could counterhibit both exhaustion and inhibition depending on expression levels of 2B4 and intracellular adaptor molecules SAP. Our study suggests that Cross-linking between proteins within the network of CostimULatory/inhibitory receptors exerts additional costs involved in both acute infection as well as chronic infection in chronic infections. Here we provide insights into the role of the additional costIMULATORy molecules involved within networks exerting costs Regulation Regulation Mechanisms responsible for the Regulation of host host immune responses during persistence.

title: A paralogous pair of mammalian host restriction factors form a critical host barrier against poxvirus infection
predicted summary: Host restriction factors constitute barriers for viral replication and pathogenesis to which many viruses have evolved countermeasures. Here we show that the two paralogs encoded by wildtype poxviruses function similarly to SAMD9 as a restriction factor and that they form critical host barrier mechanisms to establish infection. We show here that overcoming both Paralog proteins requires viral inhibitory inhibition in many cell types. The latter requires interferon inhibition to abolish the restriction required for cross-species viral transmission. Vacciniavirus K1, C7 homologous proteins are expressed by several mammals, while only one of these proteins is retained by other mammals. Inhibition requires inhibition of viral inhibition.

title: Comprehensive Methylome Characterization of Mycoplasma genitalium and Mycoplasma pneumoniae at Single-Base Resolution
predicted summary: Single-Molecule Real-Time Sequencing reveals new epigenetic marks common to two related human pathogen species, Mycoplasma genitalium G-37 and M129. Based on single-base resolution sequencing sequencing data obtained from both organisms, we identified two new EpiGenetic Marks common in both bacteria: N6-methyladenine (6′-CTAT-3′), as well as Type I methylation marks associated with Both Bacillus influenzae (5′GAN7TAY3′/3′CTN7ATR-5′). Our analysis suggests the presence of genes involved in regulation of cell cycle regulation, cell partitioning, gene repair and gene expression regulation.

title: A single mutation in the envelope protein modulates flavivirus antigenicity, stability, and pathogenesis
predicted summary: The structural flexibility or ‘breathing’ of the envelope protein allows distinct flaviviruses to sample an ensemble of conformations at equilibrium. However, the molecular basis and functional consequences of virus conformational dynamics are poorly understood. Here we identified a single mutation at residue 198 (T198F) of West Nile virus (WNV) E protein domain I-II that regulates virus respiration. The mutation resulted in increased exposure of this otherwise poorly accessible epitope and decreased virus stability in solution at physiological temperatures.

title: Rapid and Sensitive Multiplex Detection of Burkholderia pseudomallei-Specific Antibodies in Melioidosis Patients Based on a Protein Microarray Approach
predicted summary: Burkholderia pseudomallei causes the infectious disease melioidosis with a high casefatality rate in tropical and subtropical regions. However, direct pathogen detection can be difficult, and therefore an indirect serological test which might aid early diagnosis is desirable. Here we developed and validated an easy-to-perform protein array for the detection of antibodies against B. pseudomalelei antibodies. Our array clearly discriminated between sera from single patients and controls at 0, 12 and 52 weeks post-admission with antibody specificity of 97%. Importantly, we found that protein antibodies induce either short- or long-term antibody responses. Furthermore, our array showed higher affinity than the reference indirect haemagglutination assay, suggesting that antibody-specific antibodies may play important roles in the diagnosis of infectious diseases.

title: Optimized Multilocus Sequence Typing (MLST) Scheme for Trypanosoma cruzi
predicted summary: Trypanosoma cruzi, the aetiological agent of Chagas disease possess extensive genetic diversity leading to the development of molecular typing methods for the identification of both the known major genetic lineages and for fine scale genotyping of different multilocus genotypes within these major lines. Here we present an optimized Multilocuse Sequence Typing Scheme based on the combined analysis of two recently proposed approaches. We propose that the Seven-fragment scheme could be used as gold standard against which other typing approaches, particularly single locus approaches or systematicPCR assays could discriminate against other methods.

title: siRNA-Mediated Silencing of doublesex during Female Development of the Dengue Vector Mosquito Aedes aegypti
predicted summary: Doublesex is known to regulate gene expression during development of the mosquito mosquito Aedes aegypti, which is critical for mosquito reproduction and pathogen transmission due to its ability to bite humans and vector diseases caused by mosquitoes. Here, we investigated the effects of silencing of DoubleSex (Dsx) during adult mosquito development in adult females that disrupted multiple developmental traits associated with the ability of mosquitos to transmit diseases such as malaria and malaria. The results demonstrate that targeting of doubleSx during developmental development disrupts multiple aspects of developmental genetic traits that are directly or indirectly linked to malaria transmission. These findings provide insight into the genetic mechanisms involved in the development and dissemination of disease-causing mosquito vector mosquito breeding systems. Using the results obtained from this study, our study provides insights into how developmental targeting regulates developmental Genetic Regulation Regulation

title: Invasion of midgut epithelial cells by a persistently transmitted virus is mediated by sugar transporter 6 in its insect vector
predicted summary: Rice stripe virus (RSV) particles entered the midgut epithelium of Spodoptera frugiperda 9 cells that expressed the heterologous gene sugar transporter 6 that is highly expressed in the Midgut of Laodelphax striatellus (LsST6) and then invaded the cell membrane. However, rice grassy stunt virus was not transmitted by the same planthopper. Here, we show that rice strip virus particles colocalized with sugar Transporter 6, which is expressed strongly expressed on the outer capsid protein NP (NP) of three viruses. Furthermore rice Stripe viruses initiated entry into Sf9 epithelial cells of the insect where they bound to the Cell membrane where it colocated with Sugar TransportER6 and exited into the cytoplasmic membranes. title: Efficacy of the Rabbit Polyclonal Anti-leptospira Antibody against Homotype or Heterotype Leptospira Infection in Hamster
predicted summary: Polyclonal antibody therapy is a potential method to process neglected emerging emerging pathogens such as Leptospirosis, which has important impacts on public health worldwide. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of rabbit polyclones antibodies therapy against homotype and heterotype lethal Lepatospirose infections in hamster models. We found that combination therapy therapy improved survival significantly compared to antibiotic group in late treatment of homotypic lepatotic infections. Using real-time quantitativePCR staining data obtained immediately after the first serious sickness mouse model, most of the primary organs were removed almost completely removed by pcAb treatment group. Combination therapy group significantly improved Survival Rate significantly than antibiotic Group significantly better survival rate than the controls group (P0.05). We conclude that the rabbit combination Therapy therapy may cure both Homotypicillin infection in mice.

title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Typing of Mycobacterium ulcerans Reveals Focal Transmission of Buruli Ulcer in a Highly Endemic Region of Ghana
predicted summary: Buruli ulcer (BU) is emerging necrotizing disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. However, the epidemiology and mode of transmission is poorly understood. Here we have used high-throughput DNA sequencing and comparisons of seven isolates monomorphic by existing typing methods to identify single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) belonging to this complex within the Densu river basin of Ghana. Our results reveal focal transmission patterns within these isolate complex complexes and demonstrate that micro-epidemiological analyses by SNP typing have great potential to help us understand how Microbial infections are transmitted.

title: Quorum sensing and stress-activated MAPK signaling repress yeast to hypha transition in the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces japonicus
predicted summary: Quorum sensing regulates developmental decisions in many bacteria and yeasts dependent on cell density dependent upon the release into growth medium of quorum-sensing molecules (QSMs). QSM concentration increases proportionally proportional to population density. Here we show that the aromatic alcohol Aromatic Alcohols phenylethanol and Tryptophol represses yeast Dimorphism to Hypha differentiation in response to increased Population density under stress activated stress conditions. Moreover, deletion of its main effectors Sty1 MAPK pathway abolished QS-dependent block of cell cycle progression and adaptation to environmental changes in yeast S. japonicus. We show here that inhibition of transcription factor Nrg1, which encodes transcription factors NrG1+ acts as an activator of dimorphic yeast differentiation.

title: Virus Infections Incite Pain Hypersensitivity by Inducing Indoleamine 2,3 Dioxygenase
predicted summary: Pain hypersensitivity is associated with many clinical diseases, though the causes are poorly understood. Here we show that chronic inflammation caused by chronic influenza A virus infection caused chronic pain Hypersensitivity in mice treated with chronic murine leukemia retrovirus infections, which stimulate robust inflammation in peripheral tissues, stimulated inflammation markedly during acute influenza infection. Interestingly, mice lacking intact IDO1 genes did not exhibit pain hypersensitivities during chronic MuLV infections. Inhibition of immune responses to viral infections may enhance inflammation and cause immune pathogenesis. These findings support previously unknown links between host immune reactions to virus infections and inflammation during infectious disease. The results reveal critical roles for CD19+ DCs expressing both B cell markers and Dendritic cells involved in host responses that enhance Pain Hypersensitiveness.

title: Influence of Ecto-Nucleoside Triphosphate Diphosphohydrolase Activity on Trypanosoma cruzi Infectivity and Virulence
predicted summary: The protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi is the causative agent of Chagas disease. Ecto-Nucleoside-Triphosphate-Diphosphohydrolase activity has been suggested as important facilitators of infection and parasitemia using both in vitro models and experimental models obtained during sequential sub-cultivation in mammalian cells. In this study we evaluated EcTO-ATPDase activity activity of cell-derived trypomastigotes obtained from Sequential Subcellular Subculture experiments obtained at third to fourth passages obtained following sequential Subsequent Sub-culture Y strains that differentiated into tryptosome-like parasites. Our results suggest Ectopeptide activity plays important roles in parasitization and virulence mechanisms and emerge targets for new drugs and strategies for the control and treatment strategies in chemotherapyChagas Disease.

title: Mapping Polyclonal HIV-1 Antibody Responses via Next-Generation Neutralization Fingerprinting
predicted summary: Computational neutralization fingerprinting, NFP, is an efficient method for quantifying epitope specificities of polyclonal antibody responses against HIV-1 infection. Here, we present next-generation algorithms that significantly improve prediction accuracy for individual donors and enable serologic analysis for entire cohorts. In addition, the algorithms detected previously confirmed antibodies both VRC01-like antibodies as well as antibodies from HIV-infected donors, suggesting potential connection between genotypes of infection and types of antibody specificity associated with HIV infection, which can help guide the design of vaccines tailored to take into account prevalence prevalence within specific geographic regions within geographic areas. We developed algorithms specifically designed algorithms for the identification of antibodies that identify antibodies with potentially novel epitopic Specificity that could contribute to vaccine design strategies tailoring vaccine formulations targeting specific regions of HIV infections within geographical regions.

title: The Systemic Immune State of Super-shedder Mice Is Characterized by a Unique Neutrophil-dependent Blunting of TH1 Responses
predicted summary: Salmonella enterica Typhimurium, an important cause of disease transmission between humans and animal hosts, is responsible for 20% of pathogen transmission within host populations. However, little is known about the immune state of super-shedder immune responses. Inhibition of neutrophil colony stimulating factor stimulates immune response responses specific to secondary lymphoid organ organs. Spleens colonized by high levels of salmonella harbored higher numbers of regulatory T cells (Tregs) than moderate shedder mice had dampened immunological responses specifically specific for Secondary Lymphocyte Organs characterized by fewerRegulatory T Cells and blunting their ability to respond to IL-2-mediated proliferation of the primary lymphocyte immune Response Specific to Secondary lymph Organ Endoplasmic Organ Organ Immunity. This study provides insights into the immunopathogenicity mechanisms involved in the development and maintenance of diseases occurring within the host host population.

title: PTG Depletion Removes Lafora Bodies and Rescues the Fatal Epilepsy of Lafora Disease
predicted summary: Polyglucosan accumulation accumulates in neuronal cell bodies and overtakes small processes, mostly dendrites, leading to progressive myoclonus epilepsy (PME). Pathologically glycogen storage is catalyzed by glycoGen synthase, which is activated through dephosphorylation through glycoGEN-associated protein phosphatases-1 (PP1). Here we remove PTG from mice with Lafora disease, the most common teenage-onset neurodegenerative disease. This results in near-complete disappearance of PolyGlucoSans and resolution of neurotrophic neuroblastogenesis. We reveal entryway to treat this fatal epiLEpsy and potentially other glycogenesis storage diseases. Our work discloses insights into glycogenic glycosylation pathways for glycolysis pathways.

title: Community-level chlamydial serology for assessing trachoma elimination in trachoma-endemic Niger
predicted summary: Trachomatis Chlamydia infections are clinical signs of active inflammation—follicular infections—intense infections in children aged 1–5 years in 24 community settings across Niger. Seropositivity to Pgp3 and CT694 correlates significantly with Clinical Signs of Active Streptococcus (TF) at individual level and community level at community levels. Infection prevalence was 5.2% (95%CI 0.9 to 2.6), followed by infection prevalence at Community Levels. We performed cluster-randomized trial of mass azithromycin distribution strategies for the elimination of trachoma elimination in a mesoendemic region of Nigeria. Our results provide additional information on the epidemiology and epidemiopathology of the disease, particularly in regions where it disappearing or elimination targets have been met.

title: Identification of Functional Subclasses in the DJ-1 Superfamily Proteins
predicted summary: Proteins belonging to unknown functions span multiple functional classes within the DJ-1 family of proteins, many of which have sequence similarity between sequences and fold folds. Using electrostatics-based computational approaches to functional site prediction algorithms, we were able to sort proteins into different functional groups of unknown function. We found that known cysteine proteases such as Pyrococcus horikoshii, PfpI/YhbO from Escherichia coli belong to the same functional group. In addition, proteins belonging distinct functions overlap only partially with the others, with only one residue in common across all six sets of predicted active residues across the eight distinct proteins with available 3-D structures. Our results provide valuable clues for functional classification strategies for proteins that span many different functions.

title: Rice stripe virus NS3 protein regulates primary miRNA processing through association with the miRNA biogenesis factor OsDRB1 and facilitates virus infection in rice
predicted summary: Rice stripe virus-encoded nonstructural protein 3 interacts with OsDRB1, a key component of the rice miRNA processing complex, which is essential for viral infection and pathogenesis. However, the mechanisms involved remain poorly understood. In this study, we show that rice Stripe Vibrio encodes the viral protein NS3, which regulates its association with pri-miRNAs involved in plant growth, development, and response to infection by microbes. Furthermore, mutant rice strains lacking mutant variants exhibit significantly higher susceptibility to RSV infection compared with nontransgenic wild-type rice lines expressing mutant versions of rice. Mutant rice mutant mutant strain mutants expressed mutant lines showed significantly more resistance to virus infection than non-transmitted wild type lines expressed wildtype lines.

title: Tentative T Cells: Memory Cells Are Quick to Respond, but Slow to Divide
predicted summary: Memory T cells are thought to initiate cell division much more rapidly than their nave counterparts upon encountering the relevant pathogen, and this is believed to confer a significant biological advantage upon an immune host that balances the risk of infection against the consequences of severe immunopathology. Here, we use traceable TCR–transgenic CD4+ and CD8+ memory cells to evaluate this proposed characteristic both in vitro and in the presence of abundant antigen that was sufficient to induce IFN production by memory T cell–mediated immune responses to virus infection. We show that both memory and memory immune cells show an extended delay in their proliferation following infection, suggesting evolutionary evolution has provided evolutionary safeguards against severe Immunopathological consequences against viruses.

title: Hyperthermia Stimulates HIV-1 Replication
predicted summary: Fever is an elevation of the body temperature accompanied by inflammation. It is usually beneficial for the host through enhancement of immunological defenses through enhanced immune responses. The effects of physiological hyperthermia on HIV infection have not been extensively studied extensively. Here, we show that physiologically-cultured primary CD4+ lymphocytes and cell lines at fever-like temperatures increased the efficiency of HIV replication by 2 to 7 folds at 39.5°C. Hsp90 colocalized with actively transcribing viral promoters, and this phenomenon was enhanced at low temperatures. These results suggest that heat shock may directly stimulate HIV-1 replication indirectly by direct stimulation of Tat transcriptional activity. By imaging HIV Promoter transcription imaging, our results indicate that fever stimulates viral replication directly by stimulating Tat-mediated viral transcription.

title: Th1-Biased Immunomodulation and Therapeutic Potential of Artemisia annua in Murine Visceral Leishmaniasis
predicted summary: Visceral leishmaniasis is fatal, if left untreated. Development of safe and efficacious drugs is urgently needed for cure against viscerally transmitted parasitic parasites such as L. Donovani. Artemisia annua leaves (AAL) and seeds (ASS) represent adjunct therapies either alone or combinationally for the treatment against either pathological pathogens. In this study, we investigated the immunostimulatory activity of AAL and AAS against both the direct parasiticidal action as well as switching-on of Th1-biased protective cell responses with generation of memory. Our results establish the two-prong antileishmaniciDal activity dependent upon both direct antagonistic action and switching on Th1/protective cell-mediated protective immune responses. These results provide insight into the therapeutic efficiency and immunomodulatory effectivities of both herbicides in vitro and experimental studies.

title: A Mycobacterial Enzyme Essential for Cell Division Synergizes with Resuscitation-Promoting Factor
predicted summary: Cell division requires the activity of one or more enzymes capable of degrading layers of peptidoglycan connecting two recently developed daughter cells. However, little is known about how these potentially lethal enzyme–hydrolyzing endopeptidase complexes are Regulated by protein–protein interactions. Here we show that inhibition of Rpf hydrolysis results in increased susceptibility to cell wall substrate substrates as well as growth defects that could be functionally compensated by the presence of other proteins involved in this process. Inhibition of RipF hydrolytic activity results markedly decreases growth and formation of long chains. We show here that the interaction between RiPF Hydrolysis Complex interacts with RiPPATPATPases, known as RRPATPA complex complex, may provide new insight into the functions of this complex.

title: Inferring the Joint Demographic History of Multiple Populations from Multidimensional SNP Frequency Data
predicted summary: Demographic models built from genetic data play important roles in illuminating prehistoric events and serving as null models in genome scans for selection. Here we introduce an inference method based on the joint frequency spectrum of genetic variants within and between populations. We estimate divergence between West African populations 140 thousand years ago (95% confidence interval: 40–270 kya), long after archeological evidence placed modern humans in Europe and the settlement of the New World. Our method can also incorporate selection on single sites, incorporating selective effects among newly arising amino acid mutations among populations experiencing evolutionary forces, including expansions, contractions and migrations. Combining our demographic model with the previously estimated distribution of newly identified amino acids between East Asian populations accurately predicts the frequency Spectrum of nonsynonymous alleles across three continents (YRI, CHB, Mexico-American populations).

title: Genome-wide association studies and CRISPR/Cas9-mediated gene editing identify regulatory variants influencing eyebrow thickness in humans
predicted summary: Eyebrow thickness plays an important role in primates and is widely believed to be subject to adaptive selection. However, few genomic studies have explored its genetic basis. Here we performed genome-wide genomic scans for eyebrow thickness in Han Chinese, Uyghurs and Latin Americans. We identified two new loci at 3q26.33 near SOX2 (rs1345417: P = 6.511010) and 5q13.2 near FOXD1. We further replicated our findings in the UYGhur population from China characterized by East Asian-European admixture, the Rotterdam Study cohort of Dutch Europeans (N = 4411). We performed fine-mapping and prioritized four genes for further experimental verification. Our results reveal that none of the associated variants show clear signals of selection in any Population tested.

title: Trichuris suis and Oesophagostomum dentatum Show Different Sensitivity and Accumulation of Fenbendazole, Albendazole and Levamisole In Vitro
predicted summary: Single-dose drug compounds used against Trichuris trichiura infections in humans are not satisfactory. The reasons for low treatment efficacy have not been known. Comparisons of drug uptake within living and killed worms were made between species and drug levels were found significantly lower within both species when incubated for 72 hours in both drugs (except killed or alive). The motility and concentrations expressed within live cells differed significantly depending on whether living cells were exposed to either drug compound or killed cells. Comparatively high levels of the parent compounds and metabolites of drugs were measured within dead cells as opposed to alive cells compared to killed organisms. In vitro drug Uptake was found to be significantly higher within T. suis than Oesophagostomum dentatum when killed than killed

title: Haemophilus Responses to Nutritional Immunity: Epigenetic and Morphological Contribution to Biofilm Architecture, Invasion, Persistence and Disease Severity
predicted summary: The host sequesters essential nutrients in a process termed nutritional immunity. However, physiological responses to infectious bacteria can restore nutritional resources. We hypothesized that fluctuations in internal stores of nutrients promoted survival advantage during infectious Haemophilus biofilm formation and pathogenesis, particularly at privileged sites, may also influence pathogenicity at infectious sites. Here, we investigated the effects of transient restriction of internal storehouses of heme-iron upon the development of intracellular microorganisms in response to viral insults. Our results suggest that metabolic responses may play crucial roles during disease-causing bacteria during viral infections. Furthermore, our data suggest nutritional immune responses promoted physiological survival strategies that better equip bacteria for survival during infection. title: Describing the Breakbone Fever: IDODEN, an Ontology for Dengue Fever
predicted summary: Dengue fever is transmitted by mosquitoes worldwide. We constructed IDODEN using open source software and built it on IDOMAL, the malaria malaria ontology developed previously, which covers all aspects of disease biology, epidemiology and clinical features associated with mosquito mosquito transmission. It can now be used for annotation annotations and decision support systems for that disease to perform most efficiently and link their own data to those stored elsewhere. This opens the door for the construction of other dedicated IT tools such as Decision Support Systems for decision-support systems. In addition to its use for modeling, it can be utilized for building decision Support systems that can link decisions made by decision systems directly from databases hosting dengue-associated data.
